MSE 4002.course_name: Ceramic Materials: Properties, Processing, Applications.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4002.course_description: Properties, processing, and applications of the industrially and technically important ceramic materials. Traditional and oxide ceramics in addition to glass and nonoxide ceramics.

MSE 4004.course_name: Materials in Electronic Applications.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4004.course_description: Basics of photolithography, screen printing, and tape casting.  Requirements for fuel cells, magnetic nanocomposites, flat-panel displays, gas sensors, piezoelectric acutators, photonic crystals, etc.

MSE 4006.course_name: Processing and Applications of Engineering Alloys.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4006.course_description: Solidification, deformation, and powder processing of metals and alloy;, microstructural design at nano- and meso-length scales; and structure-property correlations.

MSE 4010.course_description: Theory of environmental degradation of metals, ceramics, polymers, and biomaterials.  Emphasis on the scientific principles of corrosion and physical degradation.

MSE 4022.course_description: Processing, structure, properties relationships are explored through a series of hands-on experiments. Instruction on basic laboratory skills, safety, statistical analysis of data, use of laboratory notebooks and technical report writing.

MSE 4025.course_description: The manufacture of fiber products and their process- structure-property relationships are detailed, covering fibers, yarns, fabrics, nonwovens, carpets, composites, and related materials.

MSE 4026.course_name: Testing and Evaluation of Polymer and Fiber Products.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4026.course_description: Properties influencing the end use performance of fiber and polymer products including that of plastic materials will be tested using standard ASTM, AATC and federal test methods.  Standard statistical tools will be used to analyze and interpret the test data.

MSE 4100.course_name: Chemical Applications to Fiber Materials.  2 Credit Hours.
MSE 4100.course_description: The chemical, thermal, and mechanical processes used in the preparation, coloration, printing and finishing of polymeric fiber materials are explored.  Credit not allowed for MSE 4100.

MSE 4122.course_description: Laboratory course in preparation, coloration and finishing of fiber materials.  Credit not allowed for MSE 4122.

MSE 4140.course_description: Physical chemistry of polymer solutions, polymer miscibility, adsorptions, sorptions, plasticization, molecular weights, molecular weight distributions. Study of polymer surfaces.  Credit not allowed for MSE 4140.

MSE 4230.course_name: Industrial Ctrls In MFG.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4230.course_description: Introduction to industrial controls in manufacturing, process modeling, control of continuous-variable processes, digital control, discrete control, and control of manufacturing systems.

MSE 4315.course_description: Principles and theory of industrial nondestructive evaluation methods are covered.  Emphasis is on testing the soundness and reliability of primary and secondary engineering structures.

MSE 4320.course_name: Electronic Packaging and Design.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4320.course_description: Electronic packaging design, covering properties of materials, fabrication and assembly processes, thermal-mechanical considerations, practical concerns regarding interconnection and processing issues, and reliability assessment.

MSE 4325.course_name: Thin Film Materials Science.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4325.course_description: Introduction to principal vapor deposition processes and vacuum technology. The fundamentals of the formation, characterization, and properties of inorganic nano- to micro-scale thin films.

MSE 4330.course_name: Fundamentals of Nanomaterials and Nanostructures.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4330.course_description: Introduction to nanotechnology.  Description of various nanomaterials, their applications and synthesis methods.

MSE 4335.course_name: Soft Nano and Bio Materials.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4335.course_description: Introduction soft nanomaterials and nanostructures that have been discovered and synthesized for prospective applications in nanotechnology.

MSE 4410.course_name: Capstone Engineering Design I.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4410.course_description: A capstone engineering design course covering the principles of concurrent product/process design and development.  Team-based projects will explore product/process design and development.  Credit not allowed for MSE 4410.

MSE 4420.course_name: Capstone Engineering Design II.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4420.course_description: A team problem-solving approach is used to work on a project developed in cooperation with industry.  Weekly communications, both oral and written, are required.   Credit not allowed for MSE 4420.

MSE 4698.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

MSE 4699.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

MSE 4723.course_description: Seniors will work in teams to apply a systematic design process to real multi-disciplinary problems. Problems selected from a broad spectrum of interest areas, including biomedical, environmental, mechanical, industrial design, electrical and thermal/fluids. Projects must be based on the knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work, and incorporate appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints. Emphasis is placed on the design process, the technical aspects of the design, and on reducing the proposed design to practice.  The course consists of faculty and guest lectures, prototyping in design studios, and a multi-disciplinary design project.

MSE 4740.course_description: We examine evolutionary adaptation as a source for engineering design inspiration, utilizing principles of scaling, adaptability, and robust multifunctionality that characterize biological systems.  Credit not allowed for both MSE 4740 and (BIOL 4740 or ISYE 4740 or ME 4740).

MSE 4751.course_description: Introduction to different classes of biomaterials (polymers, metals, ceramics) and physiological responses to biomaterial implantation. Topics include material properties, host response, and biomaterial characterization techniques. Crosslisted with BMED 4751.

MSE 4754.course_name: Electronics Packaging Assembly, Reliability, Thermal Management, and Test.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4754.course_description: The course provides hands-on instruction in electronics packaging, including assembly, reliability, thermal management, and test of next-generation microsystems. Crosslisted with ECE and ME 4754.

MSE 4755.course_name: Electronic Packaging Substrate Fabrication.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4755.course_description: This course provides students with hands-on instruction in basic SOP concepts and techniques, including interconnect design, substrate material selection and properties, photodielectric deposition, via formation and photolithography, copper metallization, and finally, substrate testing. Laboratory instructions are augmented by an interactive multimedia educational presentation that makes the course work material remotely accessible via the internet.

MSE 4759.course_name: Electrochemical Energy Storage and Conversion.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4759.course_description: An elective class for senior-level students interested in electrochemical storage and conversion, including the fundamentals of electrochemistry and practical battery and fueld cells. Cross-listed with ChBE and ME 4759.

MSE 4761.course_name: Industrial Controls and Manufacturing.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4761.course_description: Students are introduced to industrial controls and the fundamentals of manufacturing with hands-on experience based on lab projects using industry software and hardware for communications and control. Credit not allowed for MSE 4761.

MSE 4766.course_name: Fabrication and Properties of Nanoscale Devices.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4766.course_description: Fundamental properties at the nanoscale for photonics and sensors.  Nanoscale fabrication methods including thin films, ion beam, lithography, electroplating, and example case studies in NEMS/MEMS and photonics.  Credit not allowed for both MSE 4766 and ME 4766.

MSE 4775.course_name: Polymer Science and Engineering I: Formation and Properties.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4775.course_description: An introduction to the chemistry, structure, and formation of polymers, physical states and transitions, physical and mechanical properties of polymer fluids and solids. Crosslisted with CHE, CHEM, and ME 4775.

MSE 4776.course_name: Polymer Science and Engineering II: Analysis, Processing, and Laboratory.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4776.course_description: Polymer fabrication processes and methods of characterization and identification of polymers are presented. Experiments in polymerization, processing, and property evaluation of polymers. Crosslisted with CHE, CHEM, ME, and TFE 4776.

MSE 4790.course_name: Materials Selection and Design.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4790.course_description: Principles of selecting materials and processes for engineering applications.  Methodologies for designing new materials and conceiving hybrid solutions.  Credit not allowed for both MSE 4790 and ME 4213 (or ME 4790).

MSE 4791.course_name: Mechanical Behavior of Composites.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4791.course_description: Introduction to properties and structures of common matrix and reinforcing materials, mechanics of fiber-reinforced composites, lamina and laminate analysis, and mechanical performance. Crosslisted with AE, CEE, CHE, and ME 4791.

MSE 4793.course_name: Composite Materials and Processing.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4793.course_description: Basic principles of selecting component materials and manufacturing composites are presented.  Polymeric, metallic, and ceramic systems are considered. Crosslisted with AE, CEE, CHE, and ME 4793.

MSE 4794.course_name: Composite Materials and Manufacturing.  4 Credit Hours.
MSE 4794.course_description: Basic principles of selection and design of composite materials and their manufacturing and testing. Cost factors. Laboratory exercises on manufacturing and tests. Crosslisted with AE, CEE, CHE, and ME 4794.

MSE 4795.course_name: Fundamental Elements of Nuclear Reactor Materials.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 4795.course_description: Introduction to fundamentals of nuclear reactor materials.  Topics covered are basics of radiation damage, defect creation and evolution, microstructure-property correlations in cladding and fuel of nuclear materials.

MSE 4XXX.course_name: Materials Science & Engineering Elective.  1-21 Credit Hours.

MSE 6001.course_name: Written and Visual Communications.  2 Credit Hours.
MSE 6001.course_description: Writing and editing engineering documents; designing and explaining visuals; creating electronic presentations. May not be used for duplicate credit with MSE 6754.

MSE 6010.course_name: Fundamentals of Functional Materials.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6010.course_description: This course focuses on the effects of defects on physical properties; charge/mass transport; semiconductors, heterojunctions, electrical and magnetic polarization, interaction processes between various physical properties; electrical characterization techniques.

MSE 6105.course_description: Principles and theory of crystallography and diffraction analysis of materials are covered, emphasizing X-ray diffraction, including electron diffraction and diffraction-based imaging.  Reciprocal lattice concepts are emphasized.

MSE 6110.course_description: Introduction to the kinematical electron scattering theory, optics in TEM, diffraction contrast imaging of defects, dynamical electron diffraction effects; and chemical microanalysis using EDS.

MSE 6120.course_name: Quantitative Characterization of Microstructures.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6120.course_description: Application of statistically unbiased methods for estimating geometrical attributes of microstructures and nonplanar fracture surfaces from plane sections and projections, digital image analysis, and computer simulations of microstructures.

MSE 6130.course_description: Introduction to vacuum science and technology; structure of solid surfaces; electron and ion energy analyzers, electron spectroscopies (e.g., AES and XPS); ion-based techniques (e.g., SIMS and RBS); depth profiling; ion channeling.

MSE 6140.course_name: Computational Materials Science and Engineering.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6140.course_description: This course aims to provide a broad understanding of a spectrum of modern state-of-the-art computational methods used in materials science and engineering.

MSE 6210.course_description: Emphasis on the origin and character of point, line, and surface defects in crystalline materials and their influence on mechanical, chemical, magnetic, optical, and electronic properties.

MSE 6310.course_name: Thermodynamics and Kinetics of Transformations.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6310.course_description: Classical thermodynamics and phase equlibria with applications to chemical reactions, control of phase transformations via reduction of chemical-free energy, strain energy, and interfacial energy.

MSE 6334.course_name: Materials for Energy Storage and Conversion.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6334.course_description: Scientific principles concerning the transfer, capture, and storage of energy harnessed from various sources, including solar, wind, geothermal, and biomass.

MSE 6335.course_name: Fundamentals of Soft Nanomaterials and Nanostructures.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6335.course_description: Fundamentals and applications of soft (polymer and biological) nanomaterials such as colloidal assemblies, self-assembled structures, energy devices, photonic materials, drug delivery, flexible electronics, soft robotics.

MSE 6401.course_description: To examine the principles of thermodynamics as applied to equilibria associated with solutions, mixtures, chemical reactions, and interfaces in materials.

MSE 6402.course_name: Crystallography, Structure and Defects.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6402.course_description: Provides students with a fundamental understanding of crystal structures, symmetry, origin, character, defects in crystalline materials, and the influence of these defects on different properties.

MSE 6403.course_name: Kinetics of Phase Transformations.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6403.course_description: To introduce the fundamentals of thermodynamics and mathematics to the kinetics of diffusional and non-diffusional phase transformation in engineering materials.

MSE 6404.course_description: A general introduction to the scattering/diffraction of electromagnetic radiation from solids.  The kinematical formalism is developed emphasizing x-ray scattering as a characterization tool.

MSE 6405.course_description: Topics include the synthesis and growth processes controlling quantum dot formation, nanowires, and three- dimensional self-assembled nanostructures.  Additional characterization techniques and emerging applications are presented.

MSE 6406.course_description: To introduce students to the basic kinetic mechanisms associated with the interactions of materials with liquids and gases.

MSE 6407.course_description: Addresses structure-property relationship of cellular components.

MSE 6408.course_description: Fundamental of quantum mechanics of atoms, molecules and solids necessary for engineers to understand the electronic, optical and thermal properties of inorganic and organic materials.

MSE 6409.course_description: Course covers thermodynamics, and kinetics of metallic corrosion in electrolytes and high-temperature oxidation. Different forms of corrosion, their mechanisms, and corrosion control methods are discussed.

MSE 6411.course_description: This course introduces structural features of materials, including point/space groups, representative crystal structures, quasi-crystals, amorphous and rubbery state, liquid crystals, colloids, solutions, and effect of symmetry on properties.

MSE 6412.course_description: This course introduces structural features of materials, including point/space groups, representative crystal structures, quasi-crystals, amorphous and rubbery state, liquid crystals, colloids, solutions, and effect of symmetry on properties.

MSE 6500.course_description: To examine the principles of thermodynamics as applied to equilibria associated with solutions, mixtures, chemical reactions, and interfaces in materials.

MSE 6501.course_description: The object of this course is to review the concepts of phase equilibria in ceramic and metallic systems and develop the methodology to calculate phase diagrams in these systems.

MSE 6502.course_description: To examine the principles of thermodynamics as applied to equilibria associated with mixtures and solutions.

MSE 6510.course_name: Polymers for Electronic and Photonic Applications I.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6510.course_description: Review of fundamentals and principles of polymers used in electronics and photonics;  relationships between the advances of semiconductor technology and the importance of polymers and their applications.

MSE 6600.course_description: Common polymer processing techniques and recent advancement; Modeling of polymer processing focusing on how to build a sound model; Computer aided engineering for polymer processing.

MSE 6601.course_name: Carbon Nanotubes, Graphene, and Nanocomposites.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6601.course_description: Synthesis, characterization, and properties of carbon nanotubes and graphene.  Carbon nanotube and graphene dispersion in various media.  Carbon nanotube and graphene nano-composites processing and applications.

MSE 6602.course_name: Tensor Analysis and Mathematical Techniques for Materials.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6602.course_description: Introduction to tensor analysis and mathematical techniques for solving problems enountered in materials physics, processing and characterization, particularily involving polymeric fluids and solids.

MSE 6603.course_description: The structures and properties of natural products are presented.  Production of cellulose and proteins in discussed.  Credit not allowed for both MSE 6603 and PTFE 6301.

MSE 6610.course_description: The course will emphasize the interaction between the human body environment and synthetic materials. Materials for both medical implants and dental restoration and appliances will be covered.

MSE 6620.course_description: The emphasis will be on electrochemical corrosion and dry oxidation of metals and alloys.  In the laboratory, the student will be introduced to the methodology of corrosion testing.

MSE 6730.course_name: Materials Science of Cellular Components.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6730.course_description: Addresses structure-property relationship of cellular components.  Credit not allowed for both MSE 6730 and BMED 6730.

MSE 6750.course_name: Preparation & Reactions of Polymers.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6750.course_description: A detailed treatment of the reactions involved in the synthesis of both human-made and natural polymers, including preparation and degradative reactions of polymer systems.

MSE 6751.course_name: Physical Chemistry of Polymer Solutions.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6751.course_description: Study of polymer solutions, polymer miscibility, adsorption, sorptions, plasticization, molecular weights, molecular weight distribution, and interfacial phenomena using thermodynamics and statistical mechanics. Crosslisted with CHEM, CHE, and PTFE 6751.

MSE 6752.course_description: This course introduces the student to surface, near-surface and structural methods of polymer characterization. Specialized techniques critical to physical structure are emphasized. Crosslisted with CHEM, CHE, and PTFE 6752.

MSE 6754.course_description: Writing and editing engineering documents; designing and explaining visuals; creating and delivering electronic presentations. Crosslisted with CEE 6754.

MSE 6755.course_name: Theoretical Chemistry of Polymers.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6755.course_description: Thermodynamics and microscopic dynamics of polymers. Fundamental concepts, including scaling concepts, governing anisotropy of polarizability, phase transitions, morphology, time-dependent correlations, etc. are discussed. Crosslisted with CHEM and PTFE 6755.

MSE 6757.course_description: Advanced topics in synthetic polymerization methodology, polymer structure, and polymer properties in solution and the solid state.

MSE 6759.course_name: Materials in Environmentally Conscious Design and Manufacturing.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6759.course_description: Covers the environmental impact of materials choices and quantitative measure of life-cycle assessment and environmental burden.  The Natural Step philosophy will be used as a model for the overall approach. Crosslisted with ME and PTFE 6759.

MSE 6768.course_name: Polymer Structure, Physical Properties, and Characterization.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6768.course_description: Formulations and analysis of molecular and phenomenological models of elastic and viscoelastic behavior, development and description of structure, and fundamental aspects of structure-property relations.  Crosslisted with TFE, CHE, and ME 6768.

MSE 6774.course_name: Biomaterials: Structure and Function.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6774.course_description: Structure-function relationships of biomaterials and biomaterial characterization will be covered. Materials for medical implants, tissue engineering, biosensing, imaging, and drug delivery will be covered. Crosslisted with BMED, CHE, and ME 6774.

MSE 6775.course_description: Oral and written presentation of modern polymer topics, with an emphasis on constructive and ethical critical thinking in a group setting.

MSE 6776.course_name: Integrated Low-cost Microelectronics Systems Packaging.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6776.course_description: Broad overview of system-level, cross-disciplinary microelectronics packaging technologies, including design, test, thermal, reliability, optoelectronics, and RF integration.  Comparison of system-to-chip and system-to-package. Crosslisted with ECE and ME 6776.

MSE 6777.course_description: Advanced topics of biomaterials performance and engineering, including biointerfaces, host reactions to materials, and bio-inspired/smart-materials strategies. Crosslisted with BMED, CHE, and ME 6777.

MSE 6795.course_name: Mathematical, Statistical, and Computational Techniques in Materials Science.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6795.course_description: Fundamental physical, analytical, and mathematical techniques encountered in materials engineering including stress and strain, crystallographic and orientation transformations, X-ray, TEM, and solid-state concepts are emphasized. Crosslisted with ME and PTFE 6795.

MSE 6796.course_name: Structure-Property Relationships in Materials.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6796.course_description: Introduction to the multi-scale structure effects on material properties.  Course will prepare students for future in-depth courses.  Crosslisted with PTFE and ME 6796.

MSE 6797.course_name: Thermodynamics and Kinetics of Microstructural Evolution.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 6797.course_description: The reduction of chemical-free, strain, and interfacial energies control of the kinetics of diffusional transformations. These factors are explored from the viewpoint of processing and stability of microstructure during service. Crosslisted with PTFE and ME 6797.

MSE 6XXX.course_name: Materials Science & Engineering Elective.  1-21 Credit Hours.

MSE 7010.course_description: Defects chemistry; electrochemical and electrophysical behavior of metallic/semiconducting ceramics, dielectrics, and ferrites; device applications of various electronic ceramics.

MSE 7110.course_name: Advanced Transmission Electron Microscopy.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 7110.course_description: Introduction to theory, techniques, and applications of high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) in materials research.

MSE 7140.course_name: Impedance and Dielectric Spectroscopy.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 7140.course_description: The basic theory of how current, voltage, and phase angle measurements over a wide frequency range (typically mHz-MHz) can provide information about microstructural features at all length scales.

MSE 7210.course_name: Dislocation and Deformation Mechanics.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 7210.course_description: Emphasis on interactions of dislocations with other defects, dislocation dynamics, and their correlation with mechanical properties under different rates of loading.

MSE 7420.course_description: Fundamentals of thermodynamics, kinetics, mass transport, and physical materials are applied to the development of microstructure during solidification.

MSE 7510.course_name: Polymers for Electronic and Photonic Applications II.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 7510.course_description: Review of fundamentals and principles of polymers used in electronics and photonics. The relationship between the recent advances of semiconductor technology and the importance of polymers will be discussed.

MSE 7757.course_description: Students will learn about what it takes to be a faculty through sills needed for “delivery of lecture” via the practice of teaching.

MSE 7771.course_name: Mechanics of Polymer Solids and Fluids.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 7771.course_description: Continuum mechanics of solids and fluids; mechanics of deformation of anisotropic polymers; yield, breaking and fatigue; non-Newtonian vioscous and viscoelastic behavior of polymer fluids. Crosslisted with CHE, ME and PTFE 7771.

MSE 7772.course_name: Fundamentals of Fracture Mechanics.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 7772.course_description: Advanced study of failure of structural materials under load, mechanics of fracture, and microscopic and macroscopic aspects of the fracture of engineering materials. Crosslisted with AE, CEE, CHE, and ME 7772.

MSE 7773.course_description: Nonlinear fracture mechanics including elastic-plastic and time-dependent fracture, advanced test methods, J-integral theory, and extensions. Crosslisted with AE, CEE, CHE, and ME 7773.

MSE 7774.course_name: Fatigue of Materials and Structures.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 7774.course_description: Mechanical and microstructural aspects of nucleation and growth of cracks under cyclic loading conditions, notch effects, cumulative damage, multiaxial loading, and fatigue crack propagation.  Crosslisted with AE, CEE, CHE, and ME 7774.

MSE 7775.course_name: Topics in Fracture and Fatigue of Metallic and Composite Structures.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 7775.course_description: Brittle and ductile failure criteria. Failure prediction in composite structures. Free-edge and internal delamination. Anisotropic cracks. Fatigue behavior of composites and comparison with metal fatigue. Crosslisted with AE, CHE, and ME 7775.

MSE 7791.course_name: Damage, Failure, and Durability of Composite Material.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 7791.course_description: Analysis and failure of fiber-reinforced composite material systems.  Mechanisms of toughening, multiple cracking mechanisms.  Failure in woven fabric, braided, and special geometry composites.  Crosslisted with AE, CHE, CEE, ME, and PTFE 7791.

MSE 7792.course_name: Advanced Mechanics of Composites.  3 Credit Hours.
MSE 7792.course_description: Anisotropic elasticity, hygrothermal behavior, stress analysis of laminated composites including 3-D effects, stress concentrations, free-edge effects, thick laminates, adhesive and mechanical connections, fracture of composites. Crosslisted with AE, CHE, CEE, ME, and PTFE 7792.

MSE 7793.course_description: Major manufacturing techniques for metal, ceramic, and polymer composites. Modeling of processes with emphasis on fundamental mechanisms and effects.  Crosslisted with AE, CHE, CEE, ME, and PTFE 7793.

MSE 8001.course_description: The latest advances in research and development will be presented by the enrolled students from articles in recent issues of recognized periodicals.

MSE 8200.course_description: Designing and explaining visuals; creating and delivering scientific electronic presentations; learning to speak and present to a variety of audiences.

MSE 8801.course_description: Special topic offerings of current interest not included in regular courses.

MSE 8802.course_description: Special topic offering of current interest not included in regular courses.

MSE 8803.course_description: Special topic offering of current interest not included in regular courses.

MSE 8901.course_description: Lectures, laboratory, and library work on special topics of current interest in materials suitable for a master's degree candidate.

MSE 8902.course_description: Lectures, laboratory, and library work on special topics of current interest in materials suitable for a master's degree candidate.

MSE 8903.course_description: Lectures, laboratory, and library work on special topics of current interest in materials suitable for a master's degree candidate.

MSE 8997.course_description: For graduate students holding teaching assistantships.

MSE 8998.course_description: For graduate students holding a research assistantship.

MSE 9999.course_description: For GT-PKU students during terms when they are not taking other GT courses.  Placeholder course.

BIOL 2100.course_name: Island Biogeography of New Zealand.  3 Credit Hours.
BIOL 2100.course_description: Introduction to theory of island biogeography focused on New Zealand's geological history and unique biota.

BIOL 6150.course_name: Genomics and Applied Bioinformatics.  3 Credit Hours.
BIOL 6150.course_description: Retrieval and analysis of biological sequence, gene expression, and proteomics data from public databases and other sources; applying standard bioinformatics tools to investigate biological questions.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6150 and BIOL 4150.

BIOL 6221.course_description: An introduction to the major biological processes in the ocean, including primary production, elemental cycling, food webs, and fisheries.

BIOL 6410.course_description: Advanced studies of microbial ecosystems, the specific roles of bacteria in maintaining ecological balance, and the evolution of the ecosystem in response to changing environments.

BIOL 6417.course_description: An overview of the ecological and evolutionary patterns, processes, and mechanisms affecting the organization, structure, and function of a broad variety of marine communities.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6417 and BIOL 4417.

BIOL 6418.course_description: Study of the physiology of growth and metabolic activities of microorganisms.

BIOL 6428.course_description: Students will examine the ecological factors that affect dynamics, regulation, and evolution of natural populations, emphasizing the connections with mathematical models, genetics, and ecology. Credit will not be awarded for both BIOL 6428 and BIOL 4428.

BIOL 6478.course_name: Methods in Molecular Biophysics.  3 Credit Hours.
BIOL 6478.course_description: An introduction to biophysical methods that are employed to study biological macromolecules and their interaction to gain understanding of how they function.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6478 and BIOL 4478.

BIOL 6505.course_name: Programming in Biological and Health Sciences.  3 Credit Hours.
BIOL 6505.course_description: This course introduces students to the basics of coding, applied to fundamental biological and medical questions.

BIOL 6570.course_description: A survey of modern immunology and its applications, with emphasis on immunological methods used in molecular and cell biological research.

BIOL 6600.course_description: An introduction to evolutionary patterns and processes, including the history of life, phylogenetics, population genetics, quantitative genetics, molecular evolution, and other important topics in evolutionary biology.

BIOL 6607.course_name: Molecular Biology of Microbes: Disease, Nature, and Biotechnology.  3 Credit Hours.
BIOL 6607.course_description: Molecular genetics of bacteria with an emphasis on experimental approaches, regulatory mechanisms in disease-causing and environmental bacteria, and biotechnology applications derived from microbes. Credit will not be awarded for both BIOL 6607 and BIOL 4607, BIOL 4608, or BIOL 6608.

BIOL 6611.course_description: Advanced studies of selected aspects of the physiololgy of prokaryotic and eukaryotic microorganisms.

BIOL 6620.course_description: The course focuses on understanding the chemical mechanisms of aquatic signaling and the cascading effects on population regulation, community organization, and ecosystem function.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6620 and BIOL 4620.

BIOL 6720.course_description: To introduce advanced concepts and principles of contemporary environmental microbiological research and assosciated bioinformatics techniques through representative examples from recent literature.

BIOL 6750.course_name: Foundations of Quantitative Biosciences.  4 Credit Hours.
BIOL 6750.course_description: Introduction to quantitative methods and logic that enable key advances in understanding living systems, spanning molecules, cells, organisms, and biomes.

BIOL 6756.course_name: Discovery of Signaling Molecules.  3 Credit Hours.
BIOL 6756.course_description: The diversity of chemical signals between organisms and their structural specificities will be presented along with chemical and biological methods for isolating signaling molecules.  Crosslisted with CEE 6756 and CHEM 6756.

BIOL 6765.course_description: Interactions between microorganisms and the geosphere, microbial energetics and genetics; geochemical controls on microbial diversity and activity.  Crosslisted with EAS 6765.

BIOL 7001.course_name: Foundations in Molecular and Cell Biology.  4 Credit Hours.
BIOL 7001.course_description: The goal of this course is to provide new students with fundamental knowledge in the general areas of prokaryotic and eukaryotic molecular biology, biochemistry, structural biology, and bioinformatics.

BIOL 7010.course_description: Current topics in eukarytotic cell biology including membrane functions, intracellular sorting and compartmentalization, cell signaling, cell cycle, cytoskeleton, cell adhesion, motility, and current experimental approaches.

BIOL 7015.course_name: Cancer Biology and Technology.  3 Credit Hours.
BIOL 7015.course_description: This course covers the major concepts of cancer biology as well as to state-of-the-art technologies that are being applied to cancer research, detection and treatment.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL 7015 and BIOL 4015.

BIOL 7111.course_description: Evolutionary processes at the molecular level, organizations of genomes and genetic systems. Students will read and present up-to-date research articles in various topics in molecular evolution.

BIOL 7200.course_description: This active-learning, project-based course provides a rigorous introduction to scientific computing for bioinformatics, including Linux utilities, shell scripting and bioinformatics programming.

BIOL 7210.course_description: In this active learning class, students will learn to convert sequence information into knowledge through the use of computational genomics tools, applications and databases.

BIOL 7914.course_description: Topics of current interest in the physiology and ecology of bacteria and applications to practical problems.

BIOL 7923.course_description: Topics of current interest in the general areas of population growth and limitation, and the structure and stability of ecosystems.

BIOL 7924.course_name: Advances in Environmental Biology.  2 Credit Hours.
BIOL 7924.course_description: Topics of current interest in environmental biology.

BIOL 7963.course_name: Advances in Molecular Biology.  2 Credit Hours.
BIOL 7963.course_description: Topics of current interest in molecular biology.

BIOL 7964.course_description: Topics of current interest in genetics.

BIOL 8002.course_description: Weekly seminars on current research presented by various scientists in the field of biology.

BIOL 8003.course_description: Weekly seminars on current research presented by various scientists in the field of biology.

BIOL 8050.course_name: Professional development in quantitative biosciences.  1 Credit Hour.
BIOL 8050.course_description: Enhance the professional development of Quantitative Biosciences PhD students in preparing and submitting fellowships and in organizing scientific workshops and events.

BIOL 8060.course_name: Seminar in Quantitative Biosciences.  1 Credit Hour.
BIOL 8060.course_description: This course will introduce QBioS to QBioS Program Faculty, allowing them to learn about QBioS faculty members’ research and academic history.

BIOL 8061.course_name: Current Research in the Quantitative Biosciences.  1 Credit Hour.
BIOL 8061.course_description: The overall objective of the course is to enable QBioS PhD students to attend seminars on advances across all areas of the life sciences, including those by 4th year QBioS students.

BIOL 8106.course_name: Tools of Science Seminar.  2 Credit Hours.
BIOL 8106.course_description: This course addresses issues important to all successful scientists and engineers such as: research ethics; collaborations between industry, academics, and government; women and minorities in science; balancing research, teaching and service; writing, editing, and reviewing, presentations; job interviews; time management; speaking to the public and media; and scientific and university politics.

BIOL 8510.course_name: Epigenetics,  Stem Cells, and Development.  3 Credit Hours.
BIOL 8510.course_description: This course will introduce the basic concepts and mechanisms in epigenetics, covering topics ranging from stem cell reprogramming, organismal development, social behaviors, to human diseases.

BIOL 8515.course_description: An advanced ecology course that covers classic and contemporary concepts, patterns, and processes in the field of community ecology.

BIOL 8530.course_description: An advanced course where students will discuss primary literature and use computational tools to investigate how evolution has shaped global patterns of human genetic variation.

BIOL 8550.course_name: Origin of complex life: from cells to societies.  3 Credit Hours.
BIOL 8550.course_description: This course examines the evolutionary origins of complex life. We will examine the history of life on Earth and evolutionary process through which complexity arises.

BIOL 8560.course_name: RNA Biology and Bitechnology.  3 Credit Hours.
BIOL 8560.course_description: The purpose of this course is to introduce students (graduate and upper level undergraduate) to the fundamental concepts of RNA biology and to state-of-the-art biotechnologies that use RNA for medical and industrial applications.

BIOL 8744.course_description: This course explores how symbiotic interactions with microbes affect the biology of other organisms, focusing extensively on the beneficial microbes native to the human body.

BIOL 8801.course_description: New graduate lecture courses in areas of current interest.

BIOL 8802.course_description: New graduate lecture courses in areas of current interest.

BIOL 8803.course_description: New graduate lecture courses in areas of current interest.

BIOL 8804.course_description: New graduate lecture courses in areas of current interest.

BIOL 8805.course_description: New graduate lecture courses in areas of current interest.

BIOL 8814.course_description: Special Topics in Biology (lecture + supervised lab).

BIOL 8901.course_description: Research problems in biology under the supervision of a faculty member.

BIOL 8902.course_description: Research problems in biology under the supervision of a faculty member.

BIOL 8997.course_description: For graduate students holding a teaching assistantship.

BIOL 8998.course_description: For graduate students holding research assistantships.

SOC 1101.course_description: A survey of the discipline of sociology. Topics will include sociological theory, methods and selected substantive area, including social structure and functions, analysis of social processes, the foundations of personality, and analysis of social organization.

IL 6450.course_description: This course provides an overview of optimization, statistical, and stochastic models and methods with special emphasis on application to logistics.

IL 6451.course_name: Demand and Yield Management.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6451.course_description: This course focuses on demand estimation and modeling and revenue management.

IL 6452.course_description: This course addresses issues, driving forces, and analytical approaches to aid in designing operating reverse logistics systems.

IL 6453.course_description: This course compares labor practices in Europe, North America, and Asia with special attention on the influences on logistics.

IL 6454.course_name: European Trade and Transport.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6454.course_description: This course provides an overview of legal, cultural, political, and infrastructure issues influencing logistics in Europe.

IL 6455.course_name: Finance for the Logistics Practitioner.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6455.course_description: This course provides an in-depth understanding of concepts of finance that relate to logistics, such as valuing logistics activities and measuring logistics performance.

IL 6456.course_name: Financial Decision Making for Logistics.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6456.course_description: This course provides a thorough understanding of the key elements of building a better logistics business case.

IL 6457.course_name: Trade and Transportation in the Americas.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6457.course_description: This course provides an overview of legal, cultural, political, and infrastructure issues influencing logistics practices in the Americas.

IL 6458.course_description: This course surveys the different types of warehouses and their functions, principles of operation, and strategic relationship to the supply chain.

IL 6459.course_name: International Trade and Transportation.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6459.course_description: This course discusses how international trade is financed, what instruments are used and how they work, how transactions are settled, and the role of documentation.

IL 6460.course_description: This course focuses on international freight management including consolidation, export packaging, customs, tracking, terminal operations, mode selection, and carrier selection.

IL 6461.course_name: Asian Trade and Transportation.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6461.course_description: This course provides an overview of legal, cultural, political, and infrastructure issues influencing logistics practices in Asia.

IL 6464.course_name: Supply Chain Management II: ERP Systems.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6464.course_description: This course provides a strategic view of Enterprise Resource Planning and its relationship to logistics functions.

IL 6465.course_name: Marketing Channels and Partnering.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6465.course_description: This course focuses on logistics and supply chain issues as they impact the global marketing strategies of companies.

IL 6466.course_name: Global Supply Chain Design and Measurement.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6466.course_description: This course focuses on concepts and models for designing and measuring a global supply chain, with special focus on the impact of e-commerce.

IL 6467.course_description: This course focuses on logistics planning, execution, and performance measurement in the transportation industry.

IL 6468.course_description: This course focuses on logistics issues within the manufacturing facility including inventory, throughput, lead-time batching, and managing variability.

IL 6472.course_name: Supply Chain Integration Lab III.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6472.course_description: This course integrates supply chain management techniques in the Americas, Asia, and Europe through case studies.

IL 6475.course_name: Cases in International Logistics I.  2 Credit Hours.
IL 6475.course_description: In this course, cases are used to integrate strategic, management, and operating issues in international logistics and supply chain design.

IL 6476.course_name: Cases in International Logistics II.  2 Credit Hours.
IL 6476.course_description: In this course, cases are used t integrate strategic, management, and operating issues in international logistics and supply chain design.

IL 6477.course_name: Cases in International Logistics III.  2 Credit Hours.
IL 6477.course_description: In this course, cases are used to integrate strategic, management, and operating issues in international logistics and supply chain design.

IL 6478.course_name: Cases in International Logistics IV.  2 Credit Hours.
IL 6478.course_description: In this course, cases are used to integrate strategic, management, and operating issues in international logistics and supply chain design.

IL 6480.course_name: Supply Chain Lab I.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6480.course_description: This course integrates supply chain management techniques in the region through readings, case studies, meetings and site visits.  Typically Supply Chain Lab I focuses on the US.  Credit not allowed for both IL 6480 and IL 6470.

IL 6481.course_name: Supply Chain Lab II.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6481.course_description: This course integrates supply chain management techniques in the region through readings, case studies, meetings and site visits.  Typically Supply Chain Lab II focuses on Europe.  Credit not allowed for both IL 6481 and IL 6471.

IL 6483.course_name: Supply Chain Lab IV.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6483.course_description: This course integrates supply chain management techniques in the region through readings, case studies, meetings and site visits.  Typically Supply Chain Lab IV focuses on Asia.  Credit not allowed for both IL 6483 and IL 6473.

IL 6484.course_name: Supply Chain Lab V.  1 Credit Hour.
IL 6484.course_description: This course integrates supply chain management techinques in the region through readings, case studies, meetings, and site visits.  Typically Supply Chain Lab V focuses on Mexico and NAFTA.  Credit not allowed for both IL 6484 and IL 6474.

IAC 2001.course_name: Global Religions and Community Engagement.  3 Credit Hours.
IAC 2001.course_description: This course prepares students for leadership in a multi-faith society through the study of global religions and active engagement with diverse religious communities of Atlanta.

IAC 2002.course_name: Science, Engineering, and Religion: An Interfaith Dialogue.  3 Credit Hours.
IAC 2002.course_description: This course gathers diverse students serious about faith to explore topics at the intersection of science, engineering, and religion.

MP 4750.course_description: Physics and image formation methods for conventional X-ray CT, nuclear medicine, and magnetic resonance and ultrasound imaging.

MP 6011.course_name: Seminar in Medical Physics I.  1 Credit Hour.
MP 6011.course_description: Weekly 1-hour seminar on topics related to medical physics.

MP 6012.course_name: Seminar in Medical Physics II.  1 Credit Hour.
MP 6012.course_description: Weekly 1-hour seminar on topics related to medical physics.

MP 6101.course_description: Radioisotope production, radiopharmacy, planar gamma cameras, SPECT systems, PET systems, medical internal radiation dose (MIRD) method, nuclear medicine facilities and regulations.

MP 6201.course_description: Clinical radiation oncology, phantom systems, radiation machines, photon beams, electron beams, brachythearpy, dose modeling and treatment planning.

MP 6203.course_name: Radiation Therapy Treatment Planning Laboratory.  1 Credit Hour.
MP 6203.course_description: Radiation therapy treatment planning course covering conventional radiation therapy treatment planning, monitor unit calculations, and advanced radiation treatment planning techniques.

MP 6204.course_description: Measurement and calculation of absorbed dose, dose distributions, treatment planning, photon teletherapy, electron teletherapy, brachytherapy, clinical linear accelerators, quality assurance.

MP 6300.course_description: A survey of the most clinically relevant anatomy as visualized by modern diagnostic imaging; plan radiographs, CT, MRI, and PET are emphasized.

MP 6401.course_description: Basics of medical health physics, Title 10, U.S. Code of Federal Regulations, Parts 19, 20 and 35, shielding for hospital radiation facilities.

MP 6402.course_description: Dosimetry of ionizing radiation: photons, neutrons, and charged particles; cavity theory; concept of exposure and absorbed dose; ion chambers and other types of integration dosimeters.

MP 6403.course_name: Applications of the Monte Carlo Method in Medical Physics.  3 Credit Hours.
MP 6403.course_description: Basic principles of the Monte Carlo method, Monte Carlo transport of photon and electron, various applications of the Monte Carlo method in medical physics.

MP 6405.course_name: Radiation Protection and Dosimetry.  3 Credit Hours.
MP 6405.course_description: Radiation dosimetry quantities, calculational and experimental methods for assessing the absorbed dose, effective dose assessment, committed effective dose assessment, radiation shielding methods.

MP 6406.course_description: Introduction to the calculation of radiation dose, dosimetry, and health physics.

MP 6407.course_name: Radiation Biology and Oncology.  3 Credit Hours.
MP 6407.course_description: Radiation lesions and repair, mechanisms of cell death, cell cycle effect, radiation sensitizers and protectors, tumor radiobiology, relative sensitivities of human tissues, and radiation carcinogenesis.

MP 6756.course_description: Characteristics of atomic and nuclear radiation, transition probabilities, radioactivity abd isotopes, cross sections, electromagnetic radiation, neutrons, and charges particle interaction with matter.  Crosslisted with NRE 6756 and HP 6756.

MP 6757.course_description: Introduction to the theory and application of radiation detectors, measurement methods, signal processing, and data analysis.  Crosslisted with HP 6757 and NRE 6757.

MP 6759.course_name: Radiation Shielding Principles and Analysis.  3 Credit Hours.
MP 6759.course_description: Principles of Radiation Shielding; Design of Shields; Computational Methods for Analysis of Shielding; Emphasis on Monte Carlo Simulation as a Shielding Tool.

ACCT 2101.course_description: A study of the underlying theory and application of financial accounting concepts. These concepts include measurement principles, financial statement preparation, and introductory financial analysis.

ACCT 2102.course_name: Accounting II: Managerial Accounting.  3 Credit Hours.
ACCT 2102.course_description: A study of the underlying theory and application of managerial accounting concepts. These concepts include cost measurement, decision making, budgeting, and variance analysis.

AS 1000.course_description: Air Force customs and courtesies, drill and ceremonies, and introduction to the military environment. Emphasis on developing the leadership and interpersonal skills needed of Air Force officers.

AS 1110.course_name: Heritage and Values of the Air Force I.  1 Credit Hour.
AS 1110.course_description: A survey course designed to introduce students to the Department of the Air Force (DAF) and provides an overview of the basic characteristics, missions, communications and organization of the Air and Space Forces. Topics include: Formation of the Air Force, Military Customs and Courtesies, and Introduction to Leadership. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

AS 1120.course_name: Heritage and Values of the Air Force II.  1 Credit Hour.
AS 1120.course_description: A survey course designed to introduce students to the Department of the Air Force (DAF) and provides an overview of the basic characteristics, missions, communications and organization of the Air and Space Forces. Topics include: What is War?, Principles of War and Tenets of Airpower, and What the Department of the Air Force Brings to the Fight. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

AS 2210.course_name: U.S. Air and Space Power Fundamentals I.  1 Credit Hour.
AS 2210.course_description: This course provides a fundamental understanding of both leadership and team building. The lessons and course flow are designed to prepare students for field training and leadership positions in the detachment. Topics include: Listening, Full-Range Leadership, and Standards and Accountability. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

AS 2220.course_name: U.S. Air and Space Power Fundamentals II.  1 Credit Hour.
AS 2220.course_description: This course provides a fundamental understanding of both leadership and team building. The lessons and course flow are designed to prepare students for field training and leadership positions in the detachment. Topics include: Human Relations, Conflict Management, and Stress Management and Resiliency. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

AS 3310.course_name: Leading People and Effective Communication I.  3 Credit Hours.
AS 3310.course_description: This course utilizes student’s field training experience to take a more in-depth look at leadership. Special emphasis is placed on enhancing communication skills, and why that is important as a leader. Students have an opportunity to try out these leadership and management techniques in a supervised environment as juniors and seniors. Topics include: Change Management, Leading Diverse Organizations, and Managing Competing Priorities. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

AS 3320.course_name: Leading People and Effective Communication II.  3 Credit Hours.
AS 3320.course_description: This course utilizes student’s field training experience to take a more in-depth look at leadership. Special emphasis is placed on enhancing communication skills, and why that is important as a leader. Students have an opportunity to try out these leadership and management techniques in a supervised environment as juniors and seniors. Topics include: Mentoring, Ethical Decision Making, and Establishing Expectations. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

AS 4410.course_name: National Security and Preparation for Active Duty I.  3 Credit Hours.
AS 4410.course_description: This course is designed for college seniors and provides them the foundation to understand their role as military officers and how they are directly tied to our National Security Strategy. It is an overview of the complex social and political issues facing the military profession and requires a measure of sophistication commensurate with the senior college level. Topics include: National Security Strategy, The Total Force, and Capabilities and Force Packaging. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

AS 4420.course_name: National Security and Preparation for Active Duty II.  3 Credit Hours.
AS 4420.course_description: This course is designed for college seniors and provides them the foundation to understand their role as military officers and how they are directly tied to our National Security Strategy. It is an overview of the complex social and political issues facing the military profession and requires a measure of sophistication commensurate with the senior college level. Topics include: Leadership Authority and Responsibility, Military Justice, and Airmen Comprehensive Assessment. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

RUSS 1001.course_description: An introduction to Russian language and culture. First half of a survey of basic Russian grammar and the development of the four language skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing.  The course includes an orientation to aspects of everyday life in Russia.  Humanities credit awarded upon successful completion of RUSS 1002 or RUSS 2001.

RUSS 1002.course_description: Second half of an introduction to Russian language and culture. Second half of a survey of basic Russian grammar and the development of the four basic language skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing.  The course includes an orientation to aspects of everyday life in Russia.  Credit not allowed for both RUSS 1002 and RUSS 1692.

RUSS 10X1.course_name: Trans Elementary Russian I.  3 Credit Hours.

RUSS 10X2.course_name: Trans Elementary Russian II.  3 Credit Hours.

RUSS 1250.course_name: Vampires and Memory of Stalinism in Post-Soviet Russia.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 1250.course_description: Gothic aesthetics in post-Soviet Russian and U.S. vampire fiction and films.  Post-Soviet fiction and movies as a source for studying historical memory.  Conducted in English.

RUSS 1692.course_name: Intensive Elementary Russian II.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 1692.course_description: Continues introduction to fundamental Russian grammar and development of four modalities -- speaking, reading, listening, and writing -- in intensive immersion environment in Russia.  Credit not allowed for both RUSS 1692 and RUSS 1002.

RUSS 1811.course_description: Topics of current interest in Russian.

RUSS 1813.course_description: Topics of current interest in Russian.

RUSS 2001.course_description: A review and extension of basic grammar with intensive vocabulary-building and focus on development of idiom on the basis of conversation, reading, and writing activities. Includes reading and discussion of stories and magazine articles of general cultural interest with follow-up composition assignments.  Credit not allowed for both RUSS 2001 and RUSS 2691.

RUSS 2002.course_description: A review and extension of basic grammar with intensive vocabulary-building and focus on development of idiom on the basics of conversation, reading, and writing activities. Includes reading and discussion of stories and magazine articles of general cultural interest with follow-up composition assignments.  Credit not allowed for both RUSS 2002 and RUSS 2692.

RUSS 2691.course_name: Intensive Intermediate Russian I.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 2691.course_description: Review and extension of basic grammar, intensive vocabulary- building, and development of idiom on the basis of conversation, reading, and writing activities (in Russia). Credit not allowed for both RUSS 2691 and RUSS 2001.

RUSS 2692.course_name: Intensive Intermediate Russian II.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 2692.course_description: Review and extension of basic grammar, intensive vocabulary- building, and development of idiom on the basis of conversation, reading, and writing activities (in Russia).  Credit not allowed for both RUSS 2692 and RUSS 2002.

RUSS 2694.course_description: Modern Language Undergraduate Internship for pay for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Modern Language.

RUSS 2695.course_description: Modern Language Undergraduate Internship for credit for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Modern Languages.

RUSS 2811.course_description: Topics of current interest in Russian.

RUSS 2813.course_description: Topics of current interest in Russian.

RUSS 2821.course_description: Topics of current interest in Russian.

RUSS 3001.course_description: First half of advanced courses in Russian conversation and composition. Discussion of controversial issues with the goal of self-expression in coherent paragraphs. Advanced grammar topics.

RUSS 3002.course_description: Second half of advanced courses in Russian conversation and composition. Discussion of controversial issues with the goal of self-expression in coherent paragraphs. Advanced grammar topics.

RUSS 3005.course_name: Russian for Heritage Speakers.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 3005.course_description: Russian-language communication skills for heritage speakers. Focus on grammar and orthography, stylistics of adult/professional communication. Reading, discussion and writing on contemporary topics. Taught in Russian. Credit will not be awarded for both RUSS 3005 and RUSS 3001.

RUSS 3222.course_name: The Russian Twentieth Century in Literature and Film.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 3222.course_description: Russian twentieth-century literature and film. Discussion of historical and cultural context, aesthetics, structure and meaning. Reading and discussion in English.

RUSS 3242.course_name: Urban Mythologies in Russian Literature.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 3242.course_description: Students analyze iconic texts that have been shaped by both Russian and non-Russian urban environments across generations. Conducted in English.

RUSS 3350.course_name: Russian and American Mass Cultures.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 3350.course_description: Trends, genres and youth movements existing in contemporary American and Russian mass culture area compared to distinguish important cultural differences and similarities. Conducted in English.

RUSS 3691.course_description: Intensive development of aural/oral communication skills, capitalizing on a rich linguistic environment. Review and expansion of grammar, practiced in context. Focus on description, narration and comparison.

RUSS 3692.course_name: Advanced Reading and Composition for Business, Science and Technology.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 3692.course_description: Advanced reading and writing skills. Study of syntax enables more sophisticated paragraph structure. Readings include newspaper texts on current affairs, business, science and technology.

RUSS 3695.course_description: General introduction to political, cultural, social, and historical background of Russian domestic and foreign politics.  Lectures in English.  Discussion section and research project in Russian.

RUSS 3698.course_name: Russia Yesterday and Today.  1 Credit Hour.
RUSS 3698.course_description: Lecture and discussion of a range of problems confronting Russian society today and the depth of their connection to Russia's historical heritage. Taught in English.

RUSS 3803.course_description: Permits a group of students and a professor to pursue areas of the Russian language not extensively treated in other courses in the department.

RUSS 3812.course_description: Topics of current interest in Russian.

RUSS 3833.course_description: Topics of current interest in Russian.

RUSS 4300.course_name: Imperial Imagination Through Literature and Film.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 4300.course_description: This course examines how Russian, Soviet, and post-Soviet culture constructed the representations of the parts of the former Russian/Soviet empire. Taught in Russian.

RUSS 4320.course_description: Trends and paradigms in Russian literature from Pushkin to Chekhov. Conducted in Russian.

RUSS 4335.course_name: Technology, Society, and Culture in the Soviet Union and Russia.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 4335.course_description: Problems of sustainability, ecology, medicine, industrial development, and technological progress as manifested in Soviet and Russian society and reflected in culture. Conducted in Russian.

RUSS 4340.course_name: Invention of Business Discourse in Russia (1990-).  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 4340.course_description: Origins of business discourse in post-Soviet Russia.  Transformations in meaning of words and related practices during process of acculturation.  Conducted in Russian.

RUSS 4360.course_name: Russian Culture through the Prism of Song.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 4360.course_description: Russian songs as object of study and focal points for broader exploration of key issues in Russian and Soviet culture and history.  Conducted in Russian.

RUSS 4500.course_name: Russian Intercultural Capstone Seminar.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 4500.course_description: Russia and the West: cultural models and political fault lines.  Historical debates that continue to divide and engage Russians.  Conducted in Russian.

RUSS 4692.course_name: Intensive Advanced Russian II.  3 Credit Hours.
RUSS 4692.course_description: Russian LBAT summer program. Reading on and discussion of contemporary Russian and global issues. Advanced grammar and syntax. Stylistics of written discourses. Taught in Russian.

RUSS 4693.course_description: Russian LBAT summer program. Reading on and discussion of contemporary Russian and global issues. Advanced grammar and syntax. Stylistics of written discourses. Taught in Russian.

RUSS 6360.course_description: Russian songs as object of study and focal points for broader exploration of key issues in Russian and Soviet culture and history. Conducted in Russian.

RUSS 6510.course_description: Students will serve as researchers, student aides and apprentice instructors for any 3/4000-level undergraduate course approved by their adviser and the course.

MLDR 6701.course_name: Foundational Topics in the Manufacturing of Forest Bioproducts.  3 Credit Hours.
MLDR 6701.course_description: The course provides comprehensive foundational knowledge of the industry enabling the student to understand the role of diverse manufacturing operations and to strategically plan improvements. Cross-listed with CHBE 6701, CHBE 6741, ME 6741, CHEM 6741, MSE 6741, CHBE 6742, ME 6742, CHEM 6742, and MSE 6742.

MLDR 6800.course_name: Manufacturing Leadership Capstone Project.  3 Credit Hours.
MLDR 6800.course_description: Teams work to complete a capstone project provided at the beginning of the semester. Successful completion requires integration of the business, leadership and manufacturing courses.

SWAH 1001.course_description: Students acquire reading and writing skills and the ability to communicate in basic situations. Taught in Swahili.

SWAH 1002.course_description: Students acquire reading and writing skills and the ability to communicate in basic situations. Continuation of SWAH 1001. Taught in Swahili.

SWAH 1501.course_description: For heritage students in the U.S. who have never studied Swahili formally, but who speak some Swahili.

SWAH 2001.course_description: Development of grammatical concepts, vocabulary, and conversational abilities. Readings, audio and video material on the culture. Taught in Swahili.

SWAH 2002.course_description: Continued development of grammatical concepts, vocabulary, and conversational abilities. Readings, audio and video material on the culture. Taught in Swahili.

SWAH 2501.course_description: The continuation of SWAH 1501 or for intermediate-level heritage students in the U.S. who can communicate some in Swahili, but cannot read or write it for academic purposes. Taught in Swahili.

SWAH 3001.course_description: Advanced grammar, listening, reading, writing, speaking, the language of contemporary Swahili society, politics and culture through task-based language teaching. Taught in Swahili.

SWAH 3002.course_description: Listening, reading, writing, speaking the language of contemporary Wolof society, politics and culture through task-based language teaching. Taught in Swahili.

SWAH 3420.course_description: This interdisciplinary course will use a variety of approaches to study significant aspects of contemporary Africa’s societies, cultures, and representations. Taught in English.

SWAH 3813.course_description: Topics of current interest in Swahili.

GTL 2000.course_description: Seminar discussing aspects of European cities. Part of the Georgia Tech Lorraine summer program.

GTL 6016.course_description: For students attending both GLT and INPT ENSEEIHT.
