AE 1355.course_name: Aerospace Systems Design Competition I.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 1355.course_description: Team-oriented aerospace systems design project directed by a faculty advisor.  Typically a national student competition in aircraft, rotorcraft, or spacecraft design. Technical role commensurate with freshman standing.

AE 1601.course_name: Introduction to Aerospace Engineering.  1 Credit Hour.
AE 1601.course_description: Overview of aerospace engineering. Common terminology, introduction to use of engineering models, professional and ethical standards and experience with team-based design of aerospace systems. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 1601 and AE 1350.

AE 1750.course_description: An introduction to the field of bioengineering, including the application of engineering principles and methods to problems in biology and medicine, the integration of engineering with biology, and the emerging industrial opportunities. Crosslisted with BMED, CHE, ECE, ME, and MSE 1750.

AE 2010.course_description: Thermodynamic and fluid properties. Conservation laws, Isentropic flow, shocks and expansions, introduction to flows with friction and heat transfer. Applications to aerospace devices. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 2010 and AE 3450.

AE 2010R.course_description: This recitation is an optional session in support of AE 2010. This course is designed to allow students the chance to apply their knowledge of concepts through problem solving and group discussions.

AE 2011.course_description: Flowfield concepts, fluid properties, conservation equations for flows, isentropic flow, shocks and expansions, introduction to flows with friction and heat transfer. Applications to aerospace devices.

AE 2011R.course_description: This recitation is an optional session in support of AE 2011. This course is designed to allow students the chance to apply their knowledge of concepts through problem solving and group discussions.

AE 2220.course_description: Motion of particles and mass center of bodies, kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies in plane motion, work-energy and impulse-momentum methods, 3-D dynamics of rigid bodies.

AE 2220R.course_description: This recitation is an optional session in support of AE 2220. This course is designed to allow students the chance to apply their knowledge of concepts through problem solving and group discussions.

AE 2221.course_description: Kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies in three-dimensional motion.

AE 2221R.course_description: This recitation is an optional session in support of AE 2221. This course is designed to allow students the chance to apply their knowledge of concepts through problem solving and group discussions.

AE 2355.course_name: Aerospace Systems Design Competition II.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 2355.course_description: Team-oriented aerospace systems design project directed by a faculty advisor. Typically a national student competition in aircraft, rotorcraft, or spacecraft design.  Technical role commensurate with sophomore standing.

AE 2610.course_name: Introduction to Experimental Methods in Aerospace.  1 Credit Hour.
AE 2610.course_description: Introduction to laboratory instrumentation and measurement techniques used in aerospace. Basic application of sensor principles, uncertainty analysis, interpretation and analysis of experimental data, and documentation.

AE 2611.course_name: Technical Communications for Aerospace Engineers.  1 Credit Hour.
AE 2611.course_description: Development of technical communication skills required by aerospace engineers. Includes written, oral and visual communication methods.

AE 2698.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

AE 2699.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

AE 2801.course_description: Normally taken by sophomores. Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

AE 2802.course_description: Normally taken by sophomores. Course material is devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

AE 2803.course_description: Normally taken by sophomores. Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

AE 2901.course_description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

AE 2902.course_description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

AE 2903.course_description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

AE 3030.course_description: Aerodynamics of airfoils and wings in subsonic, transonic and supersonic flight. Laminar and turbulent boundary layers and effects of viscosity on aerodynamic performance.

AE 3090.course_name: Numerical Methods for Aerospace Engineering.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 3090.course_description: Basic numerical methods in Aerospace Engineering taught in Fortran or C, language instruction included.  Numerical integration, interpolation, FFT, linear algebra, initial and boundary value problems.

AE 3140.course_description: Application to structural analysis. Basic equations of elasticity. Bending, shearing and torsion of thin walled structures. Energy methods for structural analysis and application to finite element theory for trusses and beam structures. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 3140 and AE 3125.

AE 3330.course_name: Introduction to Aerospace Vehicle Performance.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 3330.course_description: Orbital mechanics, orbit determination, and spacecraft maneuvers. Basics of airplane flight including climb, cruise, takeoff, and landing. Actuator disk theory and elements of rotorcraft performance.

AE 3340.course_name: Design and Systems Engineering Methods.  2 Credit Hours.
AE 3340.course_description: Overview of aerospace design and systems engineering. Tools to organize the design process and to support design decisions. Introduction to numerical optimization and trade studies.

AE 3355.course_name: Aerospace Systems Design Competition III.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 3355.course_description: Team-oriented aerospace systems design project directed by a faculty advisor. Typically a national student competition in aircraft, rotorcraft, or spacecraft design.  Technical or leadership role commensurate with junior standing.

AE 3450.course_name: Thermodynamics and Compressible Flow.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 3450.course_description: First and second laws of thermodynamics. Thermodynamic properties and state equations. Isentropic flow. Flows with shocks and expansions.  Flows with friction and heat transfer. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 3450 and AE 2010.

AE 3530.course_name: System Dynamics and Vibration.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 3530.course_description: Modeling and analysis of lumped- and distributed-parameter systems, free and forced vibration in mechanical systems, free vibration in structural systems. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 3530 and ME 3017 or AE 3530 and AE 3515.

AE 3531.course_name: Control System Analysis and Design.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 3531.course_description: Control system performance analysis and specifications, classical methods of control system analysis and design, introduction to modern control methods. Students cannot receive credit for AE 3531 and AE 3515 or AE 3531 and ME 4452.

AE 3610.course_name: Experiments in Fluid and Solid Mechanics.  2 Credit Hours.
AE 3610.course_description: Experimental laboratory in solid and fluid mechanics, aerodynamics, propulsion. Emphasis on measurement techniques, analysis and interpretation of data, comparison to analytical predictions, and reporting.

AE 3801.course_description: Normally taken by juniors. Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

AE 3802.course_description: Normally taken by juniors. Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

AE 3803.course_description: Normally taken by juniors. Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

AE 3901.course_description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

AE 3902.course_description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

AE 3903.course_description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

AE 4040.course_description: Discretization of PDEs, stability and accuracy considerations, iterative and time/space marching schemes, aerospace applications.

AE 4060.course_description: Concepts and techniques, noise sources, data acquisition and reduction, aeroacoustic resonances, commonalities in the music of wind instruments and sources of aircraft noise, community impact.

AE 4070.course_name: Introduction to Propeller and Rotor Theory.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4070.course_description: A study of the theory and equations used in the design of propellers and helicopter rotors.

AE 4071.course_description: Basic rotor aerodynamics and dynamics, helicopter performance and trim, introduction to helicopter stability, control and vibration.

AE 4080.course_description: Convective heat transfer and viscous drag in high- temperature and high-speed flowfields. Inviscid hypersonic theory, real gas effects, and wall thermal protection strategies.

AE 4132.course_description: An introduction to classical approximation techniques and the fundamentals of the finite element-method applied to structures and structural dynamics with aerospace applications.

AE 4170.course_name: Structural Integrity and Durability.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4170.course_description: Multiaxial stress states, inelasticity in metals and polymers, yield criteria, metal fatigue, fracture, stress intensity factors, fracture toughness, fatigue crack growth, metal creep, and polymer viscoelasticity.

AE 4220.course_name: Structural Dynamics and Aeroelasticity.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4220.course_description: Structural dynamics of one-dimensional systems. Analysis of static aeroelastic phenomena, unsteady aerodynamics, and flutter.  Equations of motion for complete aeroelastic systems; solution techniques.

AE 4311.course_name: Aircraft Design I: Conceptual Design.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4311.course_description: Conceptual design and synthesis of fixed wing aircraft.

AE 4312.course_name: Aircraft Design II: Preliminary Design.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4312.course_description: Preliminary design and synthesis of fixed wing aircraft.

AE 4321.course_name: Space System Design I: Conceptual Design.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4321.course_description: Conceptual design and synthesis of space systems. Students apply mission and spacecraft design principles.

AE 4322.course_name: Space System Design II: Mission Design.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4322.course_description: Advanced design applications of space systems. Students apply mission and spacecraft design principles.

AE 4331.course_name: Rotorcraft Design I: Conceptual Design.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4331.course_description: Conceptual design of traditional, urban air mobility, unmanned rotorcraft vehicles.

AE 4332.course_name: Rotorcraft Design II: Preliminary Design.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4332.course_description: Preliminary design of traditional, urban air mobility, unmanned rotorcraft vehicles.

AE 4341.course_description: Aircraft Vehicle Design. Preliminary design or case study of a complete flight vehicle, including a propulsion system, a structural system, and a control system. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 4341 and AE 4350.

AE 4342.course_description: Spacecraft subsystems and synthesis. Students apply mission and spacecraft design principles in developing a space flight mission concept. Topics may vary. Students cannot receive credit for AE 4342 and AE 4356.

AE 4343.course_description: Rotorcraft Vehicle Design. Preliminary design or case study of a complete rotorcraft flight vehicle, including a propulsion system, a structural system, and a control system. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 4343 and AE 4358 or AE 4343 and AE 6333.

AE 4355.course_name: Aerospace Systems Design Competition IV.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4355.course_description: Team-oriented aerospace systems design project directed by a faculty advisor.  Typically a national student competition in aircraft, rotorcraft, or spacecraft design. Technical or leadership role commensurate with senior standing.

AE 4361.course_description: This course introduces the foundations and analysis of space flight operations for human and robotic space missions.

AE 4370.course_name: Life Cycle Cost Analysis.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4370.course_description: Modeling of total cost of complex systems over their entire life cycle.  Modeling risk uncertainty for complex energy, environmental, and military systems.

AE 4376.course_name: Accident Causation and System Safety.  2 Credit Hours.
AE 4376.course_description: This course provides an in-depth examination of the multi-disciplinary issues in accident causation and system safety (prevention) across different industries.

AE 4451.course_name: Jet and Rocket Propulsion.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4451.course_description: Principles of aerospace propulsion systems. Thermodynamic cycles. Thermodynamics of combustion. Turbine engine and rocket performance characteristics. Cycle/component analysis of engines and turbomachinery.

AE 4453.course_description: Analysis, preliminary design of turbomachinery and combustors for aircraft; engine design, off-design performance. Introduction to advanced architectures: including scramjets, pressure gain combustion, electric propulsion.

AE 4461.course_description: Basics of combustion and combustion devices. Chemical thermodynamics, reaction rates, premixed/nonpremixed flames, ignition, stabilization, and pollutants.  Applications in turbine, rocket, and internal combustion engines.

AE 4531.course_description: Three-dimensional rigid body dynamics, aircraft equations of motion, static and dynamic stability, flight control design, introduction to aeroelastic phenomena. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 4531 and AE 3521.

AE 4532.course_description: Cover fundamental material in orbit and attitude dynamics. Investigate orbits, rendezvous/intercept maneuvers, interplanetary transfers, attitude coordinates, attitude stability, attitude control, and attitude estimation. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 4532 and AE 4310.

AE 4552.course_name: Introduction to Humans & Autonomy.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4552.course_description: Learn the fundamental principles underlying the functions performed by humans and by autonomous systems in dynamic, complex domains. Credit will not be awarded for both AE 4552 and AE 6552.

AE 4580.course_name: Introduction to Avionics Integration.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4580.course_description: Avionics in modern aerospace vehicle systems, including impact on design and performance. Specific case-studies; covers: navigation, GPS, stability augmentation, radar, health monitoring, databases, human factors, and software.

AE 4610.course_name: Dynamics and Control Laboratory.  2 Credit Hours.
AE 4610.course_description: Experiments in dynamics and control related to aerospace engineering topics.

AE 4698.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

AE 4699.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

AE 4701.course_description: An introductory course on wind energy and its potential; modeling and design of wind turbines; analysis of the economic benefits of wind turbine systems.  Credit not allowed for both AE 4701 and ME 4701.

AE 4757.course_description: Introduction to the study of blood flow in the cardiovascular system.  Emphasis on modeling and the potential of flow studies for clinical research application. Crosslisted with CHE and ME 4757.

AE 4758.course_description: The mechanics of living tissue, e.g., arteries, skin, heart muscle, ligament, tendon, cartilage, and bone.  Constitutive equations and some simple mechanical models. Mechanics of cells. Applications. Crosslisted with CHE and ME 4758.

AE 4760.course_name: Engineering Acoustics and Noise Control.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4760.course_description: Study of acoustics related to noise and its control; acoustics terminology wave propagation, wave equation solutions, instrumentation, data processing, room acoustics, noise control, noise legislation. Crosslisted with ME 4760.

AE 4791.course_name: Mechanical Behavior of Composites.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4791.course_description: Stress-strain behavior of composites, property of matrix and reinforcing materials, mechanics of fiber-reinforced composites, lamina and laminate analysis, and mechanical performance.  Crosslisted with CEE, CHE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 4791.

AE 4793.course_name: Composite Materials and Processes.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 4793.course_description: Basic principles of selection and design of composite materials and their manufacturing and testing. Cost factors. Laboratory exercises on manufacturing and tests. Crosslisted with CEE, CHE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 4793.

AE 4794.course_name: Composite Materials and Manufacturing Testing.  4 Credit Hours.
AE 4794.course_description: Basic principles of selection and sign of composite materials and their manufacturing and testing. Cost factors. Laboratory exercises on manufacturing and tests. Crosslisted with CEE, CHE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 4794.

AE 4801.course_description: Normally taken by seniors.  Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

AE 4802.course_description: Normally taken by seniors. Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

AE 4803.course_description: Normally taken by seniors.  Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

AE 4804.course_description: Normally taken by seniors.  Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

AE 4901.course_name: Special Problems in Aerospace Engineering.  1-21 Credit Hours.
AE 4901.course_description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

AE 4902.course_name: Special Problems in Aerospace Engineering.  1-21 Credit Hours.
AE 4902.course_description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

AE 4903.course_description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

AE 6009.course_description: Fundamental conservation laws.  Laminar flows, wall-bound and free shear flows. Separation, heat transfer, and compressibility effects. Introduction to flow instability and transition to turbulence.

AE 6012.course_description: Basic characteristics of turbulence.  Statistical methods. Reynolds averaging, kinetic energy budget, and scaling issues.  Homogeneity and isotrophy.  Free and wall bounded shear flows. Simulation and modeling.

AE 6015.course_description: Introduce concepts, derivation and application of aerodynamic fundamentals. Emphasis on advanced knowledge in analysis and design of fixed-wing, launch/atmospheric return vehicles, and rotating systems.

AE 6020.course_description: Transonic small disturbance theory. Transonic potential flow modeling. Supercritical airfoil design. Physics of hypersonic flow.  Newtonian flow. Modeling of hypersonic viscous and inviscid flow.

AE 6030.course_description: Unsteady potential theory for various speed ranges. Calculation of steady and unsteady aerodynamic loads on airfoils and wings.  Vortex flows. Topics of current research interest.

AE 6042.course_description: Finite-difference, finite volume methods for solution of Navier-Stokes and Euler equations. Classification of equations, stability, grids, boundary conditions, implicit and explicit methods, turbulence modeling.

AE 6050.course_name: High-temperature Gas Dynamics I.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6050.course_description: Defining equations for compressible flows, real gas properties and their effect on the behavior of equilibrium and non-equilibrium flows.

AE 6060.course_description: Lighthill's theory of aerodynamic noise and extensions, flow/acoustic interactions, feedback phenomenon, supersonic jet noise, aeroacoustics of ducts, propeller noise, helicopter noise, sonic boom.

AE 6070.course_description: Vortex wake modeling; analytical inflow theories; modern computational methods for rotary wing aerodynamic analysis; aerodynamic noise.

AE 6080.course_description: Fundamental physics of turbulent flows.  Vorticity dynamics, Kolmogorov similarity hypotheses and nonlinear interactions. Mixing and dispersion. Direct and large-eddy simulations, Reynolds stress modeling.  Advanced topics.

AE 6100.course_name: Advanced Structural Analysis I.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6100.course_description: Stability of elastic systems under quasi-static loads. Classical, kinetic, and potential energy approaches through rigid member models.  Buckling of elastic bars and frames. Energy methods.

AE 6106.course_name: Analysis of Aerospace Structural Elements.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6106.course_description: This course focuses on the analysis of advanced aerospace structures. Beam theory is reviewed, plate theory is introduced.  Classical and energy solutions are presented.

AE 6114.course_name: Fundamentals of Solid Mechanics.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6114.course_description: Unified overview of fundamental aspects of solid mechanics, from nonlinear continuum mechanics to linear elasticity, including an introduction to energy methods and other special topics.

AE 6115.course_name: Fundamentals of Aerospace Structural Analysis.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6115.course_description: Overview and fundamentals of aerospace structural analysis, including virtual work and energy methods, buckling and advanced structural theories.

AE 6170.course_description: Mathematical methods of constrained optimization, sensitivity analysis, approximation concepts, decomposition techniques, shape optimization in the context of structural design.

AE 6200.course_description: Understanding and analysis of aeroelastic phenomena in fixed-wing aircraft, static aeroelasticity, dynamic aeroelasticity, and dynamic response and transient stresses in aircraft structures.

AE 6210.course_description: Kinematics of particles and rigid bodies, angular velocity, inertia properties, holonomic and nonholonomic constraints, generalized forces.

AE 6211.course_description: A continuation of AE 6210.  Equations of motion, Newtonian frames, consistent linearization, energy and momentum integrals, collisions, mathematical representation of finite rotation.

AE 6220.course_name: Rotorcraft Structural Dynamics and Aeroelasticity.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6220.course_description: Elementary blade dynamics, flap-lag dynamics, ground resonance, structural dynamics of rotating beams, nonlinear elastic blade analysis, harmonic balance and trim, Floquet theory.

AE 6230.course_description: Dynamic response of single-degree-of-freedom systems, Lagrange's equations; modal decoupling; vibration of Euler-Bernoulli and Timoshenko beams, membranes and plates.

AE 6270.course_description: Nonlinear vibration methods through averaging and multiple scales, bifurcation, periodic and quasi-periodic systems, transition to chaos, characterization of chaotic vibrations, thermodynamics of chaos, chaos control.

AE 6310.course_name: Optimization for the Design of Engineered Systems.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6310.course_description: Introduction to optimization problem formulations for engineering design, algorithms for constrained nonlinear programming, multiobjective and multidisciplinary optimization, and robust design optimization.

AE 6333.course_description: System approach to conceptual design of aerospace systems with emphasis on rotorcraft. Comprehensive methodologies for aerospace vehicle synthesis and sizing. Integration of technologies. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 6333 and AE 4343.

AE 6334.course_description: Students work together on this application to complete the preliminary design stage of a specific rotorcraft. Participants are exposed to disciplinary and interdisciplinary issues.

AE 6343.course_description: Stochastic approach to conceptual design of aerospace systems with emphasis on aircraft and missiles. Comprehensive methodologies for aerospace vehicle synthesis and sizing. Integration of technologies.

AE 6344.course_description: Students work together on this application to complete the preliminary design stage of a specific aircraft or missile. Participants are exposed to disciplinary and interdisciplinary issues.

AE 6353.course_description: First graduate-level astrodynamics class that includes two-body orbital mechanics, orbit determination, orbit prediction, orbital maneuvers, lunar and interplanetary trajectories, orbital rendzvous and space navigation.

AE 6355.course_name: Planetary Entry, Descent and Landing.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6355.course_description: Entry flight mechanics and dynamics, aerothermodynamics, thermal protection systems, aerodynamic decelerators, descent and landing.  Robotic and human exploration mission studies for aerobraking, planetary entry, aerocapture.

AE 6356.course_name: Spacecraft Attitude Estimation and Control.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6356.course_description: Attitude representations, dynamics, estimation, and control. Spacecraft attitude sensors and actuators. Attitude determination and control topics applied to spacecraft and space missions.

AE 6361.course_name: Air Breathing Propulsion System Design I.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6361.course_description: Air breathing propulsion design with emphasis on multidisciplinary design issues related to system integration, cycle selection, performance, cost, reliability, maintainability, etc.

AE 6362.course_description: Autonomous situational flight model allows students to examine complex behaviors in the "pilot-vehicle-operational conditions" system.  Flight certification and airworthiness requirements are mapped into formal scenarios.

AE 6372.course_description: Introduction to aerospace systems engineering. Systems engineering and quality engineering methods and tools. Top-down design decision support processes, computer integrated environments, Integrated Product/Process Development (IPPD).

AE 6373.course_name: Advanced Design Methods I.  4 Credit Hours.
AE 6373.course_description: Introduction to modern probabilistic design methods and techniques. Design of experiments, Taguchi methods, response surface equations, robust design, risk and uncertainty, technology assessment and selection.

AE 6383.course_description: Introduction to computing tools and processes used in subsequent applied design courses in graduate fixed wing, rotary wing, and space systems design tracks.

AE 6393.course_name: Introduction to System of Systems Engineering Principles.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6393.course_description: Introduce students to the development and analysis of complex System of Systems, and their practical application to formulate Grand Challenge projects.

AE 6394.course_name: System of Systems Engineering Applications.  4 Credit Hours.
AE 6394.course_description: Application of developed System of Systems analysis frameworks for the performance of Grand Challenge projects.

AE 6410.course_description: Acoustic wave propagation in inhomogeneous flows, flame-acoustic wave interactions, and control of combustion-driven oscillations.

AE 6412.course_description: Fundamentals of interaction between flow turbulence and reactive scalars.  Theoretical, numerical, and experimental methods. Physics of premixed, non-premixed, and partially premixed turbulent combustion.

AE 6440.course_description: Analysis and design of gas turbine engine components including axial flow compressors, turbines, inlets, and nozzles.  Heat transfer and turbine blade cooling.

AE 6450.course_description: Analysis and design of rocket engines including liquid, solid, hybrid, and advanced propulsion systems.

AE 6451.course_description: The course provides a solid background of the operating principles, performance characteristics, and design features of the state-of-the-art electric propulsion systems.

AE 6503.course_name: Helicopter Stability and Control.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6503.course_description: Helicopter general equations of motion, rotor forces and moments, helicopter stability and control characteristics, handling qualities, flight control system design.

AE 6505.course_name: Random Processes and Kalman Filtering.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6505.course_description: Probability and random variables and processes; correlation; shaping filters; simulation of sensor errors; Wiener filter; random vectors; covariance propagation; recursive least-squares; Kalman filter; extensions.

AE 6506.course_name: Aerospace Guidance and Navigation.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6506.course_description: Earth's shape and gravity. Introduction to inertial navigation. GPS aiding. Error analysis. Guidance systems. Analysis of the guidance loop. Estimation of guidance variables. Adjoint analysis.

AE 6511.course_name: Optimal Guidance and Control.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6511.course_description: Euler-Lagrange formulation; Hamilton-Jacobi approach; Pontryagin's minimum principle; Systems with quadratic performance index; Second variation and neighboring extremals; Singular solutions; numerical solution techniques.

AE 6513.course_name: Mathematical Principles of Planning and Decision-Making for Autonomy.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6513.course_description:
The course will introduce the students to the mathematical tools and the theory 
for formulating and solving problems that involve high-level decision-making for controlling and planning of autonomous systems with an emphasis on aerospace applications.

AE 6520.course_description: Reference frames and transformations, general equations of unsteady motion, application to fixed-wing, rotary-wing and space vehicles, stability characteristics, flight in turbulent atmosphere.

AE 6530.course_name: Multivariable Linear Systems and Control.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6530.course_description: Techniques for analysis and description of multivariable linear systems. Tools for advanced feedback control design for these systems, including computational packages. Credit will not be awarded for both AE 6530 and ECE 6550 or AE 6530 and ME 6401.

AE 6531.course_name: Aerospace Robust Control I.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6531.course_description: Robustness issues in controller analysis and design. LQ analysis, H2 norm, LQR, LQG, uncertainty modeling, small gain theorem, H-infinity  performance, and the mixed-norm H2/H-infinity problem.

AE 6532.course_name: Aerospace Robust Control II.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6532.course_description: Advanced treatment of robustness issues. Controller analysis and design for linear and nonlinear systems with structured and non-structured uncertainty. Reduced-order control, stability, multipliers, and mixed-mu.

AE 6534.course_name: Control of Aerospace Structures.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6534.course_description: Advanced treatment of control of flexible structures. Topics include stability of multi-degree-of-freedom systems, passive and active absorbers and isolation, positive real models, and robust control for flexible structures.

AE 6551.course_description: Cognitive engineering addresses a range of technologies and work environments that will support human cognitive performance, including information systems, decision support, automation, and intelligent systems.

AE 6580.course_description: Advanced treatment of nonlinear robust control. Lyapunov stability theory, absolute stability, dissipativity, feedback linearization, Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman theory, nonlinear H-infinity, backstepping control, and control Lyapunov functions.

AE 6694.course_description: Graduate Internship for which the student is paid.

AE 6701.course_description: An introductory course on wind energy and its potential; modeling and design of wind turbines; analysis of the economic benefits of wind turbine systems. Credit will not be awarded for both AE 6701 and ME 6701.

AE 6705.course_description: Modeling and control of actuators and electro-mechanical systems. Performance and application of microprocessors and analog electronics to modern mechatronic systems.

AE 6721.course_name: Evaluation of Human Integrated Systems.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6721.course_description: Evaluation of human integrated systems including translating research questions into measurable objectives, overview of evaluation methods and data analysis techniques applicable to such systems.  Credit not allowed for both AE 6721 and ISYE 6231.

AE 6760.course_description: Fundamental principles governing the generation, propagation, reflection, and transmission of sound waves in fluids.  Crosslisted with ME 6760.

AE 6761.course_description: Radiation and scattering of sound waves in fluids, duct acoustics, dissipation phenomena. Crosslisted with ME 6761.

AE 6762.course_description: Mufflers, resonators, acoustic materials, barriers, industrial noise, room acoustics, active noise control. Crosslisted with ME  6762.

AE 6765.course_name: Kinetics and Thermodynamics of Gases.  4 Credit Hours.
AE 6765.course_description: Thermodynamics of nonreacting and reacting gas mixtures. Introductory quantum theory, statistical thermodynamics, and gas kinetic theory. Crosslisted with ME 6765.

AE 6766.course_description: Introductory chemical kinetics, detonations and deflagrations, laminar flame propagation in premixed gases, ignition and quenching, laminar diffusion flames and droplet burning, turbulent reacting flows. Crosslisted with ME 6766.

AE 6769.course_description: Governing equations of linear elasticity, plane elasticity, boundary value problems, airy stress function and complex variable methods, simple three-dimensional solutions. Crosslisted with ME 6769.

AE 6770.course_name: Energy and Variational Methods in Elasticity and Plasticity.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6770.course_description: Applications of energy and variational methods in engineering mechanics to elastic, plastic, and dynamical behavior of deformable bodies.  Crosslisted with ME 6770.

AE 6779.course_name: Dynamic System Simulation and Modeling.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 6779.course_description: Models of dynamic systems, such as aircraft, ground vehicles and machinery, and manual control.  Numerical simulation techniques and applications. Interactive simulators. Student programming project.  Crosslisted with ISYE 6779.

AE 7741.course_description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Program introduction. Technical resume preparation. GT Robotics labs & resources.

AE 7742.course_description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Selecting and applying for Internship. Developing capstone project proposal. Public speaking practice and preparation.

AE 7743.course_description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Interview preparation & career search. Technical report writing and presentation.

AE 7764.course_description: Propagation of sound in inhomogeneous fluids; ray acoustics, ocean and atmospheric acoustics, nonlinear acoustics. Crosslisted with ME 7764.

AE 7772.course_name: Fundamentals of Fracture Mechanics.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 7772.course_description: Advanced study of failure of structural materials under load, mechanics of fracture, and microscopic and macroscopic aspects of the fracture of engineering materials. Crosslisted with CHE, CEE, ME, and MSE 7772.

AE 7773.course_description: Nonlinear fracture mechanics including elastic-plastic and time-dependent fracture, advanced test methods, J-integral theory, and extensions. Crosslisted with CEE, CHE, ME, and MSE 7773.

AE 7774.course_name: Fatigue of Materials and Structures.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 7774.course_description: Mechanical and microstructural aspects of nucleation and growth of cracks under cyclic loading conditions, notch effects, cumulative damage, multiaxial loading, and fatigue crack propagation. Crosslisted with CEE, CHE, ME, and MSE 7774.

AE 7775.course_name: Topics in Fracture and Fatigue of Metallic and Composite Structures.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 7775.course_description: Brittle and ductile fracture criteria. Failrue prediction in composite structures. Free-edge and internal delamination. Anisotropic cracks. Fatigue behavior of composites and metal. New micromechanical models. Crosslisted with CHE, ME, and MSE 7775.

AE 7785.course_name: Introduction to Robotics Resesarch.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 7785.course_description: Familiarizes students with the core areas of robotics; mechanics, control, perception, AI, and autonomy. Provides an introduction to the mathematical tools required in robotics research.

AE 7791.course_name: Damage, Failure, and Durability of Composite Materials.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 7791.course_description: Analysis and failure of fiber-reinforced composite material systems.  Mechanisms of toughening, multiple cracking mechanisms.  Failure in woven fabric, braided, and special geometry composites.  Crosslisted with CHE, CEE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 7791.

AE 7792.course_name: Advanced Mechanics of Composites.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 7792.course_description: Anisotropic elasticity, hygrothermal behavior, stress analysis of laminated composites including 3D effects, stress concentrations, free-edge effects, thick laminates, adhesive and mechanical connections, fracture of composites. Crosslisted with CHE, CEE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 7792.

AE 7793.course_description: Major manufacturing techniques of metal-ceramic and polymer-matrix composites.  Modeling of processes with emphasis on fundamental mechanisms and effects. Crosslisted with CHE, CEE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 7793.

AE 8001.course_description: Case studies of existing aerospace systems; assessment of design payoffs and risks; industry experts provide case examples and knowledge transfer to course participants; field trips.

AE 8002.course_description: Introduce AE graduate students to world-class aerospace researchers and topics, discuss and demonstrate basic graduate student resources and skills.

AE 8740.course_description: Graduate Internship at a partner company, GTRI or a GT Robotics lab.

AE 8741.course_description: Teams or individuals apply the knowledge and skills acquired throughout the MS program to a faculty supervised robotics project.

AE 8750.course_name: Robotics Research Foundation I.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 8750.course_description: Multidisciplinary research course supervised by two robotics faculty from different schools participating in the robotics Ph.D. program.

AE 8751.course_name: Robotics Research Foundation II.  3 Credit Hours.
AE 8751.course_description: Continuation of AE 8751 (Robotics Research Foundation I).

AE 8997.course_description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantships.

AE 8998.course_description: For graduate students holding graduate research assistantships.

AE 8999.course_name: Preparation for Doctoral Dissertation.  1-21 Credit Hours.

CSE 6001.course_name: Introduction to Computational Science and Engineering.  1 Credit Hour.
CSE 6001.course_description: This course will introduce students to major research areas in computational science and engineering.

CSE 6010.course_name: Computational Problem Solving for Scientists and Engineers.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6010.course_description: Computing principles, computer architecture, algorithms and data structure; software development, parallelism. No credit for graduate students or undergraduates in Computer Science or Computational Media.

CSE 6040.course_name: Computing for Data Analysis: Methods and Tools.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6040.course_description: Computational techniques needed for data analysis; programming, accessing databases, multidimensional arrays, basic numerical computing, and visualization; hands-on applications and case studies. Credit is will not be awarded for both CSE 6040 and CX 4240.

CSE 6140.course_name: Computational Science and Engineering Algorithms.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6140.course_description: This course will introduce students to designing high-performance and scalable algorithms for computational science and engineering applications. The course focuses on algorithms design, complexity analysis, experimentation, and optimization, for important science and engineering applications.

CSE 6141.course_description: Algorithms and data structures for massive graphs; programming, parallelism; principles, challenges, opportunities in graph analysis; hands-on application, case studies.

CSE 6220.course_description: This course will introduce students to the design, analysis, and implementation of high performance computational science and engineering applications.

CSE 6221.course_name: Multicore Computing: Concurrency and Parallelism on the Desktop.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6221.course_description: This course will introduce students to the design and analysis of real-world algorithms on multicore computers.

CSE 6230.course_name: High Performance Parallel Computing: Tools and Applications.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6230.course_description: Introduction to MIMD parallel computation, using textbook excerpts, resesarch papers, and projects on multiple parallel machines. Emphasizes practical issues in high-performance computing.

CSE 6236.course_name: Parallel and Distributed Simulation.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6236.course_description: Algorithms and techniques used in parallel/distributed discrete event simulation systems. Synchronization algorithms, data distribution, applications to high performance analytic simulations and distributed virtual environments.

CSE 6240.course_name: Web Search and Text Mining.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6240.course_description: Basic and advanced methods for Web information retrieval and text mining: indexing and crawling, IR models, link and click data, social search, text classification and clustering.

CSE 6241.course_description: Foundations and algorithms underlying the development and application of tools for the efficient searching, matching and discovery of discrete.

CSE 6242.course_name: Data and Visual Analytics.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6242.course_description: The course introduces students to analysis and visualization of complex high dimensional data.  Both theory and applications will be covered including several practical case studies.

CSE 6243.course_name: Advanced Topics in Machine Learning.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6243.course_description: Advanced machine learning topics including graphical models, kernel methods, boosting, bagging, semi-supervised and active learning, and tensor approach to data analysis.

CSE 6250.course_name: Big Data Analytics for Healthcare.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6250.course_description: Big data systems, scalable machine learning algorithms, health analytic applications, electronic health records.

CSE 6301.course_name: Algorithms for Bioinformatics and Computational Biology.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6301.course_description: Foundations and algorithms underlying the development and application of tools for the efficient management and processing of biomolecular data.

CSE 6643.course_description: Introduction to numerical solutions of the classical problems of linear algebra including linear systems, least squares, singular value decomposition, and eigen value problems. Crosslisted with MATH 6643.

CSE 6644.course_name: Iterative Methods for Systems of Equations.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6644.course_description: Iterative methods for linear and nonlinear systems of equations including Jacobi, G-S, SOR, CG, multigrid, Newton, quasi-Newton, updating, and gradient based methods. Crosslisted with MATH 6644.

CSE 6710.course_name: Numerical Methods in Computational Science and Engineering I.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6710.course_description: Introduction to numerical algorithms widely used in computational science and engineering. Numerical linear algebra, linear programming, and applications. Crosslisted with MATH 6710.

CSE 6711.course_name: Numerical Methods in Computational Science and Engineering II.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6711.course_description: Efficient numerical techniques for solving partial differential equations and large-scale systems of equations arising from discretization of partial differential equations or variational problems in applications in science and engineering. Crosslisted with MATH 6711.

CSE 6730.course_name: Modeling and Simulation: Foundations and Implementation.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6730.course_description: Foundations and algorithms concerning the development of conceptual models for systems, and their realization in the form of computer software; discrete and continuous models. Crosslisted with ECE 6730.

CSE 6740.course_name: Computational Data Analysis: Learning, Mining, and Computation.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6740.course_description: Theoretical/computational foundations of analyzing large/complex modern datasets, including the fundamental concepts of machine learning and data mining needed for both resesarch and practice. Crosslisted with ISYE 6740. Credit not awarded for both CSE 6740 and CS 4641/7641/ISYE 6740.

CSE 6742.course_name: Modeling, Simulation and Military Gaming.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 6742.course_description: Focuses on the creation and use of modeling and simulation tools to analyze and train students regarding strategic events in international relations. Crosslisted with INTA 6742.

CSE 6748.course_description: Practical analytics project experience applying ideas from the classroom to a significant project of interest to a business, government agency, or other organization.

CSE 6XXX.course_name: Comput. Sci. & Engr Elective.  1-21 Credit Hours.

CSE 7750.course_name: Mathematical Foundations of Machine Learning.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 7750.course_description: Provides the mathematical background for two of the pillars of modern data science: linear algebra and applied probability.

CSE 7751.course_name: Probabilistic Graphical Models in Machine Learning.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 7751.course_description: The course provides an introduction to theory and practice of graphical models in machine learning. It covers three main aspects; representation, probabilistic inference, and learning.

CSE 7850.course_name: Machine learning in computational biology.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 7850.course_description: Introduction to modern machine learning techniques in computational biology.

CSE 7999.course_name: Preparation for Doctoral Qualifying Examination.  1-21 Credit Hours.

CSE 7XXX.course_name: Comput. Sci. & Engr Elective.  1-21 Credit Hours.

CSE 8001.course_name: Computational Science and Engineering Seminar.  1 Credit Hour.
CSE 8001.course_description: Group discussion concerning advanced topics in Computational Science and Engineering.

CSE 8002.course_name: Computational Science and Engineering Seminar.  2 Credit Hours.
CSE 8002.course_description: Group discussion concerning advanced topics in Computational Science and Engineering.

CSE 8003.course_name: Computational Science and Engineering Seminar.  3 Credit Hours.
CSE 8003.course_description: Group discussion concerning advanced topics in Computational Science and Engineering.

CSE 8004.course_name: Computational Science and Engineering Seminar.  4 Credit Hours.
CSE 8004.course_description: Group discussion concerning advanced topics in Computational Science and Engineering.

CSE 8005.course_name: Computational Science and Engineering Seminar.  5 Credit Hours.
CSE 8005.course_description: Group discussion concerning advanced topics in Computational Science and Engineering.

CSE 8801.course_description: Topics of current interest in Computational Science and Engineering.

CSE 8802.course_description: Topics of current interest in Computational Science and Engineering.

CSE 8803.course_description: Topics of current interest in Computational Science and Engineering.

CSE 8804.course_description: Topics of current interest in Computational Science and Engineering.

CSE 8805.course_description: Topics of current interest in Computational Science and Engineering.

CSE 8901.course_description: Small-group or individual investigation of advanced topics with a faculty member.

CSE 8902.course_description: Small-group or individual investigation of advanced topics with a faculty member.

CSE 8903.course_description: Small-group or individual investigation of advanced topics with a faculty member.

CSE 8997.course_description: For students holding graduate teaching assistantships.

CSE 8998.course_description: For students holding graduate research assistantships.

CSE 8XXX.course_name: Comput. Sci & Engr Elective.  1-21 Credit Hours.

BC 2610.course_description: An introduction to the planning and physical development process for the construction of projects of residential and light construction scale.

BC 2620.course_description: A continuation of Construction Technology I with an emphasis on large- scale and high-rise building, i.e., commercial building construction.

BC 2631.course_name: Introduction to Construction Management.  2 Credit Hours.
BC 2631.course_description: Provides an introduction to the construction industry with emphasis on exploring career opportunities in construction.

BC 2632.course_name: Construction Materials and Methods.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 2632.course_description: The course will cover the planning and physical development process for the construction of residential, commercial and heavy/industrial projects.

BC 2634.course_name: Construction Plans and Estimates.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 2634.course_description: Course focuses on reading and accessing project drawing information, and estimating quantities for pricing of materials, labor, subcontracts and equipment.

BC 2636.course_description: This course introduces the core elements of an effective safety and health management system in a construction project, and describes the application of OSHA standards.

BC 2698.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BC 2699.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BC 3600.course_description: Introduction to cost principles and cost analysis of construction projects, including classification of work, quantity survey techniques, construction operation costs, and bid proposals.

BC 3610.course_description: Legal aspects of construction contracts, bonds, insurance, and bidding. Owner, architect, contractor, and subcontractor relationships.

BC 3620.course_name: Real Estate and Construction Finance and Accounting.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 3620.course_description: General introduction to the financing of construction and real estate development projects. Emphasis on financing requirements, activities, sources, and uses.

BC 3630.course_description: This course will offer construction planning and management techniques for project design and construction with a focus on different scheduling methods and their use.

BC 3640.course_description: An introductory course to the evaluation of behavior of buildings, the properties of structural materials, and the behavior of load-resisting members.

BC 4010.course_name: History of Construction Industry.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 4010.course_description: Addresses how today's construction industry is organized and its particular characteristics, how it evolved from early times and where it may be heading in the future.

BC 4050.course_name: Building Information Modeling for Multi-disciplinary Integration.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 4050.course_description: This course introduces students to BIM and the changes it has been causing to the traditional design, planning, management, construction, facility management, and contracting practices.

BC 4110.course_name: Trends & Pol For Res Dev.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 4110.course_description: An overview of development in the United States, current trends in residential development, and the impact of external factors on residential development.  This course is designed to help Building Construction students understand how their development impacts the social environment and quality of life of the community.

BC 4120.course_description: An overview of the principles of smart growth, livable communities and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

BC 4130.course_name: Intg Design Constr & Dev.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 4130.course_description: A study of contemporary examples of an integrated approach to design, construction and development.  Course involves real-world project analysis from multiple points of view.

BC 4140.course_description: This class is the application of course materials covered throughout the Certificate in Construction Management to an actual construction project with a simulated business construct.

BC 4270.course_name: Sustainable Community Design and Construction.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 4270.course_description: An overview of the principles of smart growth, livable communities, and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

BC 4600.course_description: This course covers practical project management, technology, and tools for this approach and the  required management skills for successful execution of projects.

BC 4610.course_name: Value Engineering and Building Economics.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 4610.course_description: First part is an introduction to principles and methodology.  Second part is an introduction to economic principles and theories and how to apply the concepts and methods of building economics.

BC 4620.course_description: Emphasis being placed on the practical design and construction of structural elements.  The course includes basic design principles with a heavy emphasis on constructability and buildability.

BC 4630.course_description: A senior construction project that  includes redevelopment analysis and feasibility study, project development, and construction.

BC 4640.course_description: Methods of construction marketing and business development. Innovative computer applications, verbal skills development, professional strategies, market segmentation, and buyer behavior.

BC 4650.course_name: Laboratory for Sustainable Design and Construction.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 4650.course_description: The goal of the laboratory is to teach students a comprehensive sustainable design and construction information system and a program of real-world, hands-on projects.

BC 4660.course_description: Basics of construction business risk assessment, looking for construction opportunities, capital investment, computerized construction business, and business failures.

BC 4672.course_name: Mechanical, Electrical and Plumbing Systems for Construction Managers.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 4672.course_description: This course covers the fundamentals of mechanical, electrical, and plumbing contracting, including terminology, components, and basic design features of HVAC systems; plumbing systems; and electrical circuits and service equipment. It also encompasses the presentation of current mechanical, electrical, and plumbing drawings, specifications, and building codes.

BC 4680.course_description: Students work for a professional architecture/engineering/ construction company in which they learn, first-hand, about the construction industry.

BC 4698.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BC 4699.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BC 4700.course_description: An accelerated-pace course designed to provide a basic understanding of fundamental topics including planning, budgeting, estimation, scheduling, and project close out.

BC 4710.course_description: This course focuses on the means, methods, strategies, and technologies to improve the energy efficiency and performance of buildings, and to reduce the environmental impact of buildings.

BC 4720.course_name: Residential Construction and Property Management.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 4720.course_description: A course designed to orient students to the basics of apartment management and includes the business functions of marketing, leasing, and financing.

BC 4730.course_name: Best Practices in Multi-Family Property.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 4730.course_description: A course designed to provide students with a broad range of the best practices related to the management of all types of multi-family residential property.

BC 4735.course_name: Real Estate Development and Construction.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 4735.course_description: Provides an overview of the real estate development process as it pertains to construction development including trends and current issues.

BC 4843.course_description: Topics of current interest in building construction.

BC 6002.course_name: Issues in Sustainable Construction Technology.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6002.course_description: Course designed to help students achieve a basic understanding of the materials used in the commercial segments in the construction industry and how these relate to sustainable construction.

BC 6004.course_name: Sustainable Energy in Architecture, Engineering and Construction.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6004.course_description: An introductory course on sustainale energy in architecture, engineering and construction.  The goal of the course is to introduce students to fundamental concepts of sustainable sources of energy to power buildings and address the impact of these sources to applicable green building rating systems.

BC 6005.course_name: Technology Applications in the Construction Industry.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6005.course_description: Hands-on exploration of various present and Future technologies that can be applied in all stages of a facilities' lifecycle.

BC 6006.course_description: Cost management and control from early project inception to completion and applications throughout the life of a facility.

BC 6010.course_name: History of Construction Industry.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6010.course_description: Addresses how today's construction industry is organized and its particular characteristics, how it evolved from early times and where it may be heading in the future.

BC 6025.course_description: An accelerated paced course providing graduate students a basic understanding of fundamental topics including planning, budgeting, estimating, scheduling and project closeout.

BC 6050.course_name: Building Information Modeling for Multi-disciplinary Integration.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6050.course_description: This course introduces students to BIM and the changes it has been causing to the traditional design, planning, management, construction, facility management, and contracting practices. Credit will not be awarded for both BC 4050 and BC 6050.

BC 6100.course_name: Professional Trends in Facility Management.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6100.course_description: An introductory course covering the organizational, managerial, ethical, and legal principles for the delivery of facility management services.  Includes contracts and risk management.

BC 6125.course_description: A course in which students work for a professional architecture/engineering/construction company in which they learn, first-hand, about the construction industry.

BC 6150.course_name: Design-Build Organization and Management.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6150.course_description: Introduction to Design-Build (DB) as a project delivery system.  Provides information about the organization, the process, and the effects of DB on the industry.

BC 6175.course_name: Real Estate Development and Construction.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6175.course_description: Provides an overview of the real estate development process as it pertains to construction development including trends and current issues.

BC 6185.course_name: Introduction to Construction Program Management.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6185.course_description: Survey of the construction program management profession, focusing on the comprehensive management of single and multiple building programs including pre-design, design, construction and post-construction activities.

BC 6200.course_name: Maintenance Management of Built Assets.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6200.course_description: This course covers the processes by which a facility and its systems are serviced and maintained during the facility's life cycle.  Includes acquisition, installation, operation, maintenance, and disposal of built assets.

BC 6250.course_name: Value Management for Integrated Facility Design and Construction.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6250.course_description: Principles and methodology of value management analysis concepts and an examination of future values and worth criteria affecting building design, construction, furnishings, and operations performance.

BC 6270.course_name: Community Design and Development.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6270.course_description: An overview of the principles of smart growth, livable communities and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

BC 6275.course_description: An overview of the principles of smart growth, livable communities and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

BC 6285.course_name: Management of Pre-design Phase as Owner.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6285.course_description: Examination of the Program Manager's role and responsibilities as owner during the pre-design phase including feasibility, organization, financing, legal, entitlement, planning, budgeting, scheduling, and team selection.

BC 6300.course_name: Safety and Environmental Issues.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6300.course_description: This course covers the environmental issues related to the performance of buildings and the health and risk factors for new and existing buildings.

BC 6350.course_name: Design and Construction Law.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6350.course_description: Overview of construction law and legal issues encountered by the construction manager including U.S. laws, general concepts and definitions, contractor relationships, and relevant case studies.

BC 6370.course_name: Real Estate Policy, Trends, Ethics.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6370.course_description: The application of market, community, and policy factors to create new development while professionally managing potential conflicts between these factors.

BC 6375.course_name: Trends & Pol For Res Dev.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6375.course_description: An overview of development in the United States, current trends in residential development, and the impact of governmental regulations on residential development. This course is designed to help Building Construction students understand how their development impacts the social environment and quality of life of the community.

BC 6385.course_name: Management of Design Phase as Owner.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6385.course_description: Examination of the Program Manager's role and responsibilities as Owner during the design phase.

BC 6400.course_name: Facility Planning, Project Management, and Benchmarking.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6400.course_description: This course introduces the techniques of planning project management, benchmarking, and their applications to facility management.  Includes space forecasting, scheduling and control of projects, and benchmarking studies.

BC 6475.course_name: Real Estate Development Law.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6475.course_description: Comprehensive overview of legal, property, and entitlement issues associated with the real estate development process.

BC 6485.course_name: Management of Preconstruction Phase as Owner.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6485.course_description: This course covers the management and oversight activities of the owner and program manager conducted during the pre-design and design phases of a construction project.

BC 6500.course_name: Real Estate Asset and Income Property Management.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6500.course_description: This course covers real estate financial management and performance topics from a decision making and strategic planning orientation for facilities management professionals.

BC 6550.course_name: Design and Construction Processes for Integrated Services.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6550.course_description: Offers a framework for use and application of design, contract, and performance documents for successful execution of various forms of integrated project delivery systems.

BC 6570.course_name: Real Estate Development Basic Finance.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6570.course_description: Comprehensive overview of the business model and financing methodology to analyze and produce new real estate development.

BC 6575.course_name: Real Estate Production Finance.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6575.course_description: Business model and financing process required to produce new real estate developments through an investigation of land acquisition, development and construction financial management.

BC 6585.course_name: Management of Construction as Owner.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6585.course_description: Survey of construction management from the owner's perspective.

BC 6600.course_name: Facilities Management Financial Analysis.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6600.course_description: This course covers real property concepts, issues, and topics pertinent to the facility management professional.  The topics include site selection, property market analysis, legal documents, and land use control.

BC 6650.course_description: A four-phased coverage of project management including organization, planning and scheduling, control, budgeting, and ending with project testing, evaluation, and termination.

BC 6675.course_name: Residential Design and Construction.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6675.course_description: Course will examine the application of market, community, and regulatory factors to single family housing design and construction; construction management process required for efficient delivery.

BC 6685.course_name: Leadership and Communications in Design and Construction.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6685.course_description: Framework and guidelines for effective leadership and communications during design and construction.

BC 6700.course_name: Advanced Facility Management Practices.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6700.course_description: Students apply specific methods and procedures from core courses to actual business situations in the facility and property management industry.

BC 6731.course_description: Design, analysis, operation, construction, and cost feasibility of so-called "zero energy" houses.  Credit not allowed for both BC 6731 and ARCH 6731.

BC 6800.course_name: Facility and Property Management Capstone.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6800.course_description: Designed to integrate the learning from basic topics through the use of actual case studies and situations found within the facility and property management industry.

BC 6850.course_name: Building Construction and Facility Management Capstone.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6850.course_description: Application of coursework covered in the Master of Science in Building Construction and Facility Management curriculum with a stimulated business construct from different perspectives: construction manager, program manager, or facility manager.

BC 6875.course_name: Real Estate Development Capstone Project.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6875.course_description: Formulation and exploration of a real estate development project. Topics include business plan, market analysis, site selection, regulations, finance, project delivery, design and engineering.

BC 6910.course_name: Best Practices in Multi-Family Property.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6910.course_description: A course designed to provide students with a broad range of the best practices related to the management of all types of multi-family residential property.

BC 6920.course_name: Introduction to Residential Property Management.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6920.course_description: A course designed to orient students to the basics of apartment management and includes the business functions of marketing, leasing, and financing.

BC 6930.course_name: Intg Design Constr & Dev.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6930.course_description: This course will focus on contemporary integrated approach to design, construction and development.  Course involves real-world project analysis from multiple points aof view. Examples to be selected from the Atlanta region.

BC 6975.course_name: The Evolution of a Deal.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 6975.course_description: Presentations and site visits conducted by developers to expose students to design program implementation, financial structure, and project management.

BC 7100.course_name: Quantitative Methods for Construction Research.  3 Credit Hours.
BC 7100.course_description: Introductory course in graduate research in the building construction industry.  Covers types of research, sampling methods, and basic analysis and evaluation techniques.

BC 7200.course_name: Advanced Readings in BC in Preparation for the PhD Comprehensive Examination.  1-12 Credit Hours.
BC 7200.course_description: This course is designed around advanced readings in research and practice for PhD students working in the building construction area.

BC 8000.course_name: PhD Seminar for Students with Building Construction Emphasis.  1 Credit Hour.
BC 8000.course_description: This is an introduction to PhD-level research in Building Construction.

BC 8100.course_description: Research design course that teaches the basics of creating credible scientific research plans with examples from construction related research.

BMED 1300.course_description: Biomedical engineering problems from industrial and clinical applications are addressed and solved in small groups using problem-based learning methodologies.

Crosslisted with AE, CHE, ECE, ME, and MSE 1750.

BMED 2110.course_description: A study of material and energy balances applied to problems in biomedical engineering.

BMED 2250.course_name: Problems in Biomedical Engineering.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 2250.course_description: Biomedical engineering problems from industrial and clinical applications are addressed and solved in small groups using problem-based learning methodologies. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED 2250 and BMED 1300.

BMED 2300.course_name: Problems in Biomedical Engineering II.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 2300.course_description: Biomedical engineering problems from industrial and clinical applications are addressed and solved in small groups using problem-based learning methods.

BMED 2310.course_name: Intro to Biomedical Engineering Design.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 2310.course_description: In small teams students will apply problem-based learning and human centered design to reverse engineer, analyze, and redesign medical devices. Credit will not be awareded for both BMED 2310 and BMED 2300.

BMED 2400.course_name: Introduction to Bioengineering Statistics.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 2400.course_description: Introduction to statistical modeling and data analysis in bioscientific and bioengineering applications. Topics include estimation, testing, regression, and experimental design.
