BMED 3100.course_description: An introduction to human physiology emphasizing biomedical engineering aproaches to the understanding of basic organ function, disease states, and medical intervention.

BMED 3101.course_name: Introduction to Biomedical Data Science and Engineering.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 3101.course_description: Practical/hands-on experience in performing biomedical-related data processing/computation/analysis with a variety of computer tools, platforms, and applications.

BMED 3110.course_name: Quantitative Engineering Physiology Laboratory I.  2 Credit Hours.
BMED 3110.course_description: A hands-on lab providing an active learning team environment to reinforce selected engineering principles of physiology, emphasizing a quantitative model-oriented approach to physiological systems.

BMED 3201.course_name: Introduction to Machine Learning for Biomedical Engineers.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 3201.course_description: This course is designed to provide biomedical engineering undergraduates with a solid foundation in the principles and applications of machine learning.

BMED 3211.course_description: Students will be introduced to the field of bioinformatics, an interdisciplinary field that combines computer science, statistics, machine learning and mathematics to analyze biological data.

BMED 3231.course_description:
An introduction to the intersection between neuroscience and neurotechnology, including identification of key aspects of the
nervous system as the basis for measurement and intervention.

BMED 3300.course_description: Fundamental principles of fluid, heat, and mass transfer with particular emphasis on physiological and biomedical systems.

BMED 3310.course_description: Fundamental principles of fluid, heat, and mass transfer with particular emphasis on physiological and biomedical systems. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED 3310 and BMED 3300.

BMED 3400.course_description: An introduction to the basic concepts and methods in biomechanics, including statistics and the mechanics of biomaterials.  The biomedical applications of mechanics will be illustrated.

BMED 3410.course_description: Introduces concepts and approaches for biomedical deformation and dynamics problems using the application of simple models from statics, mechanics of materials, kinematics, and dynamics.

BMED 3500.course_name: Biomedical Sensors and Instrumentation.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 3500.course_description: A study of basic concepts and design of electronic sensors and instrumentation used in biomedical measurements. Standard clinical measurement techniques will also be examined.

BMED 3510.course_name: Biomedical Systems and Modeling.  4 Credit Hours.
BMED 3510.course_description: Basic concepts, modeling tools and analysis techniques for the study of biochemical, bioelectrical and biomedical systems.

BMED 3520.course_name: Biomedical Systems and Modeling.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 3520.course_description: Introduction of computational systems biology, including the modeling process, various types of models, standard analysis and simulation of systems, and applications in real-world biological systems. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED 3520 and BMED 3510.

BMED 3600.course_name: Physiology of Cellular and Molecular Systems.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 3600.course_description: In depth cell and molecular physiology focused on cellular responses to stimuli, including cell organization/ reorganization, membrane transport/kinetics, cell signaling/ molecular biology, mechanobiology and energy requirements.

BMED 3610.course_name: Quantitative Engineering Physiology Laboratory II.  2 Credit Hours.
BMED 3610.course_description: This lab provides an active learning team environment, incorporating common cell/molecular biology techniques, to reinforce selected engineering principles in an in vitro cell culture setting.

BMED 4000.course_name: The Art of Telling Your Story.  1 Credit Hour.
BMED 4000.course_description: Students will create a professional portfolio and develop the ability to pitch themselves to an audience to prepare themselves to begin their professional careers.

BMED 4400.course_description: Lab and lecture on current topics in Neuroengineering, including electrophysiology, clinical and diagnostic neuroengineering, neural prosthetics, sensory-motor integration, neuromorphic VLSI, neurodynamics and neurorobotics.

BMED 4477.course_name: Biological Networks and Genomics.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 4477.course_description: Introduction to modeling of biological networks involved in gene regulation, cell signaling and metabolism. Mathematical modeling of cellular processes, such as gene expression, using genomic data.

BMED 4478.course_name: Biomed-AI and Health Informatics.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 4478.course_description: The course will introduce commonly used informatics pipelines driven by current biomedicine and health care challenges and opportunities.

BMED 4500.course_name: Cell and Tissue Engineering Laboratory.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 4500.course_description: The principles of cell and tissue engineering will be presented as a laboratory course to give students a hands-on experience.  Cell engineering topics include receptor/ligand interactions, cell cycle/metabolism, cell adhesion, cellular mechanics, cell signal transduction, and cell transfection.  Tissue engineering topics include applications, biomaterials/scaffolds and cells for reparative medicine, bioreactors and bioprocessing, functional assessment, in vivo issues.

BMED 4600.course_name: Senior Design Project I.  2 Credit Hours.
BMED 4600.course_description: Team-oriented major design project in biomedical engineering, incorporating engineering standards and realistic design constraints.  Credit not allowed for BMED 4600 and BMED 4603 (or BMED 4601).

BMED 4601.course_name: Senior Design Project II.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 4601.course_description: Team-oriented major design project in biomedical engineering, incorporating engineering standards and realistic design constraints.  Credit not allowed for both BMED 4601 and BMED 4603 (or BMED 4600).

BMED 4602.course_description: Team-oriented design project in biomedical engineering, incorporating engineering standards and realistic design constraints.  Includes introduction to relevant regulatory, intellectual property, and business management topics.

BMED 4603.course_description: Continuation of a team-oriented design experience initiated in BMED 4602 Capstone Design.  Includes more advanced relevant regulatory. intellectual property, and business management topics.  Credit not allowed for both BMED 4603 and BMED 4600 (or BMED 4601).

BMED 4698.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BMED 4699.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

BMED 4723.course_description: Interdisciplinary Capstone Design, Industry projects or CREATE-X section.

BMED 4739.course_description: An interdisciplinary course focusing on fundamental understanding of robot kinematics and dynamics as well as the design, development, and evaluation of a medical robotic system.

BMED 4740.course_description: We examine evolutionary adaptation as a source for engineering design inspiration, utilizing principles of scaling, adaptability, and robust multifunctionality that characterize biological systems.

BMED 4750.course_description: Physics and image formation methods for conventional X-ray, digital X-ray CT, nuclear medicine, and magnetic resonance and ultrasound imaging.  Crosslisted with MP 4750 and NRE 4750.

BMED 4751.course_description: Introduction to different classes of biomaterials (polymers, metals, ceramics) and physiological responses to biomaterial implantation. Topics include material properties, host response, and biomaterial characterization techniques. Crosslisted with MSE 4751.

BMED 4752.course_description: Goals are to understand the components of the nervous system and their functional interactions, and appreciate the complexity of higher order brain functions and pathways. Crosslisted with BIOL 4752.

BMED 4757.course_description: Introduction to the study of blood flow in the cardiovascular system. Emphasis on modeling and the potential of flow studies for clinical research application. Crosslisted with AE, CHE and ME 4757.

BMED 4758.course_description: The mechanics of living tissue, e.g., arteries, skin, heart muscle, ligament, tendon, cartilage, and bone. Constitutive equations and some simple mechanical models. Mechanics of cells.  Applications. Crosslisted with AE, CHE, and ME 4758.

BMED 4765.course_name: Drug Design, Development and Delivery.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 4765.course_description: Introduction to the pharmaceutical development process, including design of new drugs, synthesis and manufacturing issues, and methods for delivery into the body. Includes student presentations. Crosslisted with CHEM and CHBE 4765.

BMED 4775.course_description: Learn how to design biomedical microsystems ready for clinical and biomedical translation. Course blends theory with examples of successful biomedical research, clinical translation, and case studies.

BMED 4781.course_description: A study of medical instrumentation from a systems viewpoint. Pertinent physiological and electro-physiological concepts will be covered.  Credit not allowed for both BMED 4781 and (CHE 4781 or ME 4781 or CHBE 4781 or ECE 4781).

BMED 4782.course_description: Analytical methods for modeling biological systems, including white-noise protocols for characterizing nonlinear systems. Crosslisted with CHE, ECE, and ME 4782.

BMED 4783.course_name: Introduction to Medical Image Processing.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 4783.course_description: A study of mathematical methods used in medical image acquisition and processing. Concepts, algorithms, and methods associated with acquisition, processing, and display of two- and three-dimensional medical imaged are studied. Crosslisted with ECE 4783.

BMED 4784.course_description: Basic concepts of electrophysiology from an engineering perspective. Functionality of relevant organs and systems; instrumentation tools which monitor electrophysiology function. Crosslisted with ECE 4784.

BMED 4785.course_description: The course will cover the fundamental principles of optical imaging and detail the inner workings of key microscopy technologies.

BMED 4786.course_name: Medical Imaging Systems: Physics, Engineering, and Applications.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 4786.course_description: Introduce major biomedical and clinical imaging modalities including X-ray radiography, computed tomography (CT), nuclear medicine (SPECT and PET), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and ultrasound.

BMED 6041.course_description: Basic analytical approaches to solve mathematical problems involved in biomedical engineering applications. Course focuses on ordinary and partial differential equations and on integral transform methods.

BMED 6042.course_description: Regulation of physiological functions in the cardio-respiratory-renal, musculoskeletal, and gastrointestinal systems, and their interactions with the neural, endocrine, and immune systems.

BMED 6210.course_description: This course covers the basic physics and engineering principles, advanced techniques and major applications of magnetic resonance imaging.

BMED 6501.course_name: Fundamentals of Biomedical Innovation and Development Processes.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6501.course_description: Key steps, multiple stakeholders and interdependencies in the design and commercialization process for medical products.

BMED 6502.course_name: BioID Clinical Literacy and Experience.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6502.course_description: Education in interfacing with medical healthcare professionals, medical terminology, on-site clinical observations, needs-finding, case analysis, creating design solutions for improved methods, products and procedures.

BMED 6503.course_name: Medical Markets and Clinical Specialties.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6503.course_description: Introduction to medical device and biologics industries, interdependencies of commercial companies, vendors and suppliers required for development, commercialization and sales of products and equipment.

BMED 6504.course_name: Financial Planning for Development Projects.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6504.course_description: Finance planning for development projects including: costing, forecasting, time value of money, breakeven analysis, return on investment analysis, capital budgeting, risk and return, working capital management.

BMED 6505.course_name: Product Planning and Project Management.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6505.course_description: Strategy and analysis techniques to evaluate and manage new product innovations, product improvements and product line extensions in context of an entity's mission and goals.

BMED 6506.course_name: Professional Communications for Biomedical Innovation and Development.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6506.course_description: Techniques and practice of effective oral presentations project/grant proposal writing, technical and project report writing to support medical device engineering, design and business.

BMED 6507.course_name: Medical Device Regulatory Requirements.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6507.course_description: FDA Regulations for medical devices including clearance-approval pathways to commercialization, Quality Systems Regulations and ISO Standards for medical devices in the European Economic Community.

BMED 6508.course_name: BioID Team Masters Project I.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6508.course_description: Team project to address an unmet medical need and develop an innovative solution including the engineering design document package and proof-of-concept prototyhpe.

BMED 6509.course_name: BioID Masters Project II.  6 Credit Hours.
BMED 6509.course_description: Teams will construct prototypes for Course I biomedical device project solution, conduct and analyze performance testing, prepare FDA 510(k) submission, and prepare project commercialization plan.

BMED 6517.course_name: Machine Learning in Biosciences.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6517.course_description: Introduces machine learning concepts and methods, including supervised and unsupervised learning, dimension reduction and visualization. Topics are accompanied by bioinformatics and systems biology applications.

BMED 6700.course_description: An introduction to fundamental ideas and techniques in Biostatistics, with an emphasis on conceptual understanding and on the analysis of real data sets.

BMED 6710.course_name: Rational Design of Biomaterials.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6710.course_description: The goal of this course is to give graduate students the ability to rationally design new biomaterials by integrating organic chemistry concepts with molecular biology.

BMED 6711.course_name: Rational Design of Biomaterials Lab.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6711.course_description: The goal of this course is to teach students the laboratory skills needed to design and synthesize new biomaterials.

BMED 6720.course_description: This graduate level course covers the analysis of fluid flow phenomena in the human body, cardiovasculature, respiratory system and other organ systems.

BMED 6730.course_name: Materials Science of Cellular Components.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6730.course_description: Addresses structure-property relationship of cellular components.  Credit not allowed for both BMED 6730 and MSE 6730.

BMED 6739.course_description: This interdisciplinary course focuses on a fundamental understanding of robot kinematics and dynamics as well as the design, development, and evaluation of a medical robotic system.

BMED 6740.course_name: Living System Modeling & Analysis.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6740.course_description: The purpose of this course is to introduce graduate students to living system models as pre-clinical test beds for a wide variety of biotechnologies.

BMED 6743.course_description: Structure-function relationships and constitutive models for a variety of biological tissues, with an emphasis on understanding the mechanical behaviors of normal and pathological tissues. Credit not given for both BMED/ME 6783 and BMED/ME 6743. Crosslisted with ME 6743.

BMED 6753.course_name: Principles of Management for Engineers.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6753.course_description: The course will provide an introduction to selected topics needed to be successful in the technology industries. Cannot count toward major area requirements in M.S. or Ph.D. programs of study.

BMED 6760.course_name: Information Processing Models in Neural Systems.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6760.course_description: This course will examine "top down" modeling approaches for sensorineural systems, where an optimal computational principle used in engineering (e.g., information theory, Bayesian inference, control theory) explains observed information processing.

BMED 6765.course_name: Drug Design, Development and Delivery.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6765.course_description: Introduction to the pharmaceutical development process, including design of new drugs, synthesis and manufacturing issues, and methods of delivery into the body. Includes student presentations.  Crosslisted with BMED 6765 and CHBE 6765.

BMED 6774.course_name: Biomaterials: Structure and Function.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6774.course_description: Structure-function relationships of biomaterials and biomaterial characterization will be covered. Materials for medial implants, tissue engineering, biosensing, imaging, and drug delivery will be covered. Crosslisted with CHE, ME, and MSE 6774.

BMED 6775.course_description: Learn how to design biomedical microsystems ready for clinical and biomedical translation. Course blends theory with examples of successful biomedical research, clinical translation, and case studies.

BMED 6777.course_description: Advanced topics of biomaterials performance and engineering, including biointerfaces, host reactions to materials, and bio-inspired/smart-materials strategies. Crosslisted with CHE, ME, and MSE 6777.

BMED 6779.course_description: Study of enzymes and microbial and mammalian cells for production of biochemicals and protein therapeutics in bioreactors; downstream separation and purification; integrated view of bioprocesses. Crosslisted with CHE 6779.

BMED 6780.course_description: A study of methods for enhancing, analyzing, interpreting, and visualizing information from two- and three-dimensional data obtained from a variety of medical imaging modalities. Crosslisted with ECE and CS 6780.

BMED 6782.course_description: Engineering analysis of cellular systems.  Crosslisted with CHE and ME 6782.

BMED 6784.course_description: Mechanical analysis of the cardiovascular system emphasizing the normal and pathologic function in relation to clinical cardiovascular medicine.  Crosslisted with CHE and ME 6784.

BMED 6785.course_description: The course will cover the fundamental principles of optical imaging and detail the inner workings of key microscopy technologies.

BMED 6786.course_description: A study of the principles and design of medical imaging systems such as X-ray, ultrasound, nuclear medicine, and nuclear magnetic resonance. Crosslisted with ECE 6786.

BMED 6787.course_description: A quantitative presentation of electrophysiological systems in biological organisms, emphasizing the electrical properties and modeling of neural and cardiac cells and systems.  Crosslisted with PHYS and ECE 6787.

BMED 6789.course_description: Team discussion and case studies in biomedical engineering technology transfer, including licensing, financial capital, safety and efficacy studies, clinical trials, and strategic planning.  Crosslisted with ECE, CHE, ME, and MGT 6789.

BMED 6790.course_name: Information Processing Models in Neural Systems.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6790.course_description: Examines "top-down" modeling approaches for sensorineural systems, where optimal computational principles used in engineering(e.g., information theory, Bayesian inference, control theory) explain observed information processing.

BMED 6793.course_description: Overview of human pathophysiology from a quantitative perspective.  A brief introduction to the application of quantitative models to the understanding of biological systems.  Crosslisted with CHE, ECE, and ME 6793.

BMED 6794.course_description: Biological, engineering, and medical issues in developing tissue engineered constructs. Emphasis in the integration of these disciplines at a basic molecular and cell biology level.  Crosslisted with CHE and ME 6794.

BMED 6799.course_name: Legal Issues in Technology Transfer.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 6799.course_description: Study and analysis of U.S. law as it applies to the patenting and licensing processes. Crosslisted with CHE, ME, and MGT 6799.

BMED 7001.course_description: Graduate students of the Biomedical Engineering department (all programs) participate in seminars involving current research projects presented by faculty and invited speakers.

BMED 7002.course_description: This course provides discipline-specific training that addresses intellectual problems and teaching strategies from the perspective of the discipline.  Credit not allowed for both BMED 7002 and BMED 8696.

BMED 7003.course_description: This course provides discipline-specific training that addresses intellectual problems and teaching strategies from the perspective of the discipline.  Credit not allowed for both BMED 7003 and BMED 8697.

BMED 7004.course_name: Teaching & Research Practicum I.  1 Credit Hour.
BMED 7004.course_description: This course provides the practicial framework for understanding challenges faced during teaching, research, and academic life. This course includes topical materials required for BME RCR requirements.

BMED 7005.course_name: Teaching & Research Practicum II.  1 Credit Hour.
BMED 7005.course_description: This course provides the practical framework for understanding challenges faced during teaching, research, and academic life.

BMED 7011.course_name: Integrative Core: Introduction to Modeling and Experimentation in Biomedical Engineering.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 7011.course_description: An introduction to how engineers approach problems - via conceptual models that are then used to create wet lab models and in silico models.

BMED 7012.course_name: Integrative Core: Experimental Design-Measurements at the Right Spatial and Temporal Scales.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 7012.course_description: This integrative core course focuses on the design of experiments to answer scientific questions, with an emphasis on the spatial and temporal scales of measurements.

BMED 7013.course_name: Integrative Core: Problem Solving with Computational Models.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 7013.course_description: An introduction to computational model methodologies for complex biomedical/biological systems.  Emphasis is placed on developing well-posed scientific hypotheses through the use of simulations.

BMED 7101.course_name: Advanced Seminar: Biomaterials & Regenerative Medicine.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 7101.course_description: This course is intended to promote critical review of the "State-of-the-art" biomaterial technologies to identify knowledge gaps that must be overcome to further biomaterials development.

BMED 7201.course_name: Advanced Seminar: Cardiovascular Biology & Biomechanics.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 7201.course_description: To review current topics in cardiovascular engineering, biology and diseases through critical literature review.  In addition, each student will develop and present a "Proposal" by the end of the class.

BMED 7301.course_name: Advanced Seminar: Cellular & Biomolecular Engineering.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 7301.course_description: This seminar course illustrates the development of micro- and nano-scale engineering approaches for studies of biomolecules and cells and their applications to medicine.

BMED 7310.course_description: Fundamentals for the application of analytical engineering approaches to the quantitative study of stem cell biology and translation into cell therapies and diagnostics.

BMED 7410.course_name: Introduction to Multiscale Analysis in Systems.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 7410.course_description: The class explores modeling analyses spanning multiple levels of biological organization at different resolutions of detail.  Emphasis is placed on control in complex biological systems.

BMED 7411.course_name: Mathematical Models in Biology & Medicine.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 7411.course_description: The course introduces the student to a representative set of models that elucidate the nature of biological and medical phenomena.

BMED 7413.course_description: The course introduces BME students interested in mathematical modeling and systems biology to the computational analysis of metabolic and other dynamic systems in biology.

BMED 7601.course_name: Advanced Seminar: Neuroengineering and Neuropathology.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 7601.course_description: Current issues in neuroengineering.  Focus is placed on neuropathological complexity across cellular and organ level scales through literature reading, discussion, and independent study.

BMED 7610.course_description: A quantitative presentation of neural signal processing and information coding, emphasizing the circuitry of sensory and motor pathways of the brain.

BMED 7741.course_description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Program introduction. Technical resume preparation. GT Robotics labs & resources.

BMED 7742.course_description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Selecting and applying for Internship. Developing capstone project proposal. Public speaking practice and preparation.

BMED 7743.course_description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Interview preparation & career search. Technical report writing and presentation.

BMED 7785.course_name: Introduction to Robotics Research.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 7785.course_description: Familiarizes students with the core of robotics: mechanics, control, perception, AI, and autonomy.  Provides an introduction to the mathematical tools required in robotics research. Cross-listed with AE 7785, ECE 7785, and CS 7785.

BMED 8740.course_description: Graduate Internship at a partner company, GTRI or a GT Robotics lab.

BMED 8741.course_description: Teams or individuals apply the knowledge and skills acquired throughout the MS program to a faculty supervised robotics project.

BMED 8750.course_name: Multidisciplinary Robotics Research I.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 8750.course_description: Multidisciplinary research course supervised by two robotics faculty from different schools participating in the robotics Ph.D. program. Cross-listed with AE, CS, and ECE 8750.

BMED 8751.course_name: Multidisciplinary Robotics Research II.  3 Credit Hours.
BMED 8751.course_description: Continuation of BMED 8750 (Multidisciplinary Robotics Research I). Cros-listed with AE, CS, and ECE 8751.

BMED 8811.course_description: Topics of current interest in biomedical engineering.

BMED 8812.course_description: Topics of current interest in biomedical engineering.

BMED 8813.course_description: Topics of current interest in biomedical engineering.

BMED 8814.course_description: Topics of current interest in biomedical engineering.

BMED 8815.course_description: Topics of current interest in biomedical engineering.

BMED 8823.course_description: Topics of current interest in biomedical engineering.

BMED 8853.course_description: Topics of current interest in biomedical engineering.

BMED 8901.course_description: Individual studies and/or experimental investigations of problems of current interest in bioengineering.

BMED 8997.course_description: For graduate students holding a teaching assistantship.

BMED 8998.course_description: For graduate students holding a research assistantship.

EAS 1600.course_name: Introduction to Environmental Science.  4 Credit Hours.
EAS 1600.course_description: Introduction to environmental field science. Case study approach. Exposure to basic field equipment and techniques, analysis of data.

EAS 1601.course_description: Introduction to the origin and evolution of Planet Earth, creation of the universe and the elements, early history of Earth, radioisotope geochemistry and the timing of events in the universe, the galaxy, and on Earth. Formation of the atmosphere and oceans. Climate.

EAS 1XXX.course_name: Earth and Atmospheric Sciences Elective.  1-21 Credit Hours.

EAS 2420.course_name: Environmental Measures of Urban and Regional Change.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 2420.course_description: Identify and quantify nature's physical and chemical contributions to human-made urban environments, and measure the impacts of urban area feedback on these natural systems.

EAS 2551.course_name: Introduction to Meteorological Analysis.  1 Credit Hour.
EAS 2551.course_description: An introduction to analysis of forecasting data and moel output.

EAS 2600.course_description: An introduction to earth materials and processes.

EAS 2602.course_description: Dynamic processes affecting the Earth system on all time scales.

EAS 2655.course_name: Quantitative Techniques in Earth and Atmospheric Sciences.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 2655.course_description: Integrated course in mathematical, physical, and computing techniques for applications in earth and atmospheric sciences.

EAS 2694.course_description: Earth & Atmospheric Sciences Undergraduate Internship for pay for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Earth & Atmospheric Sciences.

EAS 2695.course_description: Earth & Atmospheric Sciences Undergraduate Internship for credit for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Earth & Atmospheric Sciences.

EAS 2699.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

EAS 2750.course_name: Physics of the Weather.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 2750.course_description: An introductory treatment of the application of the basic physical laws to the understanding of weather phenomena. Crosslisted with PHYS 2750.

EAS 2XXX.course_name: Earth and Atmospheric Sciences Elective.  1-21 Credit Hours.

EAS 3110.course_name: Energy, Environment, and Society.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 3110.course_description: This course analyzes the path towards alternative energy infrastructures for the 21st century with careful consideration of economic, environmental, technological, and political factors.

EAS 3603.course_name: Thermodynamics of Earth Systems.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 3603.course_description: Introduction to the principles of equilinrium thermodynamics and physical chemistry with applications to the atmosphere, ocean, and solid earth.

EAS 3610.course_description: An introduction to visualizing and understanding earth history, structure, and dynamics through geophysical methods including seismology, gravity, magnetism, heat flow, geochronology, and geodesy.

EAS 3620.course_description: A quantitative treatment of geochemical processes in the Earth and natural waters, with emphasis on chemical reactions among atmospheric gases, minerals, and aqueous solutions.

EAS 3XXX.course_name: Earth and Atmospheric Sciences Elective.  1-21 Credit Hours.

EAS 4110.course_name: Resources, Energy and the Environment.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 4110.course_description: Learn about the science behind the nature, occurrence and extraction of earth resources used by humans and the environmental impacts of that use.

EAS 4200.course_name: Structural Geology and Continuum Mechanics.  4 Credit Hours.
EAS 4200.course_description: Structural geology and continuum mechanics for scientists and civil engineers. Stress and strain in rocks; faults, joints, and folds; basic field mapping; laboratory exercises.

EAS 4205.course_description: Overview of the mechanical, chemical, and biological processes that shape topography.

EAS 4220.course_description: An exploration of the chemical, biological, and geological processes controlling the distribution of chemical nutrients and pollutants in aquatic and soil environments.

EAS 4221.course_description: Lab and field exploration of the chemical, biological, and geological processes controlling the distribution of chemical nutrients and pollutants in aquatic and soil environments.

EAS 4224.course_description: Fundamental principles concerning mineral surface properties, element distribution at the mineral-water interface and analytical techniques relevant to interfacial reactions.

EAS 4300.course_name: Introduction to Physical and Chemical Oceanography.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 4300.course_description: Chemistry and physics of the ocean. Distributions of temperature, salinity, and density. Equations of state and motion. Surface and deep-water circulation.  Waves and tides. Composition of seawater: dissolved sales, gases, and nutrients. Biological processes. Marine sediments.

EAS 4305.course_name: Physical and Chemical Oceanography.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 4305.course_description: Study of the dynamics of large-scale ocean circulation, air-sea interaction and their roles in biogeochemical cycling of carbon and nutrients.

EAS 4312.course_description: Quantitative discussion of dynamic processs in the solid Earth; lithospheric dynamics, continuum mechanics, lithospheric flexure and elasticity, heat transfer, viscous rheology, fluid mechanics, and earthquake dynamics.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4312 and EAS 6312.

EAS 4313.course_name: Tectonics. Climate, and Landscape Evolution.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 4313.course_description: Introduction to the interactions and feedbacks between tectonics and climate that act to shape landscapes. Includes field- and computer-based data collection and analysis.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4313 and EAS 6313.

EAS 4314.course_description: Introduction to elastic wave propagation, and studies of the solid Earth's interior and earthquake source from seismic waves.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4314 and EAS 6314.

EAS 4315.course_description: This course focuses on the fundamental concepts of fluid dynamics merged with geophysical applications.

EAS 4316.course_description: Fundamental physics of processes that control fault slips and earthquakes with a focus on the latest emerging research topics in the field.

EAS 4331.course_description: This class examines the dynamics and thermodynamics of planetary volcanism.  The course material covers the generation and transport of magma in the mantle and crust, and the fluid dynamics of eruptions and their impact on the landscape and atmosphere.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4331 and EAS 6331.

EAS 4350.course_description: This course will explore the history of the Earth's climate, covering methods for reconstructing past climate and the mechanisms behind these climate changes.

EAS 4360.course_name: Space Physics and Space Instrumentation.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 4360.course_description: This course will explore the interaction of the solar wind with the Earth's magnetosphere using a combination spacecraft observations and fundamental plasma physics.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4360 and EAS 6360.

EAS 4370.course_description: In this course we will study the forces and influences that determine the composition, structure and evolution of the planets in our solar system.

EAS 4375.course_name: Earth and Planetary Materials.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 4375.course_description: Fundamental principles and applications of mineralogy and petrology for understanding the composition of surface and subsurface materials on Earth and other planetary bodies.

EAS 4380.course_description: Techniques for making remote measurements of the composition, morphology, and thermophysical properties of solid surfaces on Earth and other planetary bodies.

EAS 4410.course_name: Climate and Global Change.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 4410.course_description: The physics behind the climate and its potential changes, as well as an introduction to the policy issues in global change.

EAS 4420.course_description: Semester-long focus on single environmental project in the local area.  Chemical and physical techniques for parameterizing environmental problems, data analysis, report writing, and interpretation of results in societal context.

EAS 4430.course_name: Remote Sensing and Data Analysis.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 4430.course_description: Introduction to the remote sensing of the atmosphere and the Earth. Laboratory examples of data and image analysis for remote sensing applications.

EAS 4450.course_description: A description of physical and mathematical procedures used in weather forecasting.  Students will practice forecasting.

EAS 4460.course_name: Satellite and Radar Meteorology.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 4460.course_description: Interpretation of satellite and radar data for meteorological forecasting based on understanding radiative transfer and the resulting strengths and limitations of the imagery.

EAS 4470.course_description: Structure and dynamics of phenomena including weather regimes, storm tracks, El Nino-Southern Oscillations, teleconnections, monsoons, Arctic Oscillation, stratospheric polar vortex, and stratosphere-troposphere coupling.

EAS 4480.course_description: Data Analysis methods used in environmental research are taught through examples.  Students learn to implement these methods to areas of their own interests.

EAS 4510.course_description: Methods of exploration geophysics, including refraction and reflection seismology, resistivity, gravity, magnetics, and ground penetrating radar.  Includes laboratory work and introduction to operation of field equipment.

EAS 4515.course_name: Fluids in the Earth's Crust I.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 4515.course_description: Fundamentals of porosity and permeability in soils, sediments, and crystalline rocks; basic physics of fluid flow through interconnected pore spaces and cracks; introductory analysis of fluid flow as an agent of heat and chemical transport in geological systems.

EAS 4520.course_name: Seismic Methods in Exploration Geophysics.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 4520.course_description: A study of seismic reflection exploration methods and theory.  Examples are taken from oil industry exploration and production and near-surface environmental imaging.

EAS 4525.course_name: Weather Risk and Catastrophe Modeling.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 4525.course_description: Overview of the physics and dynamics behind different types of hazardous weather and the mathematical tools to model the risks associated with these events.

EAS 4602.course_description: An investigation of global change focusing on the chemical, physical, geological, and biological processes that cycle the elements through the Earth system.

EAS 4610.course_description: An introduction to computer modeling in Earth system science.

EAS 4625.course_description: Gain hands-on experience using geochemical software and understanding governing geochemical principles pertaining to transformation of contaminants and other subsurface species through case studies.

EAS 4630.course_name: Physics of the Earth.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 4630.course_description: Introduction to methods and observational data used to determine solid Earth structure and to understand the dynamical processes driving surface deformation and plate tectonics.

EAS 4641.course_description: A hands-on laboratory course in which students will learn basic concepts and techniques used by atmospheric chemists including analysis, data quality and experimental design.

EAS 4651.course_description: Faculty-supervised and approved independent internship, employment, or research project related to earth and atmospheric sciences.

EAS 4655.course_description: An introduction to the atmospheric physical and dynamic processes that control weather and climate.

EAS 4656.course_description: Students learn to apply meteorological analysis tools to atmospheric observations to interpret the structure and dynamics of historical and real-time weather events.

EAS 4670.course_description: This course emphasizes physical concepts and analytic techniques for solving problems in atmospheric instabilities and wave dynamics at various temporal and spatial scales.

EAS 4694.course_description: Earth & Atmospheric Sciences Undergraduate Internship for pay for junior and seniors, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Earth & Atmospheric Sciences.

EAS 4695.course_description: Earth & Atmospheric Sciences Undergraduate Internship for credit for juniors and seniors, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Earth & Atmospheric Sciences.

EAS 4698.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

EAS 4699.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

EAS 4740.course_description: This course provides a general chemical description of the Earth's atmospheric system with a major focus on the two lowest layers of the atmosphere, i.e., the troposphere and the stratosphere. Crosslisted with CHEM 4740.

EAS 4795.course_description: Dynamics of flow and solute transport in groundwater, including theory, implementation, and case studies. Crosslisted with CEE 4795.

EAS 4813.course_description: Special Topics in Earth and Atmospheric Sciences.

EAS 4821.course_description: Special Topics in EAS (1-credit hour supervised lab).

EAS 4XXX.course_name: Earth and Atmospheric Sciences Elective.  1-21 Credit Hours.

EAS 6000.course_description: Identify and discuss ethical challenges that will be confronted in research, and give an overview of the research areas of the faculty in EAS.

EAS 6053.course_description: A guide to a career in academia for scientists. Learn about getting a faculty position, establishing a successful research.

EAS 6111.course_description: Exploration of processes linking the Earth and atmosphere.

EAS 6120.course_description: Environmental site characterization through a field-based project that advances student's research.  Theory, field data acquisition, and data fusion using geochemical, geophysical, hydrologic, and related methods.

EAS 6121.course_name: Modeling and Computer Programming for Geosciences.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6121.course_description: This course gives students first-hand experience on the development process of problem solving in Earth and Atmospheric Sciences from mathematically describing a problem to solving it by parallel programming on a high performance computer.

EAS 6122.course_description: A multidisciplinary exploration of the chemical, physical, geological, and biological processes that cycle the nutrient elements through the Earth system and thereby maintain a habitable planet.

EAS 6124.course_description: Chemistry and physics of the ocean.  Distributions of temperatures, salinity, and density.  Equations of state and motion.  Surface and deep-water circulation, waves, and tides.  Composition of seawater: dissolved salts, gases, and nutrients.  Biological processes. Marine sediments.

EAS 6125.course_description: Gain hands-on experience using geochemical software and understanding governing geochemical principles pertaining to transformation of contaminants and other subsurface species through case studies.

EAS 6128.course_name: Fluids in the Earth's Crust.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6128.course_description: Advanced treatment of fluid flow, heat transfer, and reactive transport in porous and cracked rocks; stability of flow; double-diffusive systems; evolution of permeability in geologic systems; introduction to multiphase flow.

EAS 6130.course_description: An introduction to computer modeling in earth system science.

EAS 6131.course_description: Developing and using ocean models from the simple shallow water to the full primitive equation model. Includes hands-on programming.

EAS 6132.course_name: Introduction to Climate Change.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6132.course_description: The climate of the Earth, its radiation budget, greenhouse gases and their sources and sinks, potential changes due to anthropogenic activities, detection of climate changes.

EAS 6133.course_description: Modeling population dynamics in the context of ocean circulation. Numerical techniques and simulation development.

EAS 6134.course_name: Inverse Methods and Time Series Analysis in Earth and Atmospheric Sciences.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6134.course_description: Theory of data acquisition, time series analysis, and discrete inverse theory, with applications in the earth and atmospheric sciences.

EAS 6135.course_name: Introduction to Complex Environmental Systems.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6135.course_description: Introduction to the concepts of environmental complexity through the inter-relationships between natural, human, and built systems.

EAS 6136.course_description: This course will explore the history of the Earth's climate, covering methods for reconstructing past climate and the mechanisms behind these climate changes.

EAS 6140.course_name: Thermodynamics of Atmospheres and Oceans.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6140.course_description: The instabilities and flows created by exchanges of heat.

EAS 6142.course_description: Fundamentals of the interaction of electromagnetic radiation with atmospheric constituents, including absorption and scattering processes by the atmospheric gases, aerosols, and clouds.

EAS 6145.course_name: Remote Sensing of the Atmosphere and Oceans.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6145.course_description: Provides a foundation for understanding the physical principles of remote sensing and its applications to the study of atmospheric gases, clouds, and ocean surfaces.

EAS 6155.course_name: Advanced Geophysical Fluid Dynamics.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6155.course_description: Fundamental mathematical tools for graduate students interested in Geophysical Fluid Dynamics (GFD) and related disciplines.

EAS 6200.course_description: An exploration of the chemical, biological, and geological processes controlling the distribution of chemical nutrients and pollutants in aquatic and soil environments.

EAS 6201.course_description: Lab and field exploration of the chemical, biological, and geological processes controlling the distribution of chemical nutrients and pollutants in aquatic and soil environments.

EAS 6211.course_description: Fundamental principles of chemical equilibria in geochemical systems with emphasis on solution properties and mineral water equilibria.

EAS 6212.course_description: Fundamental principles of biogeochemical kinetics and mathematical treatment of coupled transport and reaction in natural environments.  Interpretation of field and experimental data using kinetic theory.

EAS 6214.course_description: Chemical processes that regulate compositions of natural waters at or near the Earth's surface, with emphasis on quantitative calculations of acid-base, solubility, and redox equilibria.

EAS 6216.course_description: Biogeochemical significance of nuclear isotopes, both radioactive and stable.

EAS 6224.course_description: Fundamental principles concerning mineral surface properties, element distribution at the mineral-water interface, and analytical techniques relevant to interfacial reactions.

EAS 6240.course_description: Origin and transformation of organic matter in the Earth's environments, with emphasis on properties and reactions of highly complex mixtures such as humic substances.

EAS 6305.course_name: Physical and Chemical Oceanography.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6305.course_description: Study of the dynamics of large-scale ocean circulation, air-sea interaction and their roles in biogeochemical cycling of carbon and nutrients.

EAS 6311.course_name: Physics of the Earth.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6311.course_description: Physics of the Earth's interior. Composition and structure of core, mantle, crust. Introduction to seismic wave propagation, gravitational, geomagnetic, and temperature fields.

EAS 6312.course_description: Quantitative discussion of dynamical processes in the solid Earth; viscous flow, glacial rebound, fluid dynamical instabilities, thermal convection; lithospheric dynamics; evolution of the core.

EAS 6313.course_name: Tectonics, Climate, and Landscape Evolution.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6313.course_description: Introduction to the interactions and feedbacks between tectonics and climate that act to shape landscapes. Includes field- and computer-based data collection and analysis.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 6313 and EAS 4313.

EAS 6314.course_description: The propagation of seismic waves, the description of earthquake motion, and evaluation of earthquake damage. Examples provide experience in the interpretation of seismic data.

EAS 6315.course_description: This course focuses on the fundamental concepts of fluid dynamics merged with geophysical applications.

EAS 6316.course_description: Fundamental physics of processes that control fault slips and earthquakes with a focus on the latest emerging research topics in the field.

EAS 6320.course_name: Structural Geology and Continuum Mechanics.  4 Credit Hours.
EAS 6320.course_description: Structural geology and continuum mechanics for scientists and civil engineers.  Stress and strain in rocks; faults, joints, and folds; basic field mapping, laboratory exercises.

EAS 6325.course_description: Overview of the mechanical, chemical, and biological processes that shape the topography.

EAS 6331.course_description: This class examines the dynamics and thermodynamics of planetary volcanism.  The course material covers the generation and transport of magma in the mantle and crust, and the fluid dynamics of eruptions and their impact on the landscape and atmosphere.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 6331 and EAS 4331.

EAS 6333.course_name: Field Methods in Volcanic Terrain.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6333.course_description: A field based course to connect process-based models and field observations related to volcanic, eruptions, subsurface magma interaction, and crustal heat flow and tectonics.

EAS 6360.course_name: Space Physics and Space Instrumentation.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6360.course_description: This course will explore the interaction of the solar wind with the Earth's magnestophere using a combination spacecraft observation and fundamental plasma physics.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 6360 and EAS 4360.

EAS 6370.course_description: In this course we will study the forces and influences that determine the compostition, structure, and evolution of the planets of our solar system.

EAS 6375.course_name: Earth and Planetary Materials.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6375.course_description: Fundamental principles and application of mineralogy and petrology for understanding the composition of surface and subsurface materials on Earth and other planetary bodies.

EAS 6380.course_description: Techniques for making remote measurements of the composition, morphology, and thermophysical properties of solid surfaces on Earth and other planetary bodies.

EAS 6401.course_name: Introduction to Atmospheric Chemistry.  2 Credit Hours.
EAS 6401.course_description: Introduction to basic chemical principles related to chemical processes in the atmosphere.

EAS 6405.course_name: Introduction to Atmospheric and Aqueous Chemistry.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6405.course_description: An introduction to the basics of atmospheric and aqueous chemistry for first semester graduate students. The class goes over photochemistry, thermodynamics, kinetics, redox systems, carbon chemistry, radioactive and stable isotopes, and gas/solid reactions.

EAS 6410.course_description: Application of fundamental principles of chemistry to understanding the critical factors controlling the levels and distributions of atmospheric trace gases and their variation in time.

EAS 6412.course_name: Introduction to Physical Meteorology.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6412.course_description: Application of the fundamental principles of thermodynamics to the atmosphere; including hydrostatic equilibrium and static stability, derivation of Claussius-Clapeyron Equation, cloud microphysics, radiative transfer, and the Earth's energy budget.

EAS 6420.course_name: Introduction to Principles of Atmospheric Chemical.  4 Credit Hours.
EAS 6420.course_description: Introduction to the mechanical, electrical, and optical aspects of modern instrumentation used in atmospheric chemical research.

EAS 6430.course_name: Experimental Methods in Air Quality.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6430.course_description: Presents experimental and field methods through a focus on measurements of atmospheric gases and particulates associated with poor air quality. Experiments will involve laboratory measurements and an air quality filed experiment on the order of one week duration.

EAS 6490.course_name: Advanced Environmental Data Analysis.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6490.course_description: A unified view of the theories and applications underlying the statistical analysis of environmental data in the space, time and spectral domain.

EAS 6500.course_name: Climate and Global Change.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6500.course_description: The physics behind the climate and its potential changes, as well as an introduction to the policy issues in global change.

EAS 6501.course_name: Introduction to Atmospheric Dynamics.  2 Credit Hours.
EAS 6501.course_description: Introduction to the basic fundamental fluid dynamics that control atmospheric motions.

EAS 6502.course_name: Introductory Fluid Dynamics and Synoptic Meteorology.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6502.course_description: Fundamental principles of atmospheric fluid dynamics, analysis of meteorological codes, weather data and patterns, and numerical weather prediction.

EAS 6512.course_description: An introduction to the use of geophysical fluid dynamics in describing and modeling the atmosphere.

EAS 6522.course_name: Dynamics of the Tropical Atmosphere and Oceans.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6522.course_description: Explores the dynamics of the tropical atmosphere and ocean and how they interact to produce climatic features such as the monsoons, El Nino, and La Nina.

EAS 6525.course_name: Weather Risk and Modeling.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6525.course_description: Overview of the physics and dynamics behind different types of hazardous weather and the mathematical tools to model the risks associate with these events.

EAS 6532.course_description: Structure and dynamics of phenomena including weather regimes, storm tracks, El Nino-Southern Oscillation, teleconnections, monsoons, Artic Oscillation, stratospheric polar vortex, and stratosphere-troposphere coupling.

EAS 6670.course_description: This course emphasizes physical concepts and analytic techniques for solving problems in atmospheric instabilities and wave dynamics at various temporal and spatial scales.

EAS 6672.course_description: An advanced class on the ocean circulation as a dynamical system to understand the basic equations governing it, together with its variability.

EAS 6751.course_name: Physical Properties and Rheology of Rocks.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6751.course_description: Structure, physical properties, and rheology of minerals and rocks with applications to engineering structures and natural phenomena in the Earth. Fundamentals of rock mechanics and crack propagation. Crosslisted with CEE 6751.

EAS 6761.course_description: Acquaints students with fate of major pollutants, nutrients, organic compounds such as pesticides, PAH's, and trace metals in sedimentary systems. Crosslisted with CEE 6761.

EAS 6765.course_description: Interactions between microorganisms and the geosphere; microbial energetics and genetics; geochemical controls on microbial diversity and activity; redox and acid-base balances; biogeochemical cycles; evolution. Crosslisted with BIOL 6765.

EAS 6790.course_name: Air Pollution Physics and Chemistry.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6790.course_description: Interaction to the physical and chemical processes affecting the dynamics and fate of air pollutants at the local, regional, and global scales.  Particular emphasis is on tropospheric pollutant chemistry and transport. Crosslisted with CEE 6790.

EAS 6792.course_name: Air Pollution Meteorology and Chemistry.  3 Credit Hours.
EAS 6792.course_description: Air pollution history, atmospheric stability and boundary layer dynamics, atmospheric dispersion, atmospheric transport, air pollution modeling. Crosslisted with CEE 6792.

EAS 6793.course_description: Structure and dynamics of atmospheric boundary layers. Introduction to turbulence and turbulent transport. Crosslisted with CEE 6793.

EAS 6794.course_description: Application of modern numerical methods to the prediction of atmospheric chemical and physical compositions; specific applications using computer models developed by the students are included. Crosslisted with CEE 6794.

EAS 6795.course_description: Chemical and physical properties of natural and anthropogenic aerosols.  Sources, transport, transformation, and fate of primary/secondary, organic/inorganic, atmospheric semi-volatiles and aerosols. Crosslisted with CEE 6795.

EAS 6XXX.course_name: Earth and Atmospheric Sciences Elective.  1-21 Credit Hours.

EAS 7999.course_name: Preparation for Ph.D. Qualifying Exam.  1-21 Credit Hours.

EAS 8011.course_description: A forum for graduate students in earth and atmospheric sciences to present and discuss topics related to their research interests.

EAS 8012.course_description: A forum for graduate students in earth and atmospheric sciences to present and discuss topics related to their research interests.

ECEP 6301.course_name: Power System Control and Operation.  3 Credit Hours.
ECEP 6301.course_description: Introduction to methods for the real time operation and control of power systems; to study the hardware and software technologies of modern energy management systems. Credit will not be awarded for both ECEP 6301 and ECE 6320.

ECEP 6304.course_description: Comprehensive introduction to electricity economics, including economic theory, markets, and policy. Renewable energy, information systems, smart grid, and consumers examined as drivers for market architecture.

ECEP 6305.course_name: Power System Planning & Reliability.  3 Credit Hours.
ECEP 6305.course_description: To introduce basic concepts as well as analysis and optimization techniques underlying reliability assessment of electric power systems and planning techniques. Credit not awarded for both ECEP 6305 and ECE 6322.

ECEP 6310.course_description: Apply methods and techniques learned throughout the program to conduct energy system design. Students prepare a project proposal leading to a final report and presentation.

ECEP 6351.course_description: The theory and practice of modern power system protection techniques. Credit will not be awarded for both ECEP 6351 and ECE 6323.

VIP 2600.course_name: Vertically Integrated Project: Multidisciplinary project-based team, sophomore level.  1 Credit Hour.
VIP 2600.course_description: Zero-credit course for students receiving pay/stipends for participation in VIP courses.  Students held to same grading standards as VIP 2601/2602; can participate multiple semesters; no volunteers.

VIP 6600.course_description: Zero-credit course for graduate students receiving pay/stipends for participation in VIP projects. Students can participate multiple semesters. Volunteers are not permitted.

CETL 2000.course_name: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant Preparation.  1 Credit Hour.
CETL 2000.course_description: This course is an introduction to the procedural information and practical skills needed to be an effective undergraduate teaching assistant.  May be used as free elective credit with department approval.

CETL 2001.course_name: Fundamentals of Peer Tutoring.  1 Credit Hour.
CETL 2001.course_description: This course is an introduction to the practical skills needed to be an effective peer tutor at Georgia Tech. May not be used towards degree requirements.

CETL 2002.course_name: Fundamentals of K-12 Tutoring.  1 Credit Hour.
CETL 2002.course_description: This course is an introduction to the practical skills needed to be an effective tutor in the K-12 arena.  May not be used towards degree requirements.

CETL 2698.course_description: Credit hours to be arranged.  Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.  May not be used towards degree requirements.

CETL 3801.course_description: Topics of current interest.  May not be used towards degree requirements.

CETL 4001.course_name: Principles of Learning and Teaching I.  3 Credit Hours.
CETL 4001.course_description: This course focuses on the knowledge and skills necessary for effective classroom instruction and management including: educational psychology, instructional design and delivery techniques.  May be used as free elective towards BS degrees with department approval.

CETL 4002.course_name: Principles of Teaching and Learning II.  3 Credit Hours.
CETL 4002.course_description: This course focuses on the knowledge and skills necessary for effective classroom instruction and management including instructional planning, assessment, and the teaching professional community.  May be used as free elective towards BS degrees with department approval.

CETL 4698.course_description: Credit hours to be arranged.  Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.  May not be used towards degree requirements.

CETL 6490.course_name: Advanced Environmental Data Analysis.  3 Credit Hours.
CETL 6490.course_description: A unified view of the theories and applications underlying the statistical analysis of environmental data in the space, time and spectral domain.

CETL 8000.course_name: Graduate Teaching Assistant Preparation.  1 Credit Hour.
CETL 8000.course_description: This course is an introduction to the procedural information and practical skills needed to be an effective graduate teaching assistant.

CETL 8701.course_name: Classroom Management and Policies: Effective Teaching.  1 Credit Hour.
CETL 8701.course_description: A course in which students learn about official Georgia Tech policies impacting instruction and develop skills to resolve problems and enhance classroom learning.

CETL 8711.course_name: Student and Teacher Enhancement Partnership Summer Training.  1-21 Credit Hours.
CETL 8711.course_description: Participants attend training sessions on pedagogy, classroom management, educational technology; engage in practice teaching; and design action plans for partnering with local high school teachers.

CETL 8712.course_name: STEP Fellows Academic Year Seminar.  1 Credit Hour.
CETL 8712.course_description: This is the academic year follow-up course for STEP fellows.  It is a forum to share and to continue training as the fellows work in their STEP high schools.

CETL 8713.course_name: Teaching and Learning in Higher Education.  3 Credit Hours.
CETL 8713.course_description: This course explores how to apply evidence-based teaching practices in higher education including principles of learning, student development, inclusive teaching, and instructional strategies..

CETL 8714.course_description: Apprentice to faculty mentor and help teach a college course.  Get feedback from mentor, CETL, and a peer learning community.  Explore types of academic careers.

CETL 8715.course_description: Apprentice to faculty mentor and help teach a college course. Get feedback from mentor, CETL, and a peer learning community.  Explore types of academic careers.

CETL 8717.course_name: Course Design for Higher Education.  3 Credit Hours.
CETL 8717.course_description: This course examines evidence-based teaching, formative and summative assessment, and educational technology as students apply the backward design process in developing a college course.

CETL 8718.course_name: Teaching Capstone in Higher Education.  3 Credit Hours.
CETL 8718.course_description: Students apply evidence-based teaching and backward design principles, student assessment, peer and mentor feedback through supervised college teaching in this Tech to Teaching certificate capstone.

CETL 8721.course_name: Academic Writing for Graduate Students and.  1 Credit Hour.
CETL 8721.course_description: Through examination of writing samples and practice, students learn techniques for enhancing proposal preparation and methods for evaluating writing as future instructors and thesis directors.

CETL 8722.course_name: Academic Writing for International Graduate Students.  1 Credit Hour.
CETL 8722.course_description: This course aids international graduate students in enhancing their academic writing skills in English through exposure to, and practice of producing examples of academic writing. Credit will not be awarded for both CETL 8722 and CETL 8723.

CETL 8723.course_name: Academic Writing for International Graduate Students.  2 Credit Hours.
CETL 8723.course_description: This course helps international graduate students enhance their academic writing skills in English through analysis and production of academic writing samples. Credit not awarded for both CETL 8723 and CETL 8722.

CETL 8731.course_description: Participants in this course work through numerous exercises and scenarios in order to prepare them professionally and personally for a future career in academics.

CETL 8741.course_description: An examination and practice of oral presentations in a variety of academic scenarios: e.g., conference talks, proposal presentations, discussion facilitation, job talks, and oral exams/defenses.

CETL 8791.course_name: Instructional Practices for International.  2 Credit Hours.
CETL 8791.course_description: Enhancement of English pronunciation and instructional skills for international teaching assistants.  In-class and small-group language practice; discussion of teaching methodology.

CETL 8792.course_name: Classroom English and Pedagogy for International.  2 Credit Hours.
CETL 8792.course_description: Enhancement of English pronunciation and instructional skills for international teaching assistants.  In-class and small-group language practice; discussion of teaching methodology; individual tutoring.

CETL 8793.course_name: Oral Skills for International Graduate Students.  2 Credit Hours.
CETL 8793.course_description: An oral skills class designed to help graduate students become more accurate and fluent in both verbal and nonverbal skills. In addition to working on acquiring an American accent and body language when speaking English, students will work on basic presentation skills. Credit will not be awarded for CETL 8793 and CETL 8797.

CETL 8794.course_name: Academic English for International Graduate Students.  1 Credit Hour.
CETL 8794.course_description: Enhancement of English pronunciation for international teaching assistants.  In-class and small group language practice.

CETL 8795.course_name: Advanced Oral Skills for International Graduate Students and Teaching Assistants.  2 Credit Hours.
CETL 8795.course_description: An advanced oral skills class designed to help graduate students improve their verbal ability in English for teaching, making presentations, and interacting in academic and professional situations. Credit will not be awarded for both CETL 8796 and CETL 8795.

CETL 8796.course_name: Presentation Skills for International Graduate Students.  2 Credit Hours.
CETL 8796.course_description: This advanced oral skills class is designed to help graduate students improve their presentation skills in English for more effective communication in academic/professinal situations. Credit will not be awarded for both CETL 8795 and CETL 8796.

CETL 8797.course_name: Oral Communication for International Graduate Students.  2 Credit Hours.
CETL 8797.course_description: In this class, students work on fluency, pronunciation clarity, and appropriateness in spoken communication to prepare for effective and confident participation in their academic communities. Credit will not be awarded for both CETL 8797 and CETL 8793.

CETL 8997.course_name: Student and Teacher Enhancement Partnership.  1-21 Credit Hours.

COA 1011.course_name: Fundamentals of Design and the Built Environment I.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 1011.course_description: Introduction to creative problem-solving and the design realization cycle through project-based design exercises that emphasize the role of representation.

COA 1012.course_name: Fundamentals of Design and the Built Environment II.  4 Credit Hours.
COA 1012.course_description: Introduction to the design of complex problems through an emphasis on integrative and collaborative design strategies, research, critical reflection, and interdisciplinary team work.

COA 1060.course_name: Introduction to Design and the Built Environment.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 1060.course_description: Introduction to architecture, building construction, and industrial design through case studies that illuminate past and present practices, as well as future possibilities within the disciplines.

COA 2241.course_name: History of Art I.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 2241.course_description: A survey of artistic manifestations from primitive times to the present.  First semester sequence, prehistoric through Renaissance; second semester, Renaissance through contemporary art.

COA 2242.course_name: History of Art II.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 2242.course_description: A survey of artistic manifestations from primitive times to the present.  First semester sequence, prehistoric through Renaissance; second semester Renaissance through contemporary art.

COA 3114.course_name: Art and Architecture in Classical Greece.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 3114.course_description: An intensive on-site investigation of the role that the arts and architecture have played in the development of classical Greek civilization.

COA 3115.course_name: Art and Architecture in Italy I.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 3115.course_description: Investigations of the painting, sculpture, and architecture of the Classical, Early Christian, Byzantine, and Medieval periods in Italy with special emphasis on Rome.

COA 3116.course_name: Art and Architecture in Italy II.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 3116.course_description: Investigations of the painting, sculpture, and architecture of the Renaissance and Baroque periods in Italy with special emphasis on the works of Rome.

COA 4000.course_name: Furniture Workshop: Material Potential and Fabrication Strategies.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 4000.course_description: The course investigates construction into the design cycle to explore the boundaries between furniture, architecture, and sculpture. Exercises introduce furniture production techniques, material properties, and CNC milling.

COA 4010.course_name: History of Construction Industry.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 4010.course_description: Addresses how today's construction industry is organized and its particular characteristics, how it evolved from early times and where it may be heading in the future.

COA 4805.course_description: Topics in design and the built environment.

COA 6010.course_name: History of Construction Industry.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 6010.course_description: Addresses how today's construction industry is organized and its particular characteristics, how it evolved from early times and where it may be heading in the future.

COA 6011.course_description: Urban design laboratory problems focusing on analysis, design, and implementation strategies for contemporary urban problems.

COA 6114.course_name: Art and Architecture in Classical Greece.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 6114.course_description: An intensive on-site investigation of the role that the arts and architecture have played in the development of classical Greek civilization.

COA 6115.course_name: Art and Architecture in Italy I.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 6115.course_description: Investigations of the painting, sculpture, and architecture of the Classical, Early Christian, Byzantine, and Medieval periods in Italy with special emphasis on Rome.

COA 6116.course_name: Art and Architecture in Italy II.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 6116.course_description: Investigations of the painting, sculpture, and architecture of the Renaissance and Baroque periods in Italy with special emphasis on the works of Rome.

COA 6120.course_description: Study of suburban redevelopment trends, projects, and policies that improve environmental, social, and economic sustainability, with an emphasis on urban design strategies.

COA 6151.course_name: History of Urban Form.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 6151.course_description: History of the city as a collective work of architecture with an emphasis on the city's physical form and space.  Credit not allowed for both COA 6151 and ARCH 4151.

COA 6763.course_name: Design of Design Environments.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 6763.course_description: Analysis of design processes; analysis of current design tools at both the user interface and functional levels; procedures for developing better design tools.  Credit not allowed for both COA 6763 and ID 6763 or CS 6763.

COA 6764.course_description: Software development course focusing on 3D geometric constructions and modeling;  emphasizes solid modeling and its role in design.  Crosslisted with CS 6764.

COA 7011.course_name: Urban Design Studio I.  6 Credit Hours.
COA 7011.course_description: Advanced urban design problems emphasizing the application of contemporary urban design research and multidisciplinary collaboration into the design process.

COA 7012.course_name: Urban Design Studio II.  6 Credit Hours.
COA 7012.course_description: Advanced urban design problems emphasizing the application of contemporary urban design research and multidisciplinary collaboration into the design process.

COA 8530.course_description: Discussion of research and pedagogy topics and methodologies for city and regional planning.

COA 8600.course_name: The Genesis of Architecture.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8600.course_description: The nature of architecture illustrated from those of all cultures; determinist theories; its social values and its meanings to the individual- material, physical, anthropological, and cognitive.

COA 8610.course_name: Thought and Interpretation in Architecture from the Hellenic Period to the 1830's.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8610.course_description: A survey of architectural thought and theory taking account of other fields; paralleled by a review of major critical texts and assessments to the present day.

COA 8612.course_name: Thought and Interpretation in Architecture from the 1830's to the Twentieth Century.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8612.course_description: A survey of architectural thoughts and theory taking account other fields; paralleled by a review of major critical texts and assessments to the present day.

COA 8620.course_name: The Design and Evolution of American Space.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8620.course_description: Topical seminar on the development of urban, suburban, and rural American spatial forms, with emphasis on the relationship between public order and vernacular settlement.

COA 8625.course_name: Theories of Inquiry in Architecture.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8625.course_description: Introduction to research paradigms and their assumptions. The formulation of questions and frameworks of description, representation, analysis, interpretation, and data control.

COA 8630.course_name: Theories of Architecture, Space and Culture.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8630.course_description: Accounts of the social functions of architectural space and associated design choices, across a variety of building types and scales of environmental design. Credit will not be awarded for both COA 8630 and ARCH 4630.

COA 8635.course_name: Architecture and Policy:  Linking Theory and Practice.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8635.course_description: Methods and theories of planning, design, facilities management, and evaluation as they relate to organizational policy and development.

COA 8640.course_name: Theories of Psychology for Architecture.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8640.course_description: An examination of social and psychological theory as it is applied to the creation and use of space.

COA 8645.course_name: Analytical Models of Built Space and Its Functions.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8645.course_description: Introduction to analytical ideas and methodologies for the quantitative description of built space, form, building use, and functions.  Layouts as configurations: boundaries, accessibility, visibility, extensions.

COA 8650.course_name: Formal Descriptions of Designs: Analyses of Space, Shape, and Form.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8650.course_description: Introduction to the form and computational description of designs, with an emphasis on spatial patterns. Geometrical constructions, combinatorial approaches, analyses of shape.

COA 8672.course_name: Research Seminar in Design Computation.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8672.course_description: Seminar review of developments in computing applied to architecture; current major research issues.

COA 8674.course_name: Structuring Multimedia Design Knowledge.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8674.course_description: Theories and tools for structuring multimedia knowledge for design and designers.

COA 8676.course_name: Design and Engineering Databases.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8676.course_description: Survey of database use in design and engineering; surveys relational, object-oriented database technology, and ISO-STEP methods of integration.

COA 8680.course_name: Performance Aspects of Building Systems Design.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8680.course_description: Engineering analysis of building (sub) systems based on a performance ontology.  Criteria, metrics, and tools for performance aspect evaluations in different building technology domains.

COA 8685.course_description: Numerical simulation of performance characteristics of whole buildings.  Review of the finite element method for uniform treatment of transport phenomena in different building technology domains.

COA 8690.course_name: Integrated Design and Engineering Environments for Buildings.  3 Credit Hours.
COA 8690.course_description: Surveys of issues for effective integration of heterogeneous design tools for building; previous efforts, current approaches; advanced techniques, including ISO-STEP and IAI.
