ECE 7350.course_description: An in-depth treatment of several analytical techniques used in current practice for solving real-world EM wave propagation problems and their impact on wireless communications.

ECE 7380.course_name: Topics in Computational Electromagnetics.  3 Credit Hours.
ECE 7380.course_description: Computational approaches for applications such as radar signature prediction, microwave antenna and device design, and modeling techniques for electronic packaging.

ECE 7721.course_name: Are You Thinking of Becoming An Academic?.  1 Credit Hour.
ECE 7721.course_description: How to run a successful research program, advise students, apply and get a job in academia, navigate promotion and tenure, and other aspects of academia.

ECE 7722.course_description: The objective of the proposed class is to prepare students interested in applying for faculty positions for interview season and for successful start of academic career. After this class, students will have prepared material for applying for academic positions as well as developed interview talk with detailed feedback.

ECE 7741.course_description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Program introduction. Technical resume preparation. GT Robotics labs & resources.

ECE 7742.course_description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Selecting and applying for Internship. Developing capstone project proposal. Public speaking practice and preparation.

ECE 7743.course_description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Interview preparation & career search. Technical report writing and presentation.

ECE 7750.course_name: Mathematical Foundations of Machine Learning.  3 Credit Hours.
ECE 7750.course_description: Provides the mathematical background for two of the pillars of modern data science: linear algebra and applied probability.

ECE 7751.course_name: Probabilistic Graphical Models in Machine Learning.  3 Credit Hours.
ECE 7751.course_description: The course provides an introduction to theory and practice of graphical models in machine learning. It covers three main aspects; representation, probabilistic inference, and learning.

ECE 7785.course_name: Introduction to Robotics Research.  3 Credit Hours.
ECE 7785.course_description: Familiarizes students with the core areas of robotics; mechanics, control, perception, AI, and autonomy. Provides an introduction to the mathematical tools required in robotics research.

ECE 7999.course_name: Preparation for Doctoral Qualifying Examination.  1-21 Credit Hours.
ECE 7999.course_description: This course is reseved for students who are studying for the ECE Preliminary Exam.

ECE 8001.course_description: Speakers with diverse backgrounds and representing many different industries, professions, and institutions describe their experiences, entrepreneurial ventures, and research challenges.

ECE 8002.course_description: Speakers with diverse backgrounds and representing different industries, professions, and institutions describe their experiences, entrepreneurial ventures, and research challenges.

ECE 8010.course_description: Seminar presentations describing ECE-related research projects, centers, and other activities at Georgia Tech.

ECE 8022.course_description: Seminar presentations on oral and written technical communication skills needed by electrical and computer engineering professionals. Credit for this course may not be used toward the master's degree in ECE.

ECE 8740.course_description: Graduate Internship at a partner company, GTRI or a GT Robotics lab.

ECE 8741.course_description: Teams or individuals apply the knowledge and skills acquired throughout the MS program to a faculty supervised robotics project.

ECE 8750.course_name: Robotics Research Foundation I.  3 Credit Hours.
ECE 8750.course_description: Multidisciplinary research course supervised by two robotics faculty from different schools participating in the robotics Ph.D. program.

ECE 8751.course_name: Robotics Research Foundation II.  3 Credit Hours.
ECE 8751.course_description: Continuation of AE 8751 (Robotics Research Foundation I).

ECE 8997.course_description: For students holding graduate teaching assistantships.

ECE 8998.course_description: For students holding graduate research assistantships.

ECE 8999.course_name: Preparation for Doctoral Dissertation.  1-21 Credit Hours.
ECE 8999.course_description: This course is reserved for students who are actively seeking Ph.D. advisors and /or dissertation topics.

SPAN 1001.course_description: Introduction to listening, speaking, reading and writing in Spanish and to the culture of Spanish-speaking regions. Some aspects of everyday life in the Spanish-speaking world will also be introduced. Conducted in Spanish. No native speakers allowed. Credit not allowed for both Span 1001 and 1101.

SPAN 1002.course_description: Continued listening, speaking, reading and writing in Spanish with further study of the culture of Spanish-speaking regions. No native speakers allowed. Credit not allowed for both SPAN 1002 and SPAN 1102.

SPAN 1813.course_description: Topics of current interest in Spanish.

SPAN 2001.course_description: Review of basic grammatical concepts: conversational, reading, and writing activities; cultural aspects of the Hispanic world. Conducted in Spanish. No native speakers allowed.

SPAN 2002.course_description: Review of basic grammatical concepts; conversational, reading, and writing activities; cultural aspects of the Hispanic world. Conducted in Spanish. No native speakers allowed.

SPAN 2690.course_description: Intensive intermediate Spanish conducted abroad with focus on issues and perspectives of the target region.

SPAN 2694.course_description: Modern Language Undergraduate Internship for pay for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Modern Language.

SPAN 2695.course_description: Modern Language Undergraduate Internship for credit for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Modern Languages.

SPAN 2698.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

SPAN 2699.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

SPAN 2813.course_description: Topics of current interest in Spanish.

SPAN 3040.course_name: A Practical Application of Spanish Grammar.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3040.course_description: A review of important structures of Spanish, presented in communicative contexts vital to the academic careers of students.  Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 3050.course_name: Introduction to Reading Hispanic Literature.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3050.course_description: This course bridges language study and the study of literature by helping students read, understand , and interpret literature as a system of communication in Spanish.

SPAN 3061.course_name: Spanish for Business I: Fundamentals.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3061.course_description: Introduction to business language in the Hispanic world. Development of linguistic abilities to this end, with emphasis on those cultural factors that lead to commercial success. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 3064.course_description: This course facilitates acquisition of a broad vocabulary and awareness of cultural customs and trends pertaining to the healthcare field.  Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 3070.course_description: Students study the musical traditions of the Andes, Mexico and the Caribbean, focusing on the rhythms, instruments, artists, style and tendencies present. Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 3101.course_name: Spanish Conversation: Issues and Strategies I.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3101.course_description: Development of communicative ability and cross-cultural awareness through discussion of contemporary issues in the Hispanic world. Conducted in Spanish. No native speakers allowed.

SPAN 3111.course_name: Composition: Analysis and Development I.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3111.course_description: Writings from the Hispanic world used as a springboard for analysis and enrichment of self-expression and development of precision in written communication. Incorporates grammar review. Conducted in Spanish. No native speakers allowed.

SPAN 3122.course_name: Cultural History of Spain II: Nineteenth and Twentieth Century Spain.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3122.course_description: History of Spanish culture from 1800 to the present. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 3130.course_name: Spanish for Heritage Speakers.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3130.course_description: Course designed for heritage speakers with little or no formal instruction in Spanish who want to expand their linguistic skills in a content-based framework.

SPAN 3151.course_description: This course combines current event discussion with ongoing conversation practice.  Students participate in in-class discussions plus weekly language exchanges with native Spaniards.  Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 3200.course_name: Globalization in Latin America.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3200.course_description: Case-studies examination of globalization in Latin America regarding politics and industry, migration, culture and communication, and health and the environment. Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 3211.course_description: This course introduces students to current issues in the culture and history of contemporary Spain. Articles, videos, and news clips are used as springboard for discussion. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 3235.course_description: Selected journalistic and literary writings used as a springboard for discussion of social, economic, and political issues of contemporary Latin America. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 3241.course_name: The Individual and the Family in Hispanic Literature.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3241.course_description: Analysis and discussion of the portrayal of the individual and the family in selected readings from Hispanic literature. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 3242.course_name: Society in Hispanic Literature.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3242.course_description: Study of Hispanic society and political thought in selected literary works.  Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 3260.course_name: Identity in Hispanic American Literature.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3260.course_description: This course examines the construction of personal, cultural, national, political, and regional identity in Hispanic American literature over the past two centuries.  Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 3300.course_name: Satire & Media in the Americas.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3300.course_description: This course explores how new types pf satire challenge traditional media and impacts political communication in today's democratic societies in the Americas. Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 3500.course_name: Science Fiction in Latin America.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3500.course_description: This course is a survey of Latin America science-fiction. Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 3590.course_name: Issues of Sustainable Development in the Andean Region.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3590.course_description: Historical and social context of contemporary issues of cultural, economic and environmental sustainability in the Andean region.  Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 3591.course_name: Cultural Patrimony in Peru.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3591.course_description: Using literature, film and art, this course examines cultural patrimony in Peru and its impact on society, economy, environment and threats to its preservation.  Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 3592.course_name: Culture and Commerce in the Andes.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3592.course_description: Examines the 'business of nature' in the extractive economies of the Andes and culture clashes of Western and indigenous perspectives of development. Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 3690.course_name: Commerce and Sustainable Communities.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3690.course_description: Study of the connectedness and community impact of contemporary issues of economic, sociocultural, and environmental sustainability in Mexico.  Conducted in Spanish.  Part of the Spanish intensive summer LBAT program.  Admission by application only.

SPAN 3691.course_name: Business Communication and Correspondence in the Hispanic.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3691.course_description: Refinement of accuracy/flexibility in oral/written expression. Focus on appropriate use of strategies, business negotiation protocols, lexical precision in business transactions. Incorporates grammar review.  Part of the Spanish intensive summer language program. Admission by application only.

SPAN 3692.course_name: Business and Culture in the Hispanic World.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3692.course_description: Study of cultural issues, tendencies, and traditional patterns of behavior in Spanish-speaking people as they relate to business practices.  Value systems and formal manifestations. Regional variations, including the U.S. Hispanic culture. Part of the Spanish intensive summer language program. Admission by application only.

SPAN 3693.course_name: Science and Technology in the Hispanic World.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3693.course_description: Study of business organizations and use of technology in the Spanish-speaking world. Specialized vocabularies of business, economics, statistics, and computer science. Geographical and anthropological background. Part of the Spanish intensive summer language program.  Admission by application only.

SPAN 3694.course_name: Business and Culture in the Hispanic World: Seminar Abroad.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3694.course_description: Field study of technology, economic trends, business firms, financial institutions, and cultural protocols in the Spanish-speaking area. Part of the Spanish intensive summer language program. Admission by application only.

SPAN 3697.course_name: Spanish for Health Care Professionals.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3697.course_description: Culture-specific conceptions of health, medical vocabulary, professional-patient protocols, professional-professional protocols, symptoms, treatments.  Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 3698.course_name: Health Care Industry in Spain.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 3698.course_description: Study of culture-specific values in health systems in Spain/ Europe.  Visits to local sites. Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 3813.course_description: Topics of current interest in Spanish.

SPAN 3822.course_description: Topics of current interest in Spanish.

SPAN 3823.course_description: Topics of current interest in Spanish.

SPAN 3833.course_description: Topics of current interest in Spanish.

SPAN 4061.course_name: Spanish for Science and Technology I: Fundamentals.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 4061.course_description: Introduction to scientific vocabulary and discourse in Spanish, by fields of interest. Study of expository texts, numerical expressions, and graphic aids. Development of some reading and translation strategies. Writing feature descriptions and article/report summaries in Spanish. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 4062.course_name: Spanish for Science and Technology II: Applications.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 4062.course_description: Advanced analysis of scientific and technological discourse in Spanish.  Focus on reading strategies and oral discussion of topics such as use and transfer of technology and the acculturation issues that follow. Further development of comprehension, production, and translation strategies, with emphasis on professional communications and on writing feature descriptions, summaries, and abstracts. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 4065.course_description: This course is designed to develop the students' understanding of the linguistic structure of the Spanish language. The topics covered in this course include: phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, language change, and language variation.

SPAN 4101.course_description: Advancement of oral and written proficiency using a workshop and project-development format to focus on communicative precision, style and register. Includes some treatment of grammar. No native speakers allowed.

SPAN 4102.course_name: Spanish for the Professions.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 4102.course_description: This course develops communication skills for professional purposes with an emphasis on specialized vocabulary building and cultural nuances of the Spanish-speaking world. Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 4150.course_name: Learning in the Hispanic Community.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 4150.course_description: This class combines classroom discussion with Hispanic community service projects to allow students to study Hispanic cultures and practice Spanish with native speakers.  Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 4156.course_name: Spanish Service-Learning Abroad I.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 4156.course_description: Students complete service projects in a Spanish-speaking country abroad and attend weekly class meetings that combine student presentations and documentaries with a guest-speaker series. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 4157.course_name: Spanish Service-Learning Abroad II.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 4157.course_description: Students complete service projects in a Spanish-speaking country abroad and gain an in-country immersion opportunity that hones oral and aural skills and increases cultural competence through real-life interactions with the host community abroad. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 4158.course_name: Social, Cultural, and Linguistic Diversity in Spain.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 4158.course_description: This course examines the social, cultural, and linguistic dimensions of sustainability and the concepts of diversity and equity in the Spanish context.  Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 4160.course_name: U.S. Spanish: Language and Cultures.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 4160.course_description: Linguistic groups, changes, bilingualism, customs, traditions of US Hispanics. Course project on current migration, legal, financial, educational, health, media or political issues/advances. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 4165.course_name: Bilingualism in the Spanish Speaking World.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 4165.course_description: This course introduces students to bilingualism at both individual and societal levels within the Hispanic communities in the US, Spain, and Latin America. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 4170.course_description: Advanced linguistic analysis of the Spanish language, particularly as it contrasts with English. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 4220.course_name: Nation and Narration in Latin America.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 4220.course_description: This course examines the connection between nation and narration in Latin American literature and film and explores the narrative construction of national identities. Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 4237.course_name: Food, Power, and Sustainability in Latin America.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 4237.course_description: Food as gateway to region-by-region study of issues of sustainable development in Latin America.  Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 4244.course_name: Visual Culture and Social Agenda in Latin America.  3 Credit Hours.
SPAN 4244.course_description: Historical and cultural analysis of the role of art, visual image and iconography as social commentator and public platform in Latin America.  Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 4251.course_description: Students complete inernships with agencies, organizations, and businesses serving Atlanta Hispanics, using their Spanish language skills in a professional work environment. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 4255.course_description: Literary and theatrical aspects of Hispanic drama are explored through class discussion and performance of a collection of contemporary one-act plays. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 4270.course_description: This course explores the relationships between the Spanish language and the Hispanic cultures and societies of the world. Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 4350.course_description: This course examines the representation and development of cities in the Hispanic World.  Students develop three urban projects based on their study.  Taught in Spanish.

IMBA 6000.course_name: Strategic Decision Making and Compromise Game.  1 Credit Hour.
IMBA 6000.course_description: A multifirm, competitive management simulation.  The objective is to sharpen intra-firm communications skills using the internet as the communications channel and the art of compromise.

IMBA 6010.course_name: Cross-cultural Communications for Management.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6010.course_description: Participants learn tools and information to improve communications skills with new approaches and increased understanding while taking into account the effects of cross-cultural differences on communications.

IMBA 6021.course_name: Data Analysis for Business.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6021.course_description: Covers common statistical tools for the analysis of corporate data such as descriptive statistics, probability concepts, sampling and estimation, hypothesis testing, and regression analysis.

IMBA 6030.course_name: Organizational Behavior and Theory.  3 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6030.course_description: Students learn the basic concepts and principles of organizational behavior and utilize such to analyze and solve organizational decision-making problems.

IMBA 6031.course_name: Leadership and Organizational Behavior.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6031.course_description: This course focuses on the challenges in leading teams and organizations in increasingly complex, global, and dynamic business environments.

IMBA 6032.course_name: Leadership and Organizational Behavior.  3 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6032.course_description: This course focuses on the challenges in leading teams and organizations in increasingly complex, global, and dynamic business environments.

IMBA 6040.course_description: Participants are provided with a non-traditional approach using an analytical method with a global perspective to the concepts and role of economics in the world environment.

IMBA 6050.course_name: Financial and Managerial Accounting.  3 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6050.course_description: Course covers financial reporting and analysis issues facing firms, and managerial accounting information necessary for planning, controlling, and decision making within such firms.

IMBA 6061.course_name: Information Systems for Global Organizations.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6061.course_description: Tools and techniques to manage the information technology infrastructure that supports a global organization.

IMBA 6070.course_name: Managerial Finance in World Markets.  4 Credit Hours.

IMBA 6081.course_description: Covers the basic conceptual and analytical skills that are required in managing operations and confronting operational problems in competitive markets.

IMBA 6090.course_description: Students are provided with an understanding of marketing and consumer behavior concepts and tools with an international environment approach.

IMBA 6101.course_name: Product Strategies for Global Markets.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6101.course_description: Developing and marketing new products and services with an emphasis on international markets.

IMBA 6110.course_name: Risk Management and Technology Transfer.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6110.course_description: A course based upon a combination of cases, historical data, and theoretical interpretation on the analysis and allocation of risk in international investment and technology transfer.

IMBA 6121.course_name: Managing the Global Workforce.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6121.course_description: A survey of global workforce management principles and the skills necessary to function effectively in a supervisory role in a global organization.

IMBA 6132.course_description: Integrate knowledge of the functional areas of a business to understand how firms gain and sustain a competitive advantage in a globally competitive environment.

IMBA 6140.course_description: This course utilizes case studies of companies in various industries and in national cultures to highlight organizational and cultural differences between major economies in the global environment.

IMBA 6150.course_name: Entrepreneurship and Entrepreneurial Firms.  1 Credit Hour.
IMBA 6150.course_description: Participants explore the increasing importance of small and medium-sized businesses and new ventures in international business.

IMBA 6160.course_name: National and International Regulation of Business.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6160.course_description: Deals with learning how to control the legal aspects of international decisions.

IMBA 6170.course_name: Quality, Sustainable Technology, Competitiveness.  1 Credit Hour.
IMBA 6170.course_description: Students learn the philosophy and techniques of strategic quality management while focusing on assessment and group decisions centered on sustaining technology and competitiveness.

IMBA 6180.course_name: Leadership Skills and Processes.  1 Credit Hour.
IMBA 6180.course_description: Focuses on identifying and developing the attributes of successful leadership.

IMBA 6200.course_description: A unifying course providing a simulated application of the material taught in the core courses of the program.

IMBA 6210.course_name: Analysis of Emerging Technology.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6210.course_description: A case-based course dealing with the role and impact of digital technology in large and small organizations, with special emphasis on multinational companies.

IMBA 6220.course_description: A case course building an information bank of theory and practice on start-up enterprises.  Several entrepreneurs will co-teach the course with a faculty leader.

IMBA 6230.course_description: A role-play course involving the complex international negotiation simulation dealing with an international business enterprise and its relationship with one or more governments.

IMBA 6250.course_description: Analysis of foreign exchange markets, exchange rate risk management, international portfolio investments, international asset pricing, cross-border M&A, and equilibrium conditions in international markets.

IMBA 6260.course_name: Global Supply Chain and Electronic Commerce.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6260.course_description: Examines business, managerial and economic issues in the management of global supply chains and the role of electronic commerce in the supply chain.

IMBA 6300.course_name: Analysis of Global Environments I.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6300.course_description: Analysis of a specific region through an international study tour with emphasis on understanding the economy, culture and business environment.

IMBA 6301.course_name: Analysis of Global Environments.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6301.course_description: Analysis of a specific region through an international study tour with emphasis on understanding its economy, culture and business environment.

IMBA 6310.course_name: Analysis of Global Environments II.  3 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6310.course_description: Analysis of a specific region through an international study tour with emphasis on understanding the economy, culture and business environment.

IMBA 6400.course_name: Global Strategy Project I.  1 Credit Hour.
IMBA 6400.course_description: Students work on a real world problem related to global strategy.  The focus in this course is on data collection and problem definition.

IMBA 6401.course_name: Global Strategy Project I.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6401.course_description: Students work on a real world problem related to global strategy. The focus in this course is on problem definition, data collection and client engagement management.

IMBA 6410.course_name: Global Strategy Project II.  1 Credit Hour.
IMBA 6410.course_description: Students work on a real world problem related to global strategy.  The focus in this course is on defining a preliminary solution that has desirable characteristics.

IMBA 6411.course_name: Global Strategy Project II.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6411.course_description: Students work on a real world problem related to global strategy. The focus in this course is on problem definition, data collection and client engagement management.

IMBA 6420.course_name: Global Strategy Project II.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6420.course_description: Students work on a real world problem related to global strategy.  The focus in this course is on defining and presenting a comprehensive solution.

IMBA 6430.course_name: Business Strategies for Sustainability.  2 Credit Hours.
IMBA 6430.course_description: Cross-functional strategies to address competitive and regulatory demands placed on firms for achieving sustainable business practices.

PSYC 1101.course_description: A broad survey of the major topics in psychology including, but not limited to, research methodology, biological and social factors influencing behavior, development, learning, memory, personality, and abnormal.

PSYC 2005.course_description: This course explores multicultural identities and key multicultural competencies needed to succeed in a global and international society.

PSYC 2012.course_name: Introduction to Research Methods.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 2012.course_description: Introduction to methods used in conducting research on human behavior. Experimental research emphasized, but course covers other methods and some statistics.

PSYC 2015.course_description: Introduction to methods used in conducting research on human behavior. Experimental research emphasized, but course covers other methods and some statistics.

PSYC 2020.course_description: Introduction to probability and statistics as applied to psychological data.  Tests for means, variances, correlation, ANVOA, and regression.  Credit not allowed for both PSYC 2020 and PSYC 6022.

PSYC 2103.course_name: Human Development Over the Life Span.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 2103.course_description: An introductory, non-laboratory based examination of human development across the lifespan with an emphasis on typical patterns of physical, cognitive, and social development.

PSYC 2130.course_name: Introduction to Educational Psychology.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 2130.course_description: Introduction to Educational Psychology applies the basic principles of child and adolescent development to the study of teaching and learning.

PSYC 2210.course_description: Consideration of the behavior of individuals in social contexts, including interpersonal and group settings.

PSYC 2220.course_description: An introduction to industrial/organizational psychology providing an overview of behavior in the workplace and psychology applied in industrial and organizational settings.

PSYC 2230.course_description: This course surveys the spectrum of psychiatric disorders (symptoms, epidemiology, etiology, and treatment) and provides a perspective on adaptive functioning and psychological resilience.

PSYC 2240.course_description: Introduction to major approaches to personality theory.

PSYC 2250.course_description: This course provides students with an opportunity to learn about the similarities and differences in human behavior across cultures.

PSYC 2270.course_name: Introduction to Engineering Psychology.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 2270.course_description: Engineering psychology presented as an integral component in the design and evaluation of human-machine systems. Applied problems and general methodological questions are examined.

PSYC 2280.course_name: Psychology of Creativity and Art.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 2280.course_description: Evolutionary theories of art production and consumption; the psychology of aesthetics; psychological correlates of creative and artistic behavior.

PSYC 2595.course_description: Psychology Undergraduate Internship for credit for freshman or sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Psychology.

PSYC 2695.course_description: Psychology Undergraduate Internship for credit for freshman or sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Psychology.

PSYC 2698.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of the faculty member.

PSYC 2699.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

PSYC 2760.course_description: Theories and research in psychlinguistics: how people comprehend and speak human languages. Includes speech perception, word recognition, parsing, sentence interpretation, word production, and sentence generation. Crosslisted with LING 2760.

PSYC 3000.course_name: Science of Stress, Anxiety, and Happiness.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 3000.course_description: This course will cover the psychological and neuroscientific mechanisms underlying happiness and its relation to subjective health and well-being.

PSYC 3005.course_name: Mindfulness: Science and Practice.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 3005.course_description: This experiential course is an introduction to mindfulness where students will study the theory of mind-body awareness and apply principles to daily life.

PSYC 3009.course_description: This course is designed to provide a broad overview of the psychological influences on health and illness in our society.

PSYC 3011.course_description: Exploration of the central aspects of human cognition including pattern recognition, attention, memory, language, categorization, problem solving, and decision making; phenomena and methods are stressed.  Credit not allowed for both PSYC 3011 and PSYC 3012.

PSYC 3012.course_name: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 3012.course_description: Examines the foundations of Cognitive Psychology including methods, analysis techniques and psychological theories involved in perception, attention, memory, problem solving, decision making, and language.  Credit not allowed for both PSYC 3012 and PSYC 3011.

PSYC 3020.course_description: Neurophysiological, endocrinological, and biochemical bases of sensory and motor functioning, motivation, learning, memory, and behavior dysfunction.

PSYC 3031.course_name: Experimental Analysis of Behavior.  4 Credit Hours.
PSYC 3031.course_description: History, theory, and methods of behavior analysis. Topics include shaping, stimulus-stimulus and response-consequence contingencies, stimulus control, and choice.

PSYC 3040.course_description: An examination of how sensations and perceptions are processed by humans.  Topics covered will include vision, hearing, the skin senses, taste, smell, and the vestibular senses.

PSYC 3041.course_name: Human Sensation and Perception.  4 Credit Hours.
PSYC 3041.course_description: An examination of human sensory systems and perceptual processes. For Psychology majors only.

PSYC 3100.course_name: Neuroscience of Mental Health.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 3100.course_description: This course will introduce the science of well-being and provide an in-depth examination of the neural mechanisms underlying well-being and various character strengths.

PSYC 3750.course_name: Human Computer Interface Design and Evaluation.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 3750.course_description: Human computer interface is considered in terms of user-system compatibility. Concepts in human factors and interface design are covered in relation to capabilities of both humans and computers. Crosslisted with CS 3750.

PSYC 3751.course_name: Introduction to User Interface Design.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 3751.course_description: Describes the characteristics of interaction between humans and computers and demonstrates techniques for the design and evaluation of user interfaces and computational systems.

PSYC 3790.course_name: Introduction to Cognitive Science.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 3790.course_description: Multidisciplinary perspectives on cognitive science. Interdisciplinary approaches to issues in cognition, including memory, language, problem solving, learning, perception, and action. Crosslisted with CS, PST, and ISYE 3790.

PSYC 4010.course_description: Introduction to differential psychology providing an overview of differences in humans. Topics such as abilities, temperament, and group differences (e.g., gender) are addressed.

PSYC 4011.course_description: Exploration of the central aspects of human cognition including pattern recognition, attention, memory, language, categorization, problem solving, and decision making; phenomena and methods are stressed. Credit will not be awarded for both PSYC 4011 and PSYC 3011.

PSYC 4020.course_description: Neurophysiological, endocrinological, and biochemical bases of sensory and motor functioning, motivation, learning, memory, and behavior dysfunction. Credit will not be awarded for both PSYC 4020 and PSYC 3020.

PSYC 4025.course_description: Research and applications concerning acqusition of new behavior and knowledge, including accounts based on classical and instrumental conditioning and information-processing models of memory and learning.

PSYC 4031.course_description: Consideration of the applications of methods and data of experimental psychology.  Understanding of human capabilities and limitations is applied to design of technology and environments.

PSYC 4041.course_name: Human Sensation and Perception.  4 Credit Hours.
PSYC 4041.course_description: An examination of human sensory systems and perceptual processes. Credit will not be awarded for both PSYC 4041 and PSYC 3041.

PSYC 4050.course_description: A survey of the history, methods, and content of modern psychological theory, research, and application. Schools of psychology (e.g., structuralism, functionalism, behaviorism, gestalt psychology) and central theories of psychology will be reviewed in their historical and philosophical context.

PSYC 4090.course_description: Examination of the neural basis of cognitive function. Basic anatomy and methods are covered. Primary focus is on contemporary problems in the neurocognitive study of perception, memory, language, and attention, as well as disorders in these domains.

PSYC 4100.course_description: An analysis of drug-behavior interactions with emphasis on basic pharmacology, role of contingencies in drug effects, mechanisms of drug dependency, drugs as stimuli, and basic neuropharmacology.

PSYC 4200.course_name: Advanced Topics in Cognitive Psychology.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 4200.course_description: An advanced survey in various topics in cognitive psychology.  Topics will vary over time.

PSYC 4260.course_description: Survey of research concerned with the nature and causes of adult age differences in behavior.

PSYC 4270.course_description: Fundamentals of psychological test construction (reliability and validity) and applications of intelligence, personality, and interest assessment.  Topics will include theoretical, practical, ethical, and legal issues.

PSYC 4600.course_description: The first of a two course sequence in which selected students conduct original work under the direction of a faculty member. The student will produce a proposal for research that will be undertaken during the second course (PSYC 4601).

PSYC 4601.course_description: The second of a two course sequence in which selected students conduct original work under the direction of a faculty member.

PSYC 4690.course_name: Sensation and Perception: A Computational Perspective.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 4690.course_description: Explore advanced models of human brain and behavior, review the field's progress, and assess current approaches' strengths and limitations. Engage in hands-on group projects developing computational models.

PSYC 4695.course_description: Psychology Undergraduate Internship for credit for juniors and seniors, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Psychology.

PSYC 4696.course_description:
Psychology teaching assistantship for pay under the guidance of a faculty member. Permit only.
Note: This course cannot count toward Psychology Electives or Free Electives.

PSYC 4697.course_name: Psychology Undergraduate Teaching Experience.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 4697.course_description: An introduction to teaching biology for undergraduate teaching assistants, with a focus on effective teaching, active engagement of students, and development of innovative classroom activities.

PSYC 4698.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

PSYC 4699.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

PSYC 4740.course_description: This course considers the implications of neuroscience research on culture, society, the legal system, and on how individuals conceive of their nature as human beings.

PSYC 4770.course_name: Psychology and Environmental Design.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 4770.course_description: Introduction of psychological concepts relevant to environmental design. Survey of selected methods for assessing human-made environments and development of design solutions to selected problems. Crosslisted with ARCH 4770.

PSYC 4790.course_name: Seminar in Cognitive Science.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 4790.course_description: A seminar-type course in cognitive science focusing on integrating and deepening students' cognitive science knowledge and skills.  Topics include memory, language, problem solving, learning, perception, and action. Crosslisted with CS, PST, and ISYE 4790.

PSYC 4791.course_name: Integrative Project in Cognitive Science.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 4791.course_description: An integrative course in cognitive science focusing on the integration and use of concepts and skills from cognitive science.  A different integrative project or set of projects will be taken on each semester; students will contribute on the basis of their background and skills.  Crosslisted with CS, ISYE, and PST 4791.

PSYC 4792.course_name: Design Project in Cognitive Science.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 4792.course_description: Individual project with a cognitive science faculty member, designed as a supplement to the student's senior design project or thesis in their major area. Crosslisted with CS, ISYE, and PST 4792.

PSYC 4803.course_description: Special topics or courses of an experimental nature.

PSYC 4813.course_description: Special topics or courses of an experimental nature.

PSYC 4823.course_description: Special topics or courses of an experimental nature.

PSYC 4907.course_description: Students engage in individual and group projects under the direction of a faculty member.

PSYC 4908.course_description: Students engage in individual and group projects under the direction of a faculty member.

PSYC 4909.course_description: Students engage in individual and group projects under the direction of a faculty member.

PSYC 4910.course_description: Students engage in individual and group projects under the direction of a faculty member.

PSYC 6000.course_name: Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR).  1 Credit Hour.
PSYC 6000.course_description: Topics include research misconduct, data management, use of animal and human subjects, conflicts of interest and commitment, authorship, publication, peer review , and collaboration and mentoring.

PSYC 6011.course_description: Survey course on human cognition including pattern recognition, attention, memory, categorization, problem solving, consciousness, decision making, intention, and the relation between mind and brain.

PSYC 6012.course_description: Fundamental theory and research in social behavior including social perception/cognition, attitude formation and change, social influences, and group processes.

PSYC 6013.course_description: Neurophysiological, endocrinological, and biochemical bases of sensory and motor functioning, motivation, learning, memory, and behavior dysfunction.

PSYC 6014.course_description: This course examines how sensations and perceptions of the outside world are processed by humans, including physiological, psychophysical, ecological, and computational perspectives.

PSYC 6015.course_description: Overview of concepts, assumptions, methods, theories, and research in human development across the life span including cognitive, emotional, and social behavior.

PSYC 6016.course_name: Experimental Analysis of Behavior.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 6016.course_description: Conceptual, methodological, and theoretical issues in the experimental analysis of behavior with special emphasis on classical and operant conditioning as foundations for complex behavior.

PSYC 6017.course_description: Theory, methods, and applications of research on human abilities, including intelligence, aptitude, achievement, learning, aptitude treatment interactions, information processing correlates, and measurement issues.

PSYC 6018.course_name: Principles of Research Design.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 6018.course_description: Introduction to basic principles and practices of empirical research in psychology.  Covers both experimental and correlational methods and designs.

PSYC 6019.course_name: Statistical Analysis of Psychological Data I.  5 Credit Hours.
PSYC 6019.course_description: Introductory treatment of descriptive and inferential statistics as applied to psychological research.

PSYC 6020.course_name: Statistical Analysis of Psychological Data II.  5 Credit Hours.
PSYC 6020.course_description: Introductory treatment of inferential statistics, especially the general linear model, as applied to psychological research.

PSYC 6021.course_description: Survey of personality theories, research, and methods of assessment.

PSYC 6022.course_name: Psychological Statistics for HCI.  4 Credit Hours.
PSYC 6022.course_description: Introduction to statistical methods as applied to psychological data within the HCI domain.  Credit not allowed for both PSYC 6022 and PSYC 2020.

PSYC 6023.course_name: Psychological Research Methods for HCI.  4 Credit Hours.
PSYC 6023.course_description: Introduction to psychological research methods within the HCI domain. Credit not allowed for both PSYC 6023 and PSYC 2020.

PSYC 6031.course_name: Engineering Psychology: Analysis Techniques.  2 Credit Hours.
PSYC 6031.course_description: This course covers the basic analysis techniques used to investigate human-machine systems and human performance.

PSYC 6032.course_name: Engineering Psychology: Environmental Stressors and Performance.  1 Credit Hour.
PSYC 6032.course_description: This course covers environmental stressors and their influence on human performance.  Emphasis will be placed onnoise, lighting, micro-gravity and atmospheric conditions.

PSYC 6033.course_name: Engineering Psyc: Cognitive Ergonomics.  1 Credit Hour.
PSYC 6033.course_description: This course applies the research findings from cognitive psychology to the design of products and systems that involve people.

PSYC 6034.course_description: This course covers the basic human factors principles involved in display formatting.

PSYC 6035.course_name: Engineering Psyc: Controls and Workspace.  1 Credit Hour.
PSYC 6035.course_description: This course covers the basic human factors principles involved in controls and workspace layout.

PSYC 6040.course_name: Current Topics in Cognition and Brain Sciences.  1 Credit Hour.
PSYC 6040.course_description: This course presents current research topics in cognition and brain science.

PSYC 6041.course_name: Current Topics in Cognitive Aging.  1 Credit Hour.
PSYC 6041.course_description: This course presents current research topics in cognitive aging.

PSYC 6042.course_name: Neuroimaging: From Image to Inference.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 6042.course_description: This course details the potential and limits of fMRI and critically evaluates the inferences that can be drawn from fMRI studies.

PSYC 6043.course_name: Engineering Psychology Research Seminar.  1 Credit Hour.
PSYC 6043.course_description: This course presents current research topics in engineering psychology.

PSYC 6060.course_description: A survey covering psychological aspects of aging, mind, and behavior (perception, cognition, emotion, mental health) and topics relevant to adulthood (e.g. caregiving and retirement).

PSYC 6090.course_description: Examines the foundations of Cognitive Neuroscience, including the biological mechanisms underlying cognition, the dominant theories, and the experimental techniques.

PSYC 6270.course_description: Fundamentals of psychological testing. Topics include test construction and application issues.

PSYC 6750.course_description: Describes the characteristics of interaction between humans and computers and demonstrates techniques for the evaluation of user-centered systems. Crosslisted with CS 6750.

PSYC 6753.course_name: Human-Computer Interaction-Professional Preparation and Practice.  1 Credit Hour.
PSYC 6753.course_description: Preparation for a professional career in HCI. Hands-on workshops in resume and portfolio building, interviewing, public speaking, team work. HCI career choices and trajectories.

PSYC 6755.course_description: Describes the theory and practice of designing effective and efficient interactions between people and technology.

PSYC 6795.course_name: Introduction to Cognitive Science.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 6795.course_description: Multidisciplinary perspectives on cognitive science. Interdisciplinary approaches to issues in cognition, including memory, language, problem solving, learning, perception, and action. Crosslisted with CS and ISYE 6795.

PSYC 6998.course_description: Final project for students completing a Human-Computer Interaction master's degree.  Repeatable for multi-semester projects.

PSYC 7020.course_name: Survey of Cognitive Aging.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 7020.course_description: Introduction to theory and research on adult cognitive development, including intelligence, attention, memory, and problem solving.

PSYC 7101.course_name: Engineering Psychology I: Methods.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 7101.course_description: Basic methods used to study human-machine systems including both system analysis and human performance evaluation techniques. These methods will be applied to specific systems.

PSYC 7102.course_name: Engineering Psychology II: Displays, Controls, and Workspace.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 7102.course_description: Basic principles of human factors for the design, evaluation, and use of displays, controls, and workspace layouts including new technologies and associated human factors problems.

PSYC 7103.course_name: Engineering Psychology III: Environmental Stressors and Human Performance.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 7103.course_description: Environmental stressors and their influences on human performance, physiological function, and emotional responses including work/rest cycles, jetlag, noise, vibration, glare, weightlessness, etc.

PSYC 7104.course_name: Psychomotor and Cognitive Skill Learning and Performance.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 7104.course_description: Human capabilities and limitations for learning and performing psychomotor and cognitive skills are studied.

PSYC 7105.course_name: First-year Research Project I.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 7105.course_description: First year graduate students will initiate a research project.

PSYC 7106.course_name: First-year Research Project II.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 7106.course_description: First year graduate students will complete a research project.

PSYC 7201.course_description: This course introduces an overview of issues relevant to behavior in the workplace and psychology applied in industrial and organizational settings.

PSYC 7202.course_description: The course provides a conceptual framework for personnel selection guided by scientific principles, research, and theory as well as by professional, legal, and technical guidelines.

PSYC 7203.course_name: Motivation and Job Attitudes.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 7203.course_description: Examines theory and pragmatics in description, prediction, and measurement of work-related behavior and associated evaluations. Includes theoretical and methodological problems in field and laboratory contexts.

PSYC 7204.course_description: This course will focus on theory, principles, techniques, and practices relevant to training and developing human resources. Research and professional literature will be examined.

PSYC 7301.course_name: Introduction to Multivariate Statistics.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 7301.course_description: Foundations for multivariate analysis including properties of linear composite variables, multiple regression, multiple and partial correlation, MANOVA, factor analysis, multiple discriminant analysis, canonical correlation, etc.

PSYC 7302.course_description: Methods of causal modeling to study causal relations including issues of causality, establishing causality, fundamentals of linear structural equation modeling with latent variables, fitting models.

PSYC 7303.course_description: Preparation of students in statistical theory and techniques relevant to becoming professionally involved in construction, analysis, and evaluation of psychology and personnel tests.

PSYC 7700.course_description: Discussion of issues faced by professional psychologists in the areas of teaching, research, and professional practice. Ethical issues in all of these areas are emphasized.

PSYC 7701.course_description: Supervised college teaching including techniques, course and curriculum design, evaluation. Students will prepare and present lectures with direct observations and video taping for discussion.

PSYC 7790.course_description: A hands-on course covering a range of cognitive modeling methodologies. It explores the analysis, development, construction, and evaluation of models of cognitive processing. Crosslisted with CS and ISYE 7790.

PSYC 7999.course_name: Preparation for Doctoral Qualifying Exam.  1-21 Credit Hours.

PSYC 8000.course_name: Seminar in Experimental Psychology.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8000.course_description: Critical examination of current problems in a selected area of general experimental psychology. Areas to be discussed may vary each time course is offered.

PSYC 8010.course_name: Seminar in Cognitive Psychology.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8010.course_description: Critical examination of current problems in a selected area of cognitive psychology.  Areas to be discussed may vary each time course is offered.

PSYC 8020.course_name: Seminar in Cognitive Aging.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8020.course_description: Critical examination of current problems in a selected area of cognitive aging. Areas to be discussed may vary each time course is offered.

PSYC 8030.course_name: Seminar in Comparative Psychology.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8030.course_description: Critical examination of current problems in a selected area of comparative psychology.  Areas to be discussed may vary each time course is offered.

PSYC 8040.course_name: Seminar in Engineering Psychology.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8040.course_description: Critical examination of current problems in a selected area of engineering psychology.  Areas to be discussed may vary each time course is offered.

PSYC 8050.course_name: Seminar in Industrial/Organizational Psychology.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8050.course_description: Critical examination of current problems in a selected area of industrial/organizational psychology.  Areas to be discussed may vary each time course is offered.

PSYC 8060.course_name: Seminar in Quantitative Psychology.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8060.course_description: Presentation and discussion of quantitative approaches to psychology.  Topics will vary, but might include neural networks, measurement theory, behavioral ecology, modeling, system dynamics, etc.

PSYC 8070.course_name: Seminar in Cognitive Neuroscience.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8070.course_description: Critical examination of current problems in selected areas of cognitive neuroscience.  Areas to be discussed vary each time.

PSYC 8080.course_name: Seminar in Cognition and Brain Science.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8080.course_description: Critical examination of current problems in selected areas of cognition and brain sciences.  Areas to be discussed may vary each time.

PSYC 8795.course_name: Colloquium in Cognitive Science.  1 Credit Hour.
PSYC 8795.course_description: Reading of research papers by leading cognitive scientists, attendance at their colloquia, and meeting with them to discuss research. Crosslisted with CS and ISYE 8795.

PSYC 8802.course_description: Covers current issues and recent advances in cognitive neuroscience.

PSYC 8803.course_name: Special Topics in Applied Statistics.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8803.course_description: Covers current issues and recent advances in the application of statistical methods to research in psychology.  Instructors select the specific focus for a given term.

PSYC 8804.course_name: Special Topics in Cognitive Aging.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8804.course_description: Covers current issues and recent advances in cognitive aging.

PSYC 8805.course_name: Special Topics in Cognitive Neuroscience.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8805.course_description: Covers current issues and recent advances in cognitive neuroscience.

PSYC 8806.course_name: Special Topics in Cognitive Psychology.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8806.course_description: Covers current issues and recent advances in cognitive psychology.

PSYC 8807.course_name: Special Topics in Engineering Psychology.  3 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8807.course_description: Covers current issues and recent advances in Engineering Psychology.

PSYC 8811.course_description: Special topics that cover current issues and recent advances in Psychology.

PSYC 8812.course_description: Special topics that cover current issues and recent advances in Psychology.

PSYC 8890.course_name: Special Topics in Cognitive Science.  3 Credit Hours.

PSYC 8900.course_name: Special Problems in Experimental Psychology.  1-21 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8900.course_description: Students conduct research under direction of a faculty member on problems in the general area of experimental psychology.

PSYC 8901.course_name: Special Problems in Engineering Psychology.  1-21 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8901.course_description: Students conduct research under the direction of a faculty member on problems in the general area of engineering psychology.

PSYC 8902.course_name: Special Problems in Industrial/Organizational Psychology.  1-21 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8902.course_description: Students conduct research under the direction of a faculty member on problems investigating some psychological aspect of industrial/organizational problems.

PSYC 8903.course_name: Special Problems in Human-Computer Interaction.  1-21 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8903.course_description: Students conduct research under the direction of a faculty member on problems in the general area of human-computer interaction.

PSYC 8904.course_name: Special Problems in Cognitive Aging.  1-21 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8904.course_description: Students conduct research under the direction of a faculty member on problems in cognitive aging.

PSYC 8905.course_name: Special Problems in Cognitive Neuroscience.  1-21 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8905.course_description: Students conduct research under the direction of a faculty member on problems in cognitive neuroscience.

PSYC 8906.course_name: Special Problems in Cognitive Psychology.  1-21 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8906.course_description: Students conduct research under the direction of a faculty member on problems in cognitive psychology.

PSYC 8907.course_name: Special Problems in Cognition & Brain Science.  1-21 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8907.course_description: Students conduct research under the direction of a faculty member on problems in cognition and brain sciences.

PSYC 8908.course_name: Special Problems in Quantitative Psychology.  1-21 Credit Hours.
PSYC 8908.course_description: Students conduct research under the direction of a faculty member on problems in quantitative psychology.

PSYC 8997.course_description: For graduate students holding a teaching assistantship.

PSYC 8998.course_description: For graduate students holding a research assistantship.

CHBE 1750.course_description: An introduction to the field of bioengineering, including the application of engineering principles and methods to problems in biology and medicine, the integration of engineering with biology, and the emerging industrial opportunities. Crosslisted with AE, BMED, ECE, ME, and MSE 1750.

CHBE 1XXX.course_name: Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Elective.  1-21 Credit Hours.

CHBE 2100.course_description: Material and energy balances for single-phase and multi-phase processes common to chemical engineering. Phase equilibrium and analysis of reacting systems.

CHBE 2110.course_name: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics I.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 2110.course_description: Elements of engineering thermodynamics. First and second laws. Analysis of engineering machinery: compressors, turbines, engines, refrigeration.  Credit not allowed for both CHBE 2110 and  CHBE 2130.

CHBE 2120.course_name: Numerical Methods in Chemical Engineering.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 2120.course_description: Numerical methods are introduced and applied to the solution of chemical engineering problems. An introduction to chemical process simulation, and the appropriate software is provided.

CHBE 2130.course_name: Chemical Engineering  Thermodynamics I.  2 Credit Hours.
CHBE 2130.course_description: Basic principles of chemical engineering thermodynamics including first and second laws, equations of state, PVT properties, power cycles and refrigeration.  Credit not allowed for both CHBE 2130 and CHBE 2110.

CHBE 2140.course_description: Principles of thermodynamics, including: first and second laws; equations of state; PVT properties; power cycles and refrigeration; phase equilibria; fugacity and activity coefficients; multi-reaction equilibrium.

CHBE 2698.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

CHBE 2699.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

CHBE 2801.course_description: Topics relevant to chemical engineering not currently covered in the undergraduate curriculum are presented as demand or interest warrants.

CHBE 2801R.course_description: Designed to provide time for application of conceptual knowledge and extension of instruction. Optional and non-billable.

CHBE 2803.course_description: Topics relevant to chemical engineering not currently covered in the undergraduate curriculum are presented as demand or interest warrants.

CHBE 2XXX.course_name: Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Elective.  1-21 Credit Hours.

CHBE 3110.course_name: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics II.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 3110.course_description: Phase and chemical reaction equilibria. Vapor-liquid, liquid-liquid, and solid-vapor phase equilibrium Fugacity and activity coefficients. Multi-reaction equilibrium.  Credit not allowed for both CHBE 3110 and CHBE 3130.

CHBE 3130.course_name: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics II.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 3130.course_description: Basic principles of chemical engineering solution and phase equilibrium thermodynamics, including ideal and non-ideal solution models and phase equilibira calculations (VLE, SLE, LLE).  Credit not allowed for both CHBE 3130 and CHBE 3110.

CHBE 3200.course_description: Fundamentals of fluid mechanics and heat transfer. The design and analysis of equipment using the principles of fluid mechanics and heat transfer.

CHBE 3205.course_description: The basic principles of fluid mechanics are introduced and the analysis and design of equipment using these principles is practiced.

CHBE 3210.course_description: Fundamental principles and applications of mass transfer. The analysis of chemical engineering processes and operations involving mass transfer.

CHBE 3215.course_description: Fundamental principles and applications of heat and mass transfer. The analysis of chemical engineering processes and operations involving heat and mass transfer.

CHBE 3225.course_description: Fundamentals of equilibrium-stage and continuous contacting operations.  Applications of principles to distillation, absorption/stripping, extraction, absorption, and other separation technologies.

CHBE 3300.course_name: Chemical Kinetics and Catalysis.  2 Credit Hours.
CHBE 3300.course_description: The basic principles of chemical reaction kinetics, including rate laws, mechanisms, and heterogeneous catalysis are introduced.

CHBE 3600.course_name: Engineering Ethics and Leadership.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 3600.course_description: Development of quantitative and qualitative assessment tools to resolve moral and ethical dilemmas that arise in the performance of engineering duties.

CHBE 3XXX.course_name: Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Elective.  1-21 Credit Hours.

CHBE 4020.course_name: Chemical Engineering in Nanoscale Systems.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4020.course_description: Application of chemical processing fundamentals, fabrication, and characterization to design and analyze technologically important nanoscale systems. The course emphasizes an integrated engineering and science approach.

CHBE 4030.course_name: Chemical Engineering of Energy Systems.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4030.course_description: Students will acquire the knowledge and tools to analyze CHP systems, traditional power generation, refinery and biorefinery configurations and advanced power generation and storage options.

CHBE 4050.course_name: The Science and Engineering of Microelectronic Fabrication.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4050.course_description: An elective class for students interested in fabrication of semiconductor devices focusing on the fundamentals of materials synthesis, chemical and mechanical properties, and chemical reactions. Credit will not be awarded for both CHBE 4050 and CHBE 6050.

CHBE 4200.course_description: This course illustrates engineering/scientific principles and physical models important to the data collection/ interpretation of processes important to the practice of chemical engineering.

CHBE 4210.course_name: Transport Phenomena / Bioprocess Unit Operations.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4210.course_description: This course illustrates engineering/scientific principles and physical models important to the data collection/interpretation of processes important in biotechnology.

CHBE 4300.course_name: Kinetics and Reactor Design.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4300.course_description: Reacting systems are analyzed in terms of reaction mechanisms, kinetics, and reactor design.  Both homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions are considered.

CHBE 4310.course_description: Integrating several ChBE core concepts, bioprocess engineering applies the material to biological systems. Items covered are enzyme kinetics, fermentation, downstream processing, and integrated bioprocesses important to the biotech industries.

CHBE 4320.course_description:
The basic principles of reactor design are introduced, including material and energy balances for homogeneous and heterogeneous
systems.

CHBE 4400.course_description: Dynamics of chemical processes and their control. Techniques of conventional process control as well as digital control. Laboratory experiments to illustrate these concepts.

CHBE 4411.course_name: Process Dynamics and Control.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4411.course_description: Dynamics of chemical processes and their control. Techniques of conventional process control as well as digital control.

CHBE 4412.course_name: Process Dynamics and Control Laboratory.  1 Credit Hour.
CHBE 4412.course_description: Dynamics of chemical processes and their control. Techniques of conventional process control as well as digital control. Laboratory experiments would illustrate these concepts.

CHBE 4505.course_name: Process Design and Economics.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4505.course_description: Principles of flowsheet synthesis and economic analysis and optimization.  A complete design on a chemical process will be undertaken, including concepts of unit operations, design, economics, and safety.  Credit not allowed for both CHBE 4505 and CHBE 4530 (or CHBE 4520).

CHBE 4510.course_name: Process and Product Design And Economics.  2 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4510.course_description: Basic principles of chemical process and product design including heuristic design approaches, heat exchanger network design, optimization, and economic evaluation.  Credit not allowed for both CHBE 4510 and CHBE 4505 (or CHBE 4525).

CHBE 4515.course_description: Fundamental sources of chemical hazards and degree of risk.  Process design and hazard avoidance are used to reduce risk.

CHBE 4520.course_name: Chemical Engineering Capstone Design Project.  2 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4520.course_description: Basic principles of chemical process and product design including heuristic design approaches heat exchanger network design, optimization, and economic evaluation.  Credit not allowed for both CHBE 4520 and CHBE 4505 (or CHBE 4525).

CHBE 4525.course_name: Bioprocess Design and Economics.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4525.course_description: Principles of flowsheet synthesis and economic analysis and optimization. A complete design of a biochemical process will be undertaken, including concepts of unit operations, design, economics, and safety.  Credit not allowed for both CHBE 4525 and CHBE 4530 (or CHBE 4520).

CHBE 4530.course_description: Basic principles of chemical process and product design including heuristic design approaches, heat exchanger network design, optimization, and economic evaluation.  Credit not allowed for both CHBE 4530 and CHBE 4505 (or 4525).

CHBE 4535.course_name: Chemical Product Design, Engineering and Optimization.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4535.course_description: Chemical engineering principles applied to the design of products.

CHBE 4573.course_name: Pulping and Bleaching Laboratory.  2 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4573.course_description: Experiments of pulping, bleaching, fiber, and chemical testing are performed.  Hands-on experience from chip preparation, cooking, pulp processing, and bleaching are provided.

CHBE 4574.course_name: Papermaking and Recycled Pulp Laboratory.  2 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4574.course_description: Experiments of pulp preparation, refining, paperforming, handsheet testing, deinking, and recycled pulp processing are performed. Small paper machine operation will be taught.

CHBE 4600.course_name: Effective Communication for Professional Engineering.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4600.course_description: How engineers communicate with engineering and non-engineering professionals.  Industry speakers from different fields.  Engineering case study. Weekly written and/or oral presentations.

CHBE 4610.course_name: Complex Fluids - Microstructure and Mechanical Properties.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4610.course_description: Complex fluids have interesting, practically relevant mechanical properties that arise from complex microstructures. This course covers fundamental physical principles, experimental characterization techniques and current topics.

CHBE 4698.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

CHBE 4699.course_description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

CHBE 4710.course_name: Microfluidics and Bio Applications.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4710.course_description: The course focuses on the fluid and flow aspects of micro and nano devices. It will cover basic micro/nanofabrication techniques, introduce transport of momentum and materials (including charged and magnetic materials) in small scale, and the applications in biology and medicine.

CHBE 4720.course_name: Pulp and Paper Manufacturing.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4720.course_description: The course provides comprehensive foundational knowledge of the industry enabling the student to understand the role of diverse manufacturing operations and to strategically plan improvements.

CHBE 4730.course_name: Emerging Technologies for Forest Bioproducts.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4730.course_description: The course provides comprehensive knowledge of the manufacture of nontraditional products from forest biomaterials. It analyzes and assesses emerging manufacturing technologies, materials and products.

CHBE 4743.course_name: Fundamentals and Challenges for a Sustainable Chemical Enterprise.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4743.course_description: Life Cycle Inventory methodology will be explored as a means to develop new, sustainable products, materials and manufacturing processes.

CHBE 4745.course_name: Data Analytics for Chemical Engineers.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4745.course_description: Introduction to data analytics and machine learning techniques for chemical engineers. Application of basic regression, classification, dimensional reduction, and clustering techniques to chemical data sets.

CHBE 4746.course_name: Data-Driven Process Systems Engineering.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4746.course_description: This course covers theory of optimization and data-driven modeling methods, and examples of data-driven decision-making in the chemical process industry.

CHBE 4752.course_description: The objective of this course is to give students exposure to the various steps involved in the fabrication of integrated circuits and devices.  This course will include a laboratory segment in which students fabricate MOS transistors, diffused resistors, and MOS capacitors from a bare silicon substrate.  Crosslisted with ECE 4752.

CHBE 4755.course_name: Electronic Packaging Substrate Fabrication.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4755.course_description: This course provides hands-on instruction in basic packaging substrate fabrication techniques, including interconnect design and testing, dielectric deposition, via formation, and metallization. Crosslisted with ECE 4755.

CHBE 4757.course_description: Introduction to the study of blood flow in the cardiovascular system. Emphasis on modeling and the potential of flow studies for clinical research application. Crosslisted with AE and ME 4757.

CHBE 4758.course_description: The mechanics of living tissue, e.g., arteries, skin, heart muscle, ligament, tendon, cartilage, and bone. Constitutive equations and some simple mechanical models. Mechanics of cells. Applications. Crosslisted with AE and ME 4758.

CHBE 4759.course_name: Electrochemical Energy Storage and Conversion.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4759.course_description: An elective class for senior-level students interested in electrochemical storage and covnersion, including the fundamentals of electrochemistry and practical battery and fuel cells.

CHBE 4760.course_name: Biocatalysis and Metabolic Engineering.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4760.course_description: This course provides an in-depth coverage of various topics in biocatalysis and metabolic engineering. Goals of this course are the development of an understanding of proteins as catalysts, their functioning in metabolic networks, their application in various industries, recognition of their potential for addressing future challenges in science and engineering. Crosslisted with CHEM 4760.

CHBE 4762.course_description: This course covers the theory and practice of protein engineering methods, including specific examples of engineered proteins and their applications from the literature.

CHBE 4763.course_name: Pulping and Chemical Recovery.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4763.course_description: Pulping and chemical recovery processes are studied on the reaction, delignification, energy, and liquor reuse.  The process optimization, air and water pollution minimization are taught. Crosslisted with ME 4763.

CHBE 4764.course_description: Pulp bleaching and formation of paper/board products are studied along with testing, end uses, chemical and mechanical treatment of pulp, non-wood and recycled fiber utilization. Crosslisted with ME 4764.

CHBE 4765.course_name: Drug Design, Development and Delivery.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4765.course_description: Introduction to the pharmaceutical development process, including design of new drugs, synthesis and manufacturing issues, and methods for delivery into the body. Includes student presentations. Crosslisted with CHEM and BMED 4765.

CHBE 4767.course_name: Pulp And Paper Lab.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4767.course_description: Fundamentals of pulp and paper testing procedures.

CHBE 4770.course_description: This course surveys the chemical engineering aspects of nuclear power.  Topics include nuclear reactions, fuel cycles, solvent extraction of metals, the properties of actinides and other irradiated fuel materials, fuel reprocessing, and radioactive waste management.  Crosslisted with NRE 4770.

CHBE 4775.course_name: Polymer Science and Engineering I: Formation and Properties.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4775.course_description: An introduction to the chemistry, structure, and formation of polymers, physical states and transitions, physical and mechanical properties to polymer fluids and solids. Crosslisted with CHEM, ME, MSE, and PTFE 4775.

CHBE 4776.course_name: Polymer Science and Engineering II: Analysis, Processing and Laboratory.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4776.course_description: Polymer fabrication processes and methods of characterization and identification of polymers are presented. Experiments in polymerization, processing and property evaluation of polymers.  Crosslisted with CHEM, ME, MSE, and TFE 4776.

CHBE 4781.course_description: A study of medical instrumentation from a systems viewpoint. Pertinent physiological and electro-physiological concepts will be covered. Credit not allowed for both CHBE 4781 and (CHE 4781 or ECE 4781 or BMED 4781 or ME 4781).

CHBE 4782.course_description: Analytical methods for modeling biological systems, including white-noise protocols for characterizing nonlinear systems. Crosslisted with BMED, ECE and ME 4782.

CHBE 4791.course_name: Mechanical Behavior of Composites.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4791.course_description: Stress-strain behavior of composites, property of matrix and reinforcing materials, mechanics of fiber-reinforced composites, lamina and laminate analysis, and mechanical performance. Crosslisted with AE, CEE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 4791.

CHBE 4793.course_name: Composite Materials and Processes.  3 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4793.course_description: Basic principles of selection and design of composite materials and their manufacturing and testing. Cost factors. Laboratory exercises on manufacturing and tests. Crosslisted with AE, CEE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 4793.

CHBE 4794.course_name: Composite Materials and Manufacturing.  4 Credit Hours.
CHBE 4794.course_description: Basic principles of selection and design of composite materials and their manufacturing and testing. Cost factors. Laboratory exercises on manufacturing and tests. Crosslisted with AE, CEE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 4794.

CHBE 4801.course_description: Topics relevant to chemical engineering not currently covered in the undergraduate curriculum are presented as demand or interest warrants.

CHBE 4802.course_description: Topics relevant to chemical engineering not currently covered in the undergraduate curriculum are presented as as demand or interest warrants.

CHBE 4803.course_description: Topics relevant to chemical engineering not currently covered in the undergraduate curriculum are presented as demand or interest warrants.

CHBE 4804.course_description: Topics relevant to chemical engineering not currently covered in the undergraduate curriculum are presented as demand or interest warrants.

CHBE 4805.course_description: Topics relevant to chemical engineering not currently covered in the undergraduate curriculum are presented as demand or interest warrants.

CHBE 4806.course_description: Topics relevant to chemical engineering not currently covered in the undergraduate curriculum are presented as demand or interest warrants.
